PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled; the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we deplore the discriminatory tax proposals as outlined in the Government's preferred option on proposed new and widened tax proposals as so outlined, namely:
Capital Gains Tax
Hidden Death Tax described as ``Capital Gains Tax after death''
Gift Tax
Increased Company Tax
Employer taxes on employees' employment benefits
All such taxes will discriminate against and inhibit progress, growth and employment throughout the nation.

They will attack hardworking people who have built up their assets; they will discourage thrift, they will inhibit development, they will treat unfairly all who plan for the future, they will cause trouble and expense in arriving at the value of the assets; they will discourage industry and punish achievement.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should reject these tax proposals.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Metric System

The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth objection to the Metric system and request the Government to restore the Imperial system.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
Introduction of any additional capital gains taxes, wealth taxes or death duties is opposed on the grounds that:
they adversely affect the small and medium size businesses in Australia, destroying incentive and discouraging investment in this important area of the economy;
the Australian economy, and employment in particular, is heavily reliant on growth in small businesses;

any capital gains that might result when owners of small businesses finally sell the business are not ``windfall gains'' but the result of many years of work and sacrifice, with very little being taken out of the business by way of salaries so that the maximum amount of money can be ploughed back into the business to create growth and jobs;
Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, will protect the rights of private enterprise and reject any inequitable additional taxes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

pass on the full benefit of lower international oil prices on 1 March 1986;
not increase or extend fuel taxes; and
maintain its tax cut commitments.

And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

That the proposed Australian Bill of Rights Bill 1985 will endanger the Federal system in Australia, the State and Federal criminal justice systems, the State and Federal Police Force, the State and Federal education systems, the independence of the churches and religious associations, marriage and the family, children, the unborn, the handicapped, the aged and the infirm, employer and employee relationships, and Australian society generally.
Our petitioners therefore humbly pray:
That the House ensure that a referendum is held before the Australian Bill of Rights 1985 is permitted to become legislation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned shows: That we urge you to oppose the Australian Bill of Rights because:
This Bill does not guarantee vital rights such as:
The right to own your own home and other property and not to be deprived of it without just compensation.
The right to insulate our children from radical forms of education and the right to choice of schools.
The right to a referendum for constitutional amendments.
The right to TRUE freedom of speech.
The Bill gives dangerous, unlimited powers to an unelected Human Rights Commission with no appeal, no legal representation and closed hearings.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should vote to reject the Bill, believing that such a Bill should only be determined by the people at a referendum.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

5. Plant Varietal Rights legislation could lead to higher costs for the grower, the consumer, the plant-breeder and the tax-payer;
6. Plant Variety Rights will lead to a further increase in foreign control of Australia's plant genetic resources;
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that Parliament ensure that it recognises the widespread public opposition to PVR and promote alternative means of royalty collection for plant breeders.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON EDUCATION AND THE ARTS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the time for presentation of the Report of the Standing Committee on Education and the Arts on a proposed amendment to the Copyright Amendment Bill 1986 be extended to 19 September 1986.
I seek leave to make a short statement relating thereto.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Honourable senators will recall that on 11 June this year, which was the second last day of the autumn sittings, the Senate referred to the Standing Committee on Education and the Arts a proposed amendment to the Copyright Amendment Bill 1986. The amendment, which was proposed by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Senator Durack), concerns the copying of certain television and sound broadcasts by educational institutions for educational purposes. The Committee's terms of reference are to report, firstly, on the proposed amendment and, secondly, on `any other related issues arising out of the Committee's deliberations'. The Committee was asked to report on these matters on or before 28 August 1986, which at that time was the anticipated last day of the second week of the Budget session. The Committee advertised in mid-June for submissions to be lodged by 11 July 1986. Given the range and complexity of the issues involved in educational copyright, a reasonable amount of time had to be allowed for the presentation of submissions. Public hearings could not be arranged until 4 and 5 August, just over two weeks ago.

SPEECH.PARA: It is clear from the 97 submissions received by the Committee and the evidence taken that there are numerous complex questions involved in educational copyright law. I should perhaps mention that the Attorney-General's Department has been trying to find answers to these questions for many years. When moving to refer these matters to the Committee, Senator Haines remarked that she thought that any application for an extension of the time limit for the inquiry would be regarded sympathetically by the Senate. The Committee will not be able to table a thorough report on the reference by 28 August. In effect, the report would have had to be tabled by this Friday, 22 August, because of the changed sitting weeks. Tomorrow, therefore, I shall be seeking an extension of the reporting time for this reference. Unless circumstances beyond the control of the Committee intervene, I consider that the Committee will be able to report to the Senate by 19 September 1986, the end of the second week of sittings for the Budget session.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The main purpose of the Remuneration and Allowances Alteration Bill 1986 is to remove the 11.7 per cent catch-up in parliamentary salaries awarded by the Remuneration Tribunal. It also provides for the recovery of that part of the increase which has already been paid. Anyone who has any idea that he might be a little in front will find that that clause will make it certain he will not be. The Bill also adjusts the allowances of certain judges. Again, this is one of those areas that we ought to look at. The Remuneration Tribunal is now handling a lot of money, not only in relation to members and senators but also for a very wide range of people. If one looks at the last part of the annual report, one will find pages and pages listing the people who are on various committees and boards and in a whole range of positions. I respectfully suggest that we ought to look over that list to see whether those bodies and organisations should not have been looked at a little more closely last night.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill also provides that under the Ministers of State Act ministerial salaries will be increased by regulation and not by amendment, as is currently the situation under the Act. I believe it is necessary for us to bear that in mind and see whether we think it is appropriate. Frankly, I do not. Accordingly, we will move an amendment to take away the power of the Government to have the salaries of Ministers fixed by regulation. I think that that amendment would be quite appropriate. The present practice is not acceptable, and, had the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances had the opportunity to meet to consider this matter, it may well have thought so too. I think that, had the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills had the opportunity to view it, it may have passed some comments also. I do not think that the sort of amendment we passed in the last session which allowed ministerial salaries to be paid out imposes a very onerous task. I do not believe that simplifying matters for the bureaucracy is a good enough reason for making the change. Accordingly, I will be moving an amendment which will seek to leave out Part IV; clauses 13, 14 and 15 will be opposed and, in a consequential amendment to page 6, we will seek to leave out the heading of Part IV.

We need to use this opportunity to make a few comments on the remuneration. The public discuss this matter regularly. It is important that we take some notice of what the commissioners say about the status of members of parliament. It is necessary also to mention that the increases recommended by the independent Tribunal have been rejected five times in 10 years by the government of the day. I do not think that the public at large fully appreciates that. I do not think that it fully understands that in many other respects the ranges of remuneration have increased for other people far more than for members of parliament. It is not desirable that being a member of parliament should be seen as a way to make an easy fortune, but I certainly do not believe that we should be in the position where ordinary family people find it impossible to take the job because they cannot afford to hold it.

According to the available information, in 1975 level two public servants were earning $20,000. The earnings of a member of parliament were fixed at that same level of $20,000 because that was deemed to be appropriate. The latest figures that I have been able to obtain show that by 1986 the earnings of level two public servants had increased by 168 per cent while earnings of members of parliament had increased by 127 per cent. The difference in monetary terms is about $8,000. If it was good enough for public servants to be given those levels of increase, I believe that the public should at least know that that is the difference between what they are getting and what members of parliament are getting. The Tribunal carried out a very thorough investigation in its 1984 report. It stated:

It remains important that those who hold such offices should be remunerated at an appropriate level. The present is not the first occasion on which members of parliament have taken a course, and suffered a disadvantage, such as this.

As I have said, this has happened five times in 10 years. The purpose of this legislation is to reduce the award by the 11.7 per cent which the Tribunal had said was desirable if we were to be in a catch up situation. I certainly support that aspect. The state of the nation is such that we have to be shown to be making some practical denial ourselves. I realise that Ministers, whose loads are very large, should suffer the same as us. Notice has been given of another amendment by Senator Harradine concerning the entitlements of members in respect of overseas travel. The Opposition will move an amendment to Senator Harradine's amendment to make the entitlement for overseas travel for spouses or nominees the same as for internal travel. Section 1 (8) of the Remuneration Tribunal 1986 Review states:
For the purpose of this entitlement `nominee' means:
a parent;
a son or daughter other than a dependent child as defined in paragraph 1.19; or
a brother or sister

of the senator or member, and may in special circumstances include one other member (except a member of the staff of the senator or member) approved at the discretion of the Special Minister of State.
I would expect the Special Minister of State to approve those cases on a sparing basis. The present overseas travel clause in respect of which the amendment is being moved says:
For the purpose of this entitlement, `nominee' means a person with whom the senator or member has established a bona fide stable domestic relationship.

There is quite a lot of difference in those definitions and I think at this stage it is preferable that the entitlement for overseas travel is the same as that for internal travel. Accordingly, we will be moving that amendment to Senator Harradine's amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Remuneration and Allowances Alteration Bill 1986 is basically to take away from members of parliament the amount which was awarded to them by the Remuneration Tribunal. —Which would you rather?

—We might at least have had both. In the last session I spoke about the allowances of Ministers. It is a situation that we should be concerned about not only for the present; we should look somewhat into the future. Fairly obviously, allowances for members are not the principal reason why people come here. Indeed, a study was undertaken by the House of Commons to try to find a definition of the job of parliamentarian. It decided to start at what the salary range ought to be. It discovered, I think in a way we would all probably know, that if the salary were zero the House of Commons could still be filled. In other words, there were plenty of people who would want the job even if they were not paid any salary.

SPEECH.PARA: I mention that because it is a point about salaries and a point about democracy in this country. Without a doubt, we could fill this chamber without paying anybody anything, but they would all be beholden to special interest groups and other groups in the community. At some stage we are going to get to that, whether the people out there like it or not. We are going to get there and it will not be too long before we get there. The Press and everybody else like to have a little run on salaries for members of parliament because it is always a good kicking horse. After we got rid of the communist can there was not much else left to kick around the place, so we got stuck into this. It might be fun. One can always get a good rise out of it and a good laugh. But ultimately we shall get to this: Either the government of the day will have to give a massive pay rise to parliamentarians, which will be totally unacceptable to the populace, or we are going to have two chambers with members in them who are beholden to interests outside this place and who are not beholden to the interests of the electorate. We can have one or the other; but we do not have many other directions to go.

Fairly obviously, it is not at that point at the moment, but it is going to go there. There is no stopping it, because every government has made the decision that this Government has, and every parliament has made the decision that this Parliament will make. It is not the Government's decision; it is essentially a decision that is made by the Parliament, because if there was an agreement amongst all parties in the Parliament this Bill would not be here. The fact that it is here is because there is no agreement. No matter who is in opposition, they will not accept the Government doing it, and whoever is in government always make the decision that they do. That is partly due to timing because this chamber is usually not sitting when the Remuneration Tribunal brings down its decisions. There is no Caucus or party meeting to make any decision. The decision is made by Cabinet in isolation, and it is completely predictable. I think there is a problem. It is a worry which will have to be addressed at some stage in the future unless the population of Australia is quite happy for members of parliament to get part of their funds from here and part from somewhere else.

I was recently in the United States of America and one of the interesting things I found in conversations on matters other than wheat was the major worry about the American political system and the massive use of money in buying votes in both Houses. We in Australia are partly excluded from that due to our party system. I must admit that one of the few things I would want to say in favour of the party system in Australia is that it does protect the individual members in a way in which they are not protected in the United States. But if salaries continue to decline at the rate at which they are our members here undoubtedly will not be so protected and it will be possible to buy power, which will be far cheaper than employing a lobbyist. Eventually the people in this place who make the decisions could be bought as they also have families and expenses to meet. They also have to make some decisions as to where their interests lie with regard to their families. I do not think that is a happy prospect. It has not occurred yet and it is not likely to occur for some time, but I do flag that that is the way we are going to go unless some rational decision is made. A rational solution is obviously that the absurd operation of the Tribunal, which has been going on for so many years, ought simply to be abolished. It is a pity it was not abolished in the Budget as that could at least have saved some money. Parliamentarians could then automatically be attached to some level within the Public Service which would entail their going through the normal tribunal operation. I think that would be the only sensible solution. At the moment we are spending money on an inquiry whose recommendations we knock back. If that is sensible expenditure of public money then I should not be here. I think that the Remuneration Tribunal is one of the absurd institutions that we have around the place and it should go. I think all of the other matters that the Remuneration Tribunal looks after, judges salaries and so forth, ought also to be automatically set against some standard.

Another absurd situation which could also be abolished is the whole series of allowances that no longer make any sense whatsoever. In terms of absolute cost, since there are no additional costs involved, we simply ought to collapse the salaries and allowances together-they are all being taxed at the same rate anyhow-instead of having all the additional accounting carried out in the background with people working out allowances that no longer make any sense.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the superannuation.

—Superannuation is obviously a problem connected with that. I think there could be an adjustment for those people who have not had those salary levels so they would not get the windfall profit which they would normally get out of that. Since others are paying 11 per cent of their salary they would then be entitled to the additional remuneration upon retirement. But unless some sensible arrangement is made I believe we will simply continue this rather Alice in Wonderland exercise of asking responsible people in the community genuinely to deliberate on our allowances and bring down recommendations which we then knock back. I do not think we should go on with this utter farce any longer.

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of the amendments which have been flagged, some of which have been circulated, the Australian Democrats will be supporting the Opposition's amendments with regard to the Ministers of State Act, which is dealt with in Part IV. It does not seem to me to be onerous to act in this way. As a matter of principle salaries should be determined by some type of deliberate legislative act rather than simply by being delegated in a form such as that presented here. Senator Harradine has circulated an amendment and Senator Archer has suggested an amendment that the Opposition will move to Senator Harradine's amendment. I have not yet seen the Opposition's amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is coming.

—It has not yet been circulated. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Remuneration and Allowances Alteration Bill amends the Remuneration Tribunal's determination as to salaries of parliamentarians. It was pushed through the House of Representatives yesterday, the first, second and third readings having taken place on the same day. Of course that is a most unusual procedure and places those of us in this chamber at a disadvantage when we attempt to consider the measure and its implications. The Bill is open to amendment by the Senate to modify any other provisions of the Tribunal's determinations of 1986. The Government's Bill amends the determination as to salaries for members of parliament in a way that the Tribunal considers just and reasonable. It would be appropriate at this stage to amend and modify the determinations and decisions of the Tribunal which were unjustified and for which the Tribunal has made no attempt to publish justification.

SPEECH.PARA: One such provision is to grant equality of status for de factos and spouses for the purposes of overseas travel entitlements. That provision was first included in the Tribunal's determination No. 18 of 1984; it was repeated in the Tribunal's determination of 1985 and again this year. Because the Parliament cannot modify a determination without substantive legislation I introduced a Bill on 24 August 1984. During subsequent discussions on that Bill in this chamber the general view-and it was expressed particularly, as I recall, by Senator Button-was that the issues involved would need to be addressed by Parliament. As honourable senators will recall, attempts to have those issues, including the issue of de factos being treated on the same basis as spouses, addressed by this chamber have run into many problems. The problems involved time, priority and also, I believe, deliberate misunderstanding of the issues involved. Today we have the opportunity to address and determine these issues. The Government's Bill provides that opportunity.

This Bill seeks, as mine does, to modify the determination by substantive legislation in respect of the rights and privileges of members of parliament. In respect of those rights and privileges, I believe that there would not be one honourable senator present who would say that the Government has a constitutional priority over, say, an individual member of parliament. Therefore, any argument that the amendment I am proposing is inappropriate at this time falls to the ground on that basis. The appropriate way of dealing with the measure is by amendment rather than by seeking leave to amend my Bill which relates to the 1984 Tribunal determination, and thus have it debated cognately. I emphasise, as I have done consistently, that this is not a matter for political point scoring; it is a matter of principle and should be dealt with as such, whether the arguments are for or against. I add that it is not a matter that can be covered over by subterfuge. I believe the Opposition's amendment would do just that, and I intend to point out how shortly. My view, and I believe it is shared by a very broad cross-section of the community, has always been that the Tribunal's 1984 decision granting equality of status to de factos with married spouses, repeated in its 1985 and 1986 determinations, publicly demeans the institution of marriage, strikes at its legislative recognition, and flies in the face of the responsibility of parliamentarians to uphold publicly a fundamental principle underpinning the laws we pass through Parliament.

Let me go to the question of the laws we pass through Parliament. What are those laws when it comes to the question of marriage? They have been clearly and repeatedly stated. They have been stated, for example, in the Family Law Act and in the Marriage Act. I point out that there are also obligations under the marriage regulations, and I will deal with those first. Under the Marriage Act regulations an authorised celebrant must give to persons intending marriage the following statement:
Marriage and family life have been basic to the strength of our society for a long time. The Parliament, in the Family Law Act has placed great stress on their importance.
In the Family Law Act the principles are high sounding, although the practice may not be so. It says of marriage:
. . . the need to preserve and protect the institution of marriage as the union of a man and a woman to the exclusion of all others voluntarily entered into for life.
It goes on:

. . . the need to give the widest possible protection and assistance to the family as the natural and fundamental group unit of society, particularly while it is responsible for the care and education of dependent children.

Under section 46 (1) of the Marriage Act the Parliament insists that the authorised celebrant must, in the presence of witnesses, remind the couple of `the solemn and binding nature of the relationship into which you are now about to enter'.

We in this Parliament have made those declarations about the status of marriage. Surely we in this Parliament have a responsibility to uphold those principles, to uphold them when they relate particularly to matters that affect this Parliament. I will quote a former distinguished member of the House of Representatives, Mr Kim Beazley senior, who in opposing the Tribunal's decision in 1984 said:

(The Commonwealth) should hesitate a long time before further belittling marriage, in this case the marriage of Federal legislators, with the proposal to ask the taxpayer to finance the travel of people who are not spouses and who have undertaken no obligation such as the obligation of marriage.

Insofar as the obligation of marriage is concerned, Kim Beazley senior is absolutely correct. A similar view was expressed by Justice Sir Murray McInerney of the Victorian Supreme Court on 21 August 1982 when he said:

I have read one paper on this subject by an author who started with the grievance that de factos were required to `forfeit the rights of married people'. De factos are not required to forfeit anything. They have elected to live together outside marriage by virtue of which alone they would have acquired those rights. They have in many cases elected-deliberately-not to acquire the status and more significantly not to undertake the duties and responsibilities inherent in that status. Very often that election has been made precisely because the party is not prepared to subject himself or herself to any legal obligation in respect of the incidents of the proposed cohabitation.

I believe that by facilitating this conscious rejection of obligations we are deliberately denigrating the vast majority of couples who accept their obligations by entering into marriage. Let me make my position very clear because, of course, in the course of my working life, both in the trade union movement and in this sphere, I have dealt with and helped persons not in a marriage relationship. Let nothing that I say here be taken in any way as an attack on benefits paid to de factos. Of course, those benefits have been regarded as not placing a de facto relationship in a more advantageous position than a bona fide marriage relationship. I have studied this for some years and the initial provisions in respect of de factos were precisely that. Originally they were designed to ensure that cohabiting unmarried couples were not placed in a position of advantage in relation to legally married couples, for example, in regard to pension benefits. That was the first basis within the social security system for recognising de facto relationships. In other words, had the Department of Social Security not recognised de facto relationships then of course a de facto couple living together would have received pension benefits higher than that received by a married couple. That was the first basis of recognition. Later benefits extended to persons in cohabiting circumstances or de facto relationships could perhaps be regarded as tolerant and charitable gestures of society to those who had not yet come to the real vision of the beauty of marriage and its fundamental importance to society. So we come to some of the statements that have been made in support of this measure. One of those statements was made by the then Attorney-General, Senator Gareth Evans. That statement was truly surprising, to say the least. In effect, the then Attorney-General said that unless we gave to de factos the same entitlements that spouses have we could be operating against the sex discrimination legislation. He said:

There is a further point that it has been recognised by this Parliament . . . by the passage of the Sex Discrimination Act that there should not be discrimination in the provision of public goods and services and so on on the grounds of marital status, which includes its negative, the absence of a formal marital status.

I wonder whether the former Attorney-General would adhere to that, given the most recent decision of the High Court of Australia in relation to ex-nuptial children. The High Court found that the marriage power could not be utilised for the purposes of dealing with ex-nuptial children. I will, of course, be dealing with the question of the Sex Discrimination Act at a later stage this session. I indicate that in the third committee debate in the United Nations when the convention was being considered there was no intention at that stage to equate a de facto relationship with a marriage relationship, and therefore the Commonwealth cannot invoke the external affairs power under the Constitution for so doing in domestic legislation so far as it relates to the States. In any event, there is no definition of `goods' in the sex discrimination legislation, but there is a definition of `services', and it includes services relating to entertainment, recreation or refreshment. I do not know whether that is what the former Attorney-General had in mind.

Leaving all that aside, when the Remuneration Tribunal first decided that members of parliament could take de facto spouses overseas there was an outcry, as all honourable senators will recall. There was a significant outcry from ordinary electors who saw this as flying in the face of what society ought to do, in that if it is good enough for the leaders of our society to do this it is good enough for everyone else. I believe that although the hubbub has died down the principle remains. We have an opportunity now to excise from the Tribunal's determination the provision which gives de factos recognition on the same basis as spouses. We ought to do that by simply passing my amendment. The Opposition's proposed amendment, as it has been described by Senator Archer, would be a smoke screen to enable the Government-the Minister-to approve of de factos going overseas.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or reject.

—As Senator Archer said: `Or reject'. The fact is that this Minister approves. If we give that power under this legislation, he will approve. He is already doing it so far as Ministers are concerned. That approval is regularly given. To say that it will be placed on the same basis as domestic travel is a nonsense because this cannot be equated with domestic travel. Domestic travel is outlined by the Tribunal as being for particular purposes. On page 75 of the Tribunal's 1986 review it is stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Spouse or Nominee of a Senator or Member
For the purpose of this entitlement `nominee' means:
a parent;
a son or daughter other than a dependent child as defined in paragraph 1.19; or
a brother or sister

of the senator or member, and may in special circumstances include one other person (except a member of the staff of the senator or member) approved at the discretion of the Special Minister of State.

I am not sure what the Opposition's amendment would do, but the Opposition says, as Senator Archer has said, that the amendment would place overseas travel on the same basis as internal travel. It cannot do that because internal travel is paid for out of funds of the Commonwealth; it is not paid for out of the entitlement that is given to members of parliament. In any event are we going to--

TALK.START.PARA: —It's a very fine distinction, Senator.
—So does the Opposition wish to allow a parent or a son or a daughter other than a dependent child or a brother or sister to accompany a member of parliament overseas? Is that what is proposed?
—If they are the nominee. You can't change your nominee once a week.
—That is very interesting. I do not know whether the Senate would have the power to do that in any event because it may indeed be adding to the burden of the Commonwealth purse.
—No, it is still the same allowance. There is a set allowance.
—It's not adding to anything.
—The provisions on internal travel are for a certain number of trips per year.
—We're not changing that.
—I understand what the honourable senators are saying. What they are saying so far as overseas travel is concerned--
—We're not changing that either.

—What honourable senators are saying about overseas travel is that there was previously no entitlement to take a brother or a sister or a parent but that there was an entitlement for a de facto. Most of us have brothers and sisters, or parents, but most of us do not have de factos. I cannot quite follow that it may not add--
—You can't follow--
—I cannot follow that it may not add significantly to the cost of travel overseas.
—It can't add to the cost.
—How can it add to the cost?

—I will deal with that in the Committee stage. Opposition senators are trying to ensure that de factos will be covered. They know that, under the provisions on page 75 of the report, the Minister already approves the internal travel of de factos to Canberra. That was not the case under the previous Minister for Administrative Services, Mr Newman. The provision which enables the Minister in special circumstances to include one other person for travel was specifically designed for two particular purposes. It was specifically designed for use in the case of formal functions to which a senator and his or her partner were invited and to enable the housekeeper or some person who was not a relative of a widowed senator but who was looking after his or her children to come to Canberra.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a far cry from the case of overseas travel. The principle is very clear and needs to be dealt with by the Parliament efficiently and effectively. If the Opposition's amendment to my amendment goes through, then as surely as night follows day all that will be done is that a smoke screen will be put over the whole matter which will ensure that the principle is not dealt with. I ask Opposition members to consider this matter very carefully before they vote on it, because that will be the outcome.

Mr Deputy President, you will recall that once the Remuneration Tribunal's determination of 1974 came out there was an outcry. You will recall that I attempted to rectify the situation. Not only I, but also a number of other members of this chamber, were concerned about the provision which granted equality of status to de factos compared with married spouses. You will also recall, Mr Deputy President, that the Parliament had difficulties in addressing this question because under the present legislation we cannot reject or accept a Tribunal recommendation in part, other than by substantive regulation. We cannot, for example, disallow just one provision of a determination by a disallowance motion. We have to either accept or reject the lot.

This Bill now provides us with the opportunity to address this question which is of great significance to this society. I believe that the whole of society, the people of Australia, is very concerned about the fact that this Government and this Parliament are not upholding the institution of marriage as they should. If we do not do so, the fundamental institution of society-marriage-will come under greater and greater pressure. I believe that we have the opportunity today to make our decision concisely and without the confusion that the Opposition's amendment will produce. My concern is that if the Opposition pursues what it seeks to pursue it will simply transfer the equality of status for de factos from the Tribunal's decision to the hands of the Minister, whose record is to provide that equality of status.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whenever I examine Remuneration Tribunal reports I do so with a certain amount of cynicism.

—I think this cynicism would apply on both sides of the Parliament. In 1973 we established the Remuneration Tribunal to take away from Parliament the odium with respect to making decisions about salary increases for members of the Senate and the House of Representatives. SPEECH.PARA: I heard Senator Macklin make a few constructive comments about the salaries of members of parliament in particular. I agree with him. I have felt for years that our salaries ought to be linked to an appropriate level of the Australian Public Service so that when salary increases occur in the community our salaries are increased without the embarrassment of our being isolated from the rest of the community. Our wives should not be regarded - -

TALK.START.PARA: —Hang on!

—And husbands. I forgot the new Leader of the Australian Democrats, who is trying desperately to attract my attention to her husband's welfare. I include Senator Haines's husband. It seems to me that the spouses of members of parliament should not be regarded as second class citizens with respect to travel to Canberra, for example. If we examine the record we will find that in any case only about 43 per cent of the current entitlement is taken advantage of by our wives. SPEECH.PARA: Last year, honourable senators will recall, the Tribunal, having regard to salaries paid to other sections of the community, said that we were entitled to an increase in salary of something in excess of $4,000. But no, we could not do that because it was not the right time. We are now placed at a disadvantage. Now I suppose the rest of the community will say: `That is great; the members of parliament are getting what the community thinks they are worth'. I think that is a stupid attitude, in any case. I suppose the community will be highly delighted now because, as a result of the fringe benefits tax, our electorate allowance is to be taxed and we are to suffer a decrease in salary in excess of 20 per cent, or $150 to $200 a week. I suppose the community will think that to inhibit the capacity of parliamentarians to do the job of representing it in an effective manner is a great joke, a great laugh. I am really getting a bit hot under the collar about the Tribunal, the disregard that we have had for it and the cost that it imposes upon taxpayers. We ought to reconsider the whole question of the Tribunal in the interests of the economy and perhaps in the interests of a better go for members of this Parliament.

I have no great problem because my overdraft is probably a little less than that of most people in this place. I have no dependent children. However, I feel very sorry for the younger members of parliament who have children at school, who are paying off houses at extremely high interest rates, who are paying off motor vehicles or are leasing them, who are in some cases paying school fees, and who have costs associated with keeping children and wives properly dressed. A lot of members of parliament will have to reconsider whether they are prepared to go on in this way in future. I make that point quite clear. At the moment we are being treated disgracefully.

Senator Macklin drew attention to the United States of America. The system there seems to be quite good. Members of parliament receive something like $10 more than the highest paid public servant. I do not think that would be entirely satisfactory or acceptable in Australia and I would not suggest it. However, I reinforce what Senator Macklin said-that is, we ought to be linked with an appropriate level of the Public Service having regard to our work load and our responsibilities in the community. I hope that the Government will revise its attitude to the Remuneration Tribunal in future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — Although those listening to Senator Harradine may be forgiven for thinking otherwise, the basic point of the Remuneration and Allowances Alteration Bill 1986 is not to mount an assault on the institution of marriage; rather, it is an assault on the pockets of members of parliament. As such it represents one of those rare occasions in parliamentary life when we are all in furious agreement. For a start we know that we are conspicuously underpaid by any standard of comparative salary justice, with the erosion of salaries from a rough equivalence of Level 1 or Level 2 of the Public Service some years ago down to around Class 10 of the Third Division at the moment and falling. However we know, secondly, that no one believes that we are underpaid. Thirdly, we know that the Remuneration Tribunal did the right and rational thing in recommending in its determination an 11.7 per cent catch-up. We further know that we have no alternative whatsoever in the present economic and political environment but to knock back, as we are now doing, that determination. Finally, we know that having made that decision we will get no credit whatsoever from anyone for having made the sacrifice. So clearly we have no alternative but simply to join hands around the chamber and sing in unison the familiar refrains of the masochism tango.

SPEECH.PARA: Only one aspect of the Opposition and Australian Democrats contribution to this debate causes me some concern and that is the back sliding that it represents from a previously often espoused high principle. I talk, of course, of the well-known opposition of both the Opposition and the Democrats to any retrospective legislation which inflicts pain. This manifestly is an example of such a piece of retrospective pain-inflicting legislation in that it not only denies us a pay increase in the future but also requires us to pay back some $600 of money already received. I simply make the point that should there be any disposition to honour that high principle on the part of the Opposition and the Australian Democrats the Government would, on this occasion, bear that result with such fortitude as it could command.

As to the amendments that have been moved, we have been treated once again to the familiar concern of Senator Harradine that de facto partners should not be acknowledged as having any- thing like the same rights, status and perhaps humanity as those who have chosen to formalise their relationships. There is a lot to be said about all that but I will leave it to the Committee stage and, in particular, to the contribution of the Minister for the defence of domestic sin, Senator Grimes, to perhaps re-state the familiar arguments against the really very extreme position that Senator Harradine here advances.

I am not in a position to indicate the Government's willingness to accept the Opposition's amendment on this question. All I will simply say is that from my perspective, and I think from that of those who have been listening to this debate, it offers some obvious advantages over not only Senator Harradine's amendment, which it is designed to replace, but also perhaps the present system which focuses clearly, so far as overseas travel is concerned, on one particular category of nominee-the de facto partner. Maybe there is something to be said for extending that range of categories by adopting the same list as that used for the domestic environment, thus making it possible for members of parliament to use their fixed travel entitlement not only for a de facto nominee but also for parents, children and so on.

However, from a Government perspective I have to make the point that although clearly there is no right on the face of it to any greater access to government funds than is available at the moment-it is simply a question of substituting one class of nominee for a broader range-nonetheless, in practice, there may be some additional burden on the Treasury to the extent that people who would not now take their full entitlement to the travel grant would, by virtue of this extension of the categories of people for whom it is able to be used--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is no different from the interstate position though, is it?

—That is true but to the extent that it may mean in practice there is more using up of the entitlement than is the case at the moment there may be adverse implications for the Treasury and as such I would have to express some reluctance on the part of the Government to accept it. However, should this amendment be forced upon us I again indicate that I guess we would bear it with fortitude.

SPEECH.PARA: The other amendment moved by the Opposition would remove the provision in this Bill enabling ministerial salaries to be adjusted in future by regulation rather than by legislation. If people feel passionately that this should be the subject of specific legislation each year rather than regulation, that will not cause any particular difficulty for the Government. It will simply mean that we have yet further burdens on already scarce legislative time. To the extent that people have been concerned or are likely to be concerned in the future about what is in the regulations adjusting ministerial salaries, of course the disallowance provisions are available so no parliamentary rights are being lost as a result of the proposed clauses in this Bill. I indicate again, perhaps to shorten debate at the Committee stage, that should this amendment win majority support the Government will not regard that as a great tragedy, although as the legislation stands it is a desirable streamlining measure. I thank honourable senators for their support for this Bill and wish it a speedy passage through its remaining stages.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

Proposed new clause 4a.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 4, after clause 4, add the following clause:
`Entitlements of members of the Parliament
`4a. (1) Determination No. 11 of 1986 of the Remuneration Tribunal dated 6 June 1986 is modified-
(a) by omitting paragraph 7.1;
(b) by omitting from sub-sub-paragraph 7.2 (d) (ii) `, or nominee as defined,';
(c) by omitting from sub-sub-paragraph 7.2 (d) (iii) `, spouse, or nominee as defined,' and substituting `or spouse';
(d) by omitting from sub-paragraph 7.3 (c) `or nominee'; and
(e) by omitting from paragraph 7.4 `or nominee'.
`(2) The determination of the Remuneration Tribunal referred to in this section as modified by this section has effect as if it were a determination of the Remuneration Tribunal.'.
The amendment proposes to omit paragraph 7.1 of the Remuneration Tribunal's Determination No. 11 of 1986. Paragraph 7.1 reads:
For the purposes of this entitlement, `nominee' means a person with whom the senator or member has established a bona fide stable domestic relationship.
Other consequential amendments are listed and I do not intend to canvass them at this stage. They were canvassed during the second reading debate and during previous debates in this Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have foreshadowed an amendment that has already been circulated which would provide that the same conditions apply as under paragraph 1.8 of the determination for the travel of a spouse or nominee of a senator or member within Australia. I should like to touch on one or two points. I do not see that it is desirable to have two different provisions for what is fundamentally a very similar situation. I believe there are times when the provisions for domestic travel arrangements could be appropriate for overseas travel, and I believe that such a situation has happened recently. I certainly do not believe that there should be an open slather, first come, first served arrangement in regard to who becomes one's travelling partner. I draw attention in particular to paragraph 1.9 which states:

SPEECH.PARA: A senator or member may nominate to the Special Minister of State one nominee. . .

This, of course, precludes the inference that one can draw lots and take anybody anywhere one likes, any time one likes. That is not the case. Also, I draw attention to the fact that approval is at the discretion of the Minister and I would expect the Minister, whoever that may be, to accept that discretion and to administer it accordingly. I believe it is desirable for the sake of consistency for people to know that exactly the same arrangements apply. Again for the sake of consistency, I believe that if we are to make a legislative change, it would be better if it came about by way of an all purpose Bill that would pick up the question of spouses as against de facto spouses in all the legislation in which this question occurs. I therefore move as an amendment to Senator Harradine's proposed new clause 4a:
Leave out paragraphs (a) to (e) (inclusive) of proposed new sub-clause 4a (1), insert the following:
``by omitting paragraph 7.1 and substituting the following paragraph:
`7.1 For the purposes of this entitlement, `nominee' means:
a parent;
a son or daughter other than a dependent child as defined in paragraph 1.19; or
a brother or sister

of the senator or member, and may in special circumstances include one other person (except a member of the staff of the senator or member) approved at the discretion of the Special Minister of State .'.''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise, not as the holder of the title given to me by my learned colleague the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) but as someone who has something to say in this area that needs to be said, without necessarily defending sin, domestic or otherwise. I have some sympathy for Senator Harradine. It looks as though he has moved an amendment to achieve an end and, as a result of further amendments, the whole thing has gone the opposite way. We look like having a situation whereby the provisions for people to be able to take a spouse or nominee when travelling overseas will be the same as those that now apply in regard to domestic travel. I will not oppose this. As Senator Macklin has pointed out, this does not increase the entitlement or, necessarily, the cost to the taxpayer. Perhaps we should have given the matter more thought. We would have done so if we had known that this sort of amendment was to be moved today.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to make some remarks about Senator Harradine's statements. I point out that the Remuneration Tribunal and the Government, in considering this matter, have always referred to bona fide, stable domestic relationships. I happen to think, as does Senator Harradine, that stable domestic relationships-within marriage or outside marriage-are important to the stability of our society. I do not think that his emphasis on the married state being the ultimate criterion for the stability of our society is necessarily right. It is certainly something which is believed, and will be believed for a long time in our society, because most people in our society will remain in the married state, as has been the case in the past. But in other, what I would call civilised, societies, particularly the Scandinavian societies and some of the western European societies, no great distinction is made between the married state and what we choose to call the de facto state. In fact, in the Scandinavian countries different words are used to describe the different states. They are publicly acknowledged and no one thinks twice about it. I do not think that their societies are any less stable or civilised than ours.

I repeat what I have said during debates on previous occasions: People live in relationships which are not formalised by marriage for all sorts of reasons. On many occasions those reasons are good reasons. Sometimes, in fact not infrequently, even under our reformed system, the reason that people do so is for the benefit of a third person who may have been married previously to one of the partners. Under our existing legal setup, people sometimes do not obtain a divorce-at least for a time, but sometimes not at all-for the protection of that third person. They do that for reasons which for them are important reasons and moral reasons and just reasons. I do not believe it is for members of this Parliament to pass judgment on them. I do not think it is for this Parliament to penalise them. I do not think they should be given any great advantages-they are not advantaged under the Social Security Act-but I do not think they should be penalised. It is for that reason that I think much of the hoo-ha about this subject is unfortunate.

Senator Harradine is an exception. When he debates this matter, he does so as a matter of principle. He puts forward his arguments without making a personal attack. As he said, when this matter was announced there was a hue and cry in the community. That hue and cry, unfortunately, was not of the standard he has maintained in this place. Some of the hue and cry by members of parliament-not only by members of the Opposition-concerned political point-scoring. There were headlines about taxpayers paying for members to take their floosies around the world. That nonsense went on and on as it always does under these circumstances.

I do not think we should let that hue and cry allow us to forget that there are people in this society who live in relationships which are not formalised by marriage. They live in stable, bona fide domestic relationships. As Senator Haines once said in a debate in this place, what is better for our society-a couple who have lived in a stable, bona fide, loving domestic relationship for five or 10 years, or a married couple with a husband who belts his wife twice a week, gives her inadequate support, and abuses her mentally and physically? Apparently we consider that to be a respectable way in which to live. I do not think we are in a position to make judgments just because people have not signed a bit of paper inside or outside a church. For that reason I reject Senator Harradine's moves in this area, although I respect the reasons why he is doing so.

The Government-which is at the moment represented by Senator Evans and me-will accept the Opposition's amendment. As this matter will have to be considered in the House of Representatives, we shall consult our colleagues to ensure that there will not be a great increase in expenditure for the taxpayer. I suspect that the Opposition's amendment at least will bring the consistency about which Senator Archer talks. Senator Macklin is right. We have salaries, allowances-electoral, ministerial and travel-domestic travel rights for wives, spouses, friends and nominees and overseas travel rights.

TALK.START.PARA: —In fact it is money.

—As Senator Archer says, it is all about money. We have a complicated set of allowances. The allowances have largely arisen because members on both sides of parliament are always reluctant, for political reasons, to face up to the fact that, if we are to have a proper democracy in this country, members of parliament must be paid adequately, or they will be paid from outside parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: In the old days, in the State of Montana in the United States of America, members of the legislature were paid by the biggest mining company in that State. Some years ago, Senator Coates and I had an acquaintance who was one of the few socialist members of parliament in the United States. He was a member of the Montana State legislature and was paid by the Anaconda Mining Co. He did not last very long in that parliament. That is an extreme example but it shows the sort of situation we shall end up with if the remuneration of members of parliament continues to drop as it has already done. There are members of the House of Representatives in particular who are in some difficult seats and have not had an easy time in becoming and remaining members of parliament. If we are not to go through the farce that occurs in West Germany-where the salaries are minute and the allowances huge, at about three times salary levels-we should at some time bite the bullet, get together and work out a reasonable level.

TALK.START.PARA: —But not just now.

—Yes, I know. I would do it now, probably. We should work out a reasonable level, but it is no good even saying, as the Remuneration Tribunal has done, that we need an 11 per cent increase in salaries. We need to get all the salaries and allowances together, judge what is a reasonable total and stop all the nonsense, book work and crazy business that goes on. We must build that into a reasonable remuneration and somehow get it away from politics. I remind the Senate that we set up the Remuneration Tribunal to get remuneration away from politics. To my horror, when I became a senator, I found that we earned $14,000. We increased that to $20,000. Two honourable senators opposed that, one of whom is still a senator. I heard him grizzling this morning about the Bill. But in those days he was an independent; now he is a member of a party and has the protection about which Senator Macklin talks and he wants justice now.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government will accept the Opposition's amendment to Senator Harradine's motion. We shall not cry about losing our capacity to increase our ministerial salaries by regulation. However, we as a Government will have to consider this matter because the financial implications are perhaps not as clear cut as Senator Archer believes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will support the Opposition's amendment to Senator Harradine's motion. I should like to make it clear, because it was not clear from Senator Harradine's comments, that the overseas allowance is structured so that each member of parliament receives one air fare in each three-year period. That air fare remains constant. It may be divided between a member, or senator, and his nominee. It is not, as the general public and media understand it, an additional fare. That must be made very clear. We are talking about not an additional fare but one fare and whether it will be paid as a first class air fare or two tourist class air fares. That important point seems to have been missed in all our debates

SPEECH.PARA: The Remuneration Tribunal's review excludes from travel entitlements a member of the staff of the senator or member. It is fairly obvious why that exclusion exists. We must remember that overseas travel is not for the delectation and amusement of members of parliament but for the benefit of the Commonwealth. There could be real argument to exclude spouses entirely and to allow only staff, on the grounds that what one does overseas is work and that that work would be enhanced by the attendance of a member of staff. I give a personal example. A couple of years ago a member of my staff paid his own way to accompany me to the United States. His work was invaluable because it doubled or trebled the time I could use and the contacts I was able to make. He increased magnificently the amount of work I was able to get through. I have never taken my spouse overseas. I suppose that I am lucky in that I am married to a qualified researcher because my wife would be capable of fulfilling that type of task.

I wonder whether we are looking at this aspect from the right end. I hope that if the Government takes up the suggestions that other honourable senators and I have made and to which Senator Grimes responded, it will look in a rational way at the intention behind overseas trips. If the intention is work, one must look at it as work. Senator Evans made the outlandish suggestion that members of the Opposition might be backsliding with regard to retrospective taxation. I refer him to Hansard and the debate on this matter under the Fraser Government. One specific exclusion in terms of retrospective taxation applied to people who had agreed to have that exclusion applied to them. As it appears that there will be a unanimous vote in this exercise, I hope that the point will be well taken that we are inflicting this pain on ourselves. The retrospective tax principle concerned members of parliament inflicting that tax on others. In this case, as Senator Evans said, we shall all be masochists and inflict this pain on ourselves.

TALK.START.PARA: —Also, the cut was declared at the time.

—Yes, that is perfectly correct. I should like to comment on Senator Harradine's propositions and reiterate a point made by Senator Grimes. I feel strongly about this. In the past couple of weeks, we saw an example-I emphasise that it is only an example-of massive child abuse. I am not sure why that case was highlighted but I and, I am sure, other honourable senators have had brought to attention cases that are almost as horrific. The example to which I referred took place inside marriage. We are looking-I talk particularly from the point of view of the children-for people who will care and nurture children and enable them to grow up as good citizens in our society. I would not want to be associated with anything that detracted in any way from the type of caring work done by people who may not have a marriage certificate. I think very much in those circumstances of the children. I would not feel that I could go ahead in voting without making it clear that that is my personal and passionately held view.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Harradine's point about overseas travel had some legitimacy. However, that point might be better addressed by referring to my first argument that we should work out what we are doing in terms of overseas travel for the Commonwealth. That might be a better avenue of deliberation in terms of expenditure than the one on which we have been engaged until now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —In respect of the matter just raised by Senator Macklin and the issue raised by Senator Grimes, it seems to me that what they indicated about my amendment is precisely what they would have us do; in other words, my amendment really proposes to omit from the Remuneration Tribunal 1986 Review paragraph 7.1, which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: For the purposes of this entitlement, `nominee' means a person with whom the senator or member has established a bone fide stable domestic relationship.

I do not want to be in that judgmental frame of mind where I have to say what is bona fide and what is not. If one does not have these matters dealt with on the basis of what the law is so far as marriage is concerned, of course one gets into judgmental situations. The very burden of Senator Macklin's contribution and Senator Grimes's contribution was that we should not get into judgmental situations. The only way to avoid that, of course, is to set the standard on the basis of the law, and that is precisely what I am doing. I believe that we set a whip for ourselves if we do it in any other way. Besides demeaning publicly the institution of marriage and besides undermining the fundamental principle of the laws which we as a Parliament have established, we will fall into the trap of being required to be judgmental in order to determine who accompanies a senator overseas and who does not.

I think that the Opposition's amendment-of course, the Government knows this-will do what is already being done; that is, approval will be given for a senator or member to be accompanied by a de facto when travelling overseas. I take the point that was made by Senator Gareth Evans, that this could well increase the amount of money that is spent. In fact, he supported what I found difficulty in expressing in the second reading debate-that the effect of the Opposition's amendment would be not only to maintain what the current situation is, namely, that de factos can go overseas, but also to extend that to parents, brothers, sisters and what have you. I admit that we have only a certain entitlement, which can be taken either by the senator or member or shared by the senator or member with the others nominated in the Remuneration Tribunal's determination. However, there are a number of senators and members who are probably too busy on committee work or other work in the Parliament to take up their entitlements but who, should the Opposition's amendment go through, when going overseas would have the choice of taking relatives as described under the amendment. If that is the proposition, that is fair enough. If that is the way the Parliament wants it, that is fair enough. But it comes back to the other provision whereby the Minister, in special circumstances, could include one other person, and that person is approved at the discretion of the Minister. The Minister already approves de factos so far as Ministers are concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not de factos; it is `a companion'.

—We have got companions now, have we? That is an interesting point mentioned by Senator Archer, because it has always intrigued me. The Tribunal's determination does not mention female companions either. It just says:

SPEECH.PARA: For the purposes of this entitlement, `nominee' means a person with whom the senator or member has established a bona fide stable domestic relationship.
I assume that to mean de factos. I do not assume that to be anything else.

TALK.START.PARA: —You read it again.

—Does Senator Archer think that means homosexual partners? I do not. I give them the benefit of the doubt. I think it probably does mean de factos. The Opposition's amendment maintains the status quo and extends it. I will be opposing that amendment as I believe it ought to be opposed.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.
Proposed new clause, as amended, agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to have Part IV deleted, as per the amendment circulated.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 6, Part IV, (clauses 13 to 15) lines 1 to 13, leave out the Part.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that the Government will oppose this amendment because we regard it as desirable, in the interests of preserving parliamentary time, that things that can be done by regulations and still preserve Parliament's right to scrutinise the matter should be done that way. I have indicated previously that we will not pursue that opposition to the point of division if the Australian Democrats indicate they are in support of it, because it will not change the status quo. It simply seems to us to represent some unnecessary obsession on the part of the other side with the difference between legislation and delegated legislation and one that really does need argument in support of it rather than mere assertion.
—It is an important distinction.

—It is a distinction without practical significance if Parliament retains the opportunity to disallow and in circumstances like this, where there is no question of policy building and so on involved but simply annual changes to tables of rates. I agree that there is an important distinction between legislation and delegated legislation if we are talking about legislative policy making at large, but on something essentially mechanical like this, where there is a fail-safe mechanism available to the Parliament, it seems to the Government to be an unnecessary bit of enthusiasm on the part of the Opposition. Depending on what the Democrats do, I guess we will just have to live with it.

—I did mention during the second reading debate that, to prevent another payment being made before the recoveries start, it is necessary that the Bill go through as quickly as possible. It was introduced yesterday afternoon and debated in the other place before we had even seen a copy of it. It was brought in here this morning to be introduced and dealt with so that it could go out straight away. It has not passed either the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances or the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. If they followed their normal practice they would at least raise this question of delegated authority passing substantial sums of money on a regular basis. I do not think it is at all unreasonable that we should draw attention to it at this stage. In fact, we would prob- ably be negligent if we did not. On behalf of the Opposition I object to having an amount of this type of regularity being dealt with by regulation.
—I indicate that the Australian Democrats will be supporting the Opposition's amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is an important principle to stand upon. I agree with what has been said by Senator Archer and Senator Macklin.

SPEECH.PARA: Part IV negatived.
Clause 16 agreed to.
Clause 17 (Recovery of overpayments).

TALK.START.PARA: —This clause deals with the recovery of overpayments. I believe that the insertion of this clause into Federal legislation is a precedent which we should not accept. It is being applied to us at this time and it could be applied to others at a later date. I do not think that any trade unionist worth his salt either would or should agree to this provision. The provision is entitled `Recovery of overpayments'. The fact is that we have not been overpaid. A decision has been made by the Remuneration Tribunal and that decision is law until it is reversed by a decision of the Parliament either as in the normal case, by a disallowance motion, or by substantive legislation.
—You agreed to clause 2. The commencement date is 1 July.

—Sorry, I missed it. Perhaps I am too late. Perhaps I can go back to clause 2 later. The question of retrospectivity comes into this. Does this clause mean that we will be required to pay back what payments have been legitimately made under the Tribunal? What will happen to the tax that we have paid on that sum? I imagine that in some way that will be paid back to us and not kept by the Australian Taxation Office. I am concerned that if this goes through the Parliament it may be misunderstood that we accept the principle of retrospectivity. Both Senator Macklin and Senator Archer have indicated their support. They stand against retrospectivity but they are able to support this legislation on the basis that an announcement was made at the time. There seems to be no real argument against that. This legislation deals with the question of the payment of salaries and wages. Having been a trade unionist for a long time, I am concerned about allowing this provision. I do not mind giving the money back voluntarily.
—That is going a bit too far.
—Does the honourable senator think that that is going a bit too far? I would rather give it back voluntarily than have in legislation a provision for recovery under such circumstances.

—I wish to confirm what Senator Harradine has said. I cannot see where the retrospectivity applies when the announcement was made at the time of the declaration and before we had in fact received the first payment. I accept that we are now undertaking the legislative measures to make it possible to confirm what the Government advised at the time the decision was made. I cannot agree that this represents any retrospectivity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I simply say on behalf of the Government that I am indebted to Senator Archer for his deft bit of footwork in demonstrating why it is that this is not really a retrospective piece of pain inflicting legislation. That is the Government's view of it and, unhappy as the result may be for all of us, the Government does insist on the retention of this clause.
