SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said when I spoke briefly before this debate was adjourned on 13 June, I wholeheartedly support the Affirmative Action (Equal Opportunity for Women) Bill 1986. It was very annoying that it was not able to be dealt with and finalised in June; but, as promised then, it is being given priority now. The Bill seeks to ensure that discrimination against women in employment is eliminated and, to put it in a more positive way, that there is equal opportunity for women in the work place. The Bill proposes to do this in a very gentle and very gradual way.

SPEECH.PARA: Despite the moans of some in the Opposition, it is a very gentle piece of legislation. It will apply for the time being only to higher education institutions and to employers with more than 1,000 employees. Even then the implementation is to be gradual. Next year the Bill will apply only to employers with more than 1,000 employees, and not until 1988 for those with more than 500, and not until 1989 for those with more than 100. It asks each relevant employer to institute an affirmative action program. It does not prescribe quotas or anything like that. There are no draconian penalties, the sanction for non-co-operation being merely naming in a report to the Minister. Even though the Opposition's amendment calls for the program to be based on voluntary co-operation rather than legislation, it is virtually voluntary anyway. I have some sympathy for organisations such as the Women's Electoral Lobby and the Australian Council of Trade Unions that have called for a tougher Bill, but our position is to give it a try in this more gentle, non-punitive way. If such encouragement does not work, if the response from business and industry is not good enough over the years, we will have to consider a different tack. But we are giving it a chance this way to see whether the good response experienced in the pilot program can be extended amongst employers generally for their benefit as well as for the benefit of Australian women.

The full value of capable women is not being realised because they are generally overlooked and underrated by employers. Affirmative action programs are necessary in principle but they have economic and social merit too and will lead to an improvement in the Australian work force generally as more and more employers appreciate the benefit to them and as workers, male and female, obtain a better recognition of their worth. Attitudes on all sides must change. The emphasis in this legislation is on consultation, setting objectives, and monitoring and evaluation.

I want to look at the need for affirmative action in the light of the increasingly disturbing phenomenon dubbed the feminisation of poverty, which should be a matter of grave concern to all Australians-as it is to this Government. The Affirmative Action Bill is an indication of how seriously this Government views the position of Australian women, a position generally of low status both economically and culturally. Quite often women in Australian society are isolated from the mainstream of Australian life; that is, they do not enjoy full access to wealth, education, housing, living standards and recreational activities. Many factors-cultural, social, ideological and geographical-contribute to this sort of isolation, but the real cause is economic problems.

The facts speak for themselves. Of all full time workers in all job categories women still earn on average only 78 per cent of the earnings of their male counterparts. Ninety-six per cent of all single parent families, the families most likely to be suffering poverty, are headed by women. In an address given at Adelaide University a couple of years ago by Bettina Cass of Sydney University, who is the Director of the Social Security Review, the disturbing situation faced by Australian women was succinctly put. She said:

Female sex itself connotes such a profound risk of relative deprivation that it is categorised as a disability without the addition of other harmful conditions like unemployment, sickness, age or invalidity.

In the 1980s the likelihood of women suffering unemployment, poverty, inadequate housing and so on is something like four times greater than it is for men. Women and their children are largely the victims of poverty. In the years up to 1983 job opportunities for women, particularly in full time employment, became severely restricted. At the same time, Australian society underwent many important changes. That period also witnessed the emergence of a greater preponderance of single parent families. The far greater percentage of women single parents in receipt of social security benefits indicates the difficulties women face in the Australian labour market. While men face the same difficulty with child care and home responsibilities, more men than women are able to work. Too often sections of this society blame single parents for being an enormous drain on the Federal budget but according to the figures single mothers are excluded from the work force with the result that they have no alternative but to rely on government assistance.

Women are facing huge changes in the labour market, and problems arise mainly for women who have suffered losses of jobs, retrenchments and reductions of hours because of the introduction of new technology. In December last year women made up only 30 per cent of all full time workers yet they represented 78 per cent of all part time workers. Since 1966 the number of female part time workers has jumped from 350,000 to 973,000, a rise of 178 per cent. There may be abundant part time work for women but part time work does little to improve the long term economic security of women and their children. Working women, whether part time or full time, are concentrated in three occupational groups-clerical, sales, and service, including sport and recreation. Jobs in these areas generally have low status, offer lower wages and afford few opportunities for advancement, promotion or on the job training and development.

An indication of the extent of the segregation of the Australian labour market and the accompanying low status, low wage syndrome lies in the fact that in professional occupations in which women predominate, for example nursing, wage levels are unacceptably low. For too long this country has been dividing work by sex and, as is so often the case, where there is division there is hierarchy. In the Australian labour market that hierarchy manifests itself in the following way: Men's work is considered important and valuable and is remunerated accordingly; women's work is not accorded the same value and so is poorly remunerated. This is one of the reasons why despite equal pay women still earn only two-thirds of the average male rate. This is the poverty trap in which far too many women are caught.

The affirmative action program is being introduced into this labour market. This Government has had the foresight and concern to do something to redress the employment problems that women face. We have made a firm decision that it is not enough to mouth platitudes about equal opportunity and the elimination of sex discrimination. Something decisive and constructive needs to be done. The affirmative action legislation sets up the structures and procedures by which results can be achieved. Australia is fortunate in that it can draw on the experience of other countries in this type of legislation and so avoid some of the problems and pitfalls that other nations have had to face in their attempts to redress the problems of disadvantaged and minority groups.

This experience has proved invaluable in relation to the setting of quotas, which this legislation avoids. In countries in which quotas were set requiring companies or businesses to employ a certain number of women in the ensuing 12 months, merit was often overlooked. This had a couple of unfortunate results. There was a backlash of resentment from those people who though properly qualified had been passed over, because of the exigencies of the quota, for someone without the same qualifications and or training. This does little to advance the cause of women who deserve recognition and respect in the labour force. Also, quotas are in many ways unfair on those people who when appointed lack qualifications and experience and so are unable to cope fully with the job, thus suffering a lack of job satisfaction and low morale. It cannot be stressed strongly enough that affirmative action in the Australian context does not involve quotas and is not positive discrimination but is firmly based on the principle of merit. Certain sections of the community which have not supported affirmative action have distorted the contents of this Bill in an attempt to delude the electorate for their own purposes. The Australian newspaper was guilty of this sort of misinformation in an editorial on 21 February this year. It used the following words:

Do we need federal legislation such as the Affirmative Action Bill . . . to coerce businesses and institutions such as universities into setting and meeting quotas to increase the number of women in their work forces and then establish programs to ensure these women are treated on equal footing with men?

As I said, there is a vast difference between employers setting targets and goals in accordance with the specificity of their circumstances and the Government coercing employers to fulfil quotas. Perhaps the editor of the Australian should actually read the legislation. In introducing this Bill the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said:

I want to stress that the Government's affirmative action legislation does not propose positive discrimination or reverse discrimination. We are totally opposed to the use of quotas, and this legislation, by stating that all actions are based on merit, makes this clear.

It seems that despite efforts by this Government to explain its proposed legislative measures through extensive consultation and by having many groups participate in the pilot program there are groups which wilfully misrepresent the contents of the Bill. The Bill does not involve riding over the merit principle to give preferential treatment in hiring, promotion or admission to an educational institution merely on the basis of membership of a disadvantaged group. Affirmative action in Australia is not designed to give preferential treatment to any group or individual but is designed to identify and remove practices and procedures which are discriminatory and which have caused the exclusion of women. It is designed to remove the barriers which at present allow men to be the preferred group. The Government believes that legislation is necessary to encourage employers to improve the prospects for their women employees.

In a Press release in February this year Mr Geoff Allen of the Business Council of Australia said that the Council `strongly opposes the view that legislation is either appropriate or necessary to achieve the objectives of equal opportunity for women'. He put forward an alternative idea: That equal opportunity for women could be achieved far more effectively by voluntary participation in the Council for Equal Employment Opportunity, which is sponsored by the Business Council of Australia. As an indication of the necessity for the legislation, it is worth noting that the Council for Equal Employment Opportunity was established only after the Government had launched the affirmative action program. If private industry is as committed to equal employment opportunity as Mr Allen would have us believe, it would have made moves in this direction years ago instead of needing the impetus of a government initiative.

The BCA and other groups which say legislation is not necessary do not realise that legislation has another dimension apart from specific requirements and regulations. That dimension is harder to measure but is of vital importance and can be called its educative role. It is this educative role which has the effect of changing attitudes which hinder the raising of the status of women. The fact is that affirmative action in itself is not sufficient to improve the economic position of women. It is a start, but it needs to be complemented by attitudinal changes. The right of women to work needs to be recognised. The value of the work women do has to be acknowledged. The ability of women to undertake successfully work which is traditionally seen as men's work needs to be recognised. Women's role as the primary caretakers of children needs to be changed so that fathers take equal responsibility for their children. Access to quality child care needs to be extended to allow women to participate in the full time work force. The Government is making great strides in this direction, but a lot still remains to be done. I doubt that voluntary participation in the Council of Equal Employment Opportunity will be able to effect these changes which are necessary to overcome the insecure economic position of women. Perhaps the BCA's Council can be complementary, but it is not a substitute.

The Affirmative Action (Equal Opportunity for Women) Bill is an important factor in the process of achieving the changes I have talked about and is a worthy piece of legislation for that reason. I congratulate the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women (Senator Ryan) on her initiative, on behalf of the Australian Labor Party when we were in opposition in 1981, in introducing the forerunner to this Bill. I congratulate her for battling for the Bill to the point where it is near fruition. I am hopeful of great success for the participant employers and for the women who thereby gain the recognition they deserve.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak briefly on the Affirmative Action (Equal Opportunity for Women) Bill 1986. I am respectful of the fact that there are some 22 speakers on the list all wanting an equal opportunity to speak on it, but there are a number of points I want to make. The goal of the Bill is equal employment opportunity for women, which is something I think we would all applaud, certainly on this side of the chamber. The question is: How much does this Bill contribute towards the goal of equal employment opportunity for women? I intend to argue in my brief contribution that, although the Bill might make some contribution, it is generally geared towards the welfare of women in employment, women who are better educated and women who are more likely to be upwardly mobile in employment, rather than the large number of disadvantaged women about whom Senator Coates spoke. I argue that the major problems facing women are really beyond the competence of this Bill to remedy. Nevertheless, I am prepared to accept that it can play a constructive and purposeful role for the limited number of women of whom I just spoke.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind the Senate that the Bill is so structured as to seek from relevant employers affirmative action programs designed to ensure that employers take appropriate action to eliminate discrimination against women in relation to employment matters, and to take measures to promote equal opportunity for women in relation to employment matters. Employment matters include recruitment procedures and selection criteria for the appointment or engagement of persons as employees, the promotion and transfer of employees, training and staff development for employees, and conditions of service of employees. As Senator Coates said, the Bill covers higher education institutions and employers who employ in excess of 100 employees. It does not include the Commonwealth, a State, a Territory, an authority or a voluntary body.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not yet.

—Not yet. It is limited in form. It is interesting, for example, that trade unions as voluntary associations would not be covered by the Bill. But that is not the principal argument I want to put. As I said, there is an argument that with regard to some women it can be of advantage. I refer to a survey taken at Sydney University in 1985 which showed that less than one-third of the university's academic staff were women. That indicates a problem in itself, but more dramatic is that in the top levels of the professional staff-the senior lecturers, professors, et cetera-only 10 per cent were women, whereas in the bottom academic staff levels, such as research assistants, 60 per cent were female. Obviously, there is room within the tertiary institutions for considerable upgrading and for a program which will allow a more equitable distribution of senior jobs for women.

SPEECH.PARA: I accept that there is a beneficial purpose in a program at Sydney University, for example, which could help remedy that imbalance, but, as I said, that represents only a small section of women. The women in most need of legislation, or constructive government help in other ways, are those who will not benefit from this Bill. Basically, this Bill provides a tool for women whom I might describe as being in the know, women who are already in the bureaucracy, femocrats with their networks, women in middle management, women in tertiary and financial institutions, women who already have access to the system, generally with education and reasonably available prospects of opportunity. They are the women I define as in the know and they are women who will benefit particularly from this Bill.

That leaves that massive group of women who are not in the know, women who will not benefit by this legislation, women employed in lowly paid jobs, in highly repetitive jobs, in labour intensive jobs. In particular I give the example of migrant women with little knowledge of English, with limited support services, and with very little opportunity to rise beyond the positions they already occupy because of the necessity to earn enough for themselves and their families. How will they benefit from this Bill? The answer is, of course, that they will not; it is not designed to apply to them in their situation. It is worth noting-it will not come as a surprise-when I mention migrant women that the percentage of unemployment amongst them is higher than for all women. It is 12.8 per cent as opposed to 10.8 per cent. Therefore, this group of women in most need will not benefit specifically from this form of legislation.

Furthermore, if we look at migrant women we see that their participation rate in the work force is higher than for non-migrant women. This is simply because migrant women generally come from lower socio-economic groups and have a greater need for work. What we on this side of the chamber are particularly interested in is giving the women who need work a fair opportunity to work. For example, Vietnamese women have a participation rate in the work force of some 57 per cent of their number compared to 46 per cent for all Australian women. Therefore, migrant women have a greater need which will, not be helped by this legislation. What do we need for such women? We need programs of language classes which are more accessible to migrant women. Special needs in regard to training and retraining have also to be taken into account.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is affirmative action.

—I agree that affirmative action will do that. However, the affirmative action contained within the structure of this Bill will not do that. This Bill, as it is structured, will not be of any help to those women whatsoever. These are women who are not in the know. This Bill is designed primarily for women in the know. Let us look at another group of severely disadvantaged women-the single parents. Whether we like it or not almost 15 per cent of all families with dependent children today are now single parent families. Of that 15 per cent, 93 per cent are headed by women. According to statistics available to all of us some 41 per cent are below the poverty line. Therefore, we have a major group of disadvantaged women to whom we should be addressing programs to assist them. Will this Bill assist them? The answer is no. Such women are disadvantaged and are not in a position to take advantage of the forms of affirmative action which this Bill encompasses and which it is designed to meet. What we need is a different form of program for such women. Child care is paramount in their considerations but child care does not come within the ambit of this Bill. I would like to remind the Senate that of course it was the Opposition that, during the last election, addressed that specific problem faced by single women seeking to enter the work force, that is, how they can get child care facilities at reasonable cost, at a cost which they can afford. Of course, we addressed this through a suggested program of taxation rebate. That is what I would suggest to this Government. Affirmative action should look at specific problems in regard to disadvantaged women.
—Supporting mothers do not enjoy--

—Senator Crowley will get her turn to speak. Such programs should address the problems of single parents and should take constructive steps forward for their benefit. The women who are, of course, most disadvantaged at the moment are women who are unemployed. Again it is worth reflecting on the fact that the unemployment rate for women is higher than that for men. As I understand, current unemployment levels stand officially at 6.8 per cent for women as opposed to 6 per cent for men. However, that figure does not of course take into account the women who are unemployed and who have not registered as unemployed. I think that one could assume on reasonable grounds that unemployment would be higher among women than among men. Therefore, again we find women in the community disadvantaged as opposed to men. We should be looking for a constructive affirmative action program to help these highly disadvantaged unemployed women. Primarily, we do not find such help within this Bill. This Bill will not give such women greater opportunity to get into employment.

SPEECH.PARA: On the other side the Opposition again looks to constructive, positive alternatives. As honourable senators know we have therefore been strong advocates of permanent part time work opportunity. This is something which the Labor Government and the trade union movement have been most tardy in embracing. It is only now and with great reluctance that we see some progress being made in this area-perhaps because of the agitation from the Opposition. Nevertheless, the small progress being made by some unions, such as the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association, is applauded by the Opposition. However, that union's newly negotiated agreement, which will deal with clerical and administrative assistants, will be limited to only 3 per cent of the total number of clerical and administrative staff within the Australian Public Service. That agreement has been made grudgingly. It represents only a small step in the right direction. We are advocating much greater opportunity in regard to permanent part time work. We are advocating that it be introduced within awards relating to work on the factory floor level or in the closed shop situation to aid women in lower paid work or women who seek to get into such lower paid jobs. However, the union movement simply is not prepared to give an inch on that matter. We would argue that if the Labor Government were to do something constructive it could develop an affirmative action program in that area. In that way it would be doing something worth while.

It is of worry to us that technological change, which must now continue at a more rapid rate if Australia is to recover economically, will place greater pressure on the employment of women because traditionally women have held jobs at the lower end of employment and in the more unskilled areas. Therefore, I see the problem being accentuated. It is a problem that needs to be addressed by a purposeful affirmative action program. However, it is not within the design or structure of this Bill.

Apart from the women who are particularly disadvantaged not being helped by this legislation-I refer to migrant women, the single parents, the unemployed and that mass of women employed at the bottom level of the unskilled employment market and who are the most dramatic cases that need the benefit of government action-we must then move to the next sector of women in employment. In Australia, perhaps as opposed to other parts of the Western world, we find that women who are in the work force tend to be concentrated in a small number of industries and within a narrow range of occupations within those industries. I remind honour- able senators that the vast majority of women have been, and continue to be, employed in clerical, sales, service and professional technical-related occupations. Women make up some 81 per cent of the labour force in those four occupational groupings.

If we look at industry we find that in 1982 almost two-thirds of female employees were concentrated in four main industries. In the community services area women represented 28 per cent of the work force. It will be no surprise to honourable senators to learn that in the wholesale and retail trade women represented 22 per cent of the work force. In manufacturing industry they represented 12.6 per cent and in the finance, insurance, real estate and business services area they represented 11.5 per cent. We therefore find women concentrated in a small number of industries and confined to a narrow range of occupations. Obviously if we are going to do something constructive that concentration has to be broken down. Women have to be given more opportunities in industries outside those traditional areas. Is that goal going to be helped by this Bill? To be quite fair I think that one can see only very little opportunity for affirmative action type programs, as encompassed by this Bill, helping to meet the needs of these women as exhibited by their restriction within traditional forms of employment. This would require a different type of affirmative action. It would require a different kind of program in order to develop changes of attitude. Changes within the education system would be needed to overcome educational shortcomings for girls in this country. We need programs to educate parents into looking at higher employment aspirations for their girls. This is a necessary and worthwhile goal. However, it is a goal that will not be solved by virtue of this legislation.

In those few words what I wanted to do was to give credit where it was due. I can see that in some small area this Bill will assist some women. But I stress the fact that with the major problem areas in this field, that is, the highly disadvantaged areas for women, this Bill will not help. Therefore, the Government has a responsibility that is not being adequately met. With respect to that large group of employed women who are, if I might use the term, in the centre, their problems of having a wider sphere from which to choose employment and a wider sphere from which to seek to become upwardly mobile are also not being met by this piece of legislation, and therefore in relation to those women the Government has a responsibility which is not currently being met.

Affirmative actions which recognise the failures of the past and which provide positive steps to redress such failures are to be supported and certainly will be supported on this side. To do so is compatible with the merit principle because women have to be given the opportunity to be put in a position where true merit can be tested. Unless they are given that opportunity by affirmative action programs to get there in the first instance, so many will miss out. That is why we are prepared to support the concept in principle. There is still a long way to go. I would be most unhappy if this Government feels that it can sit down with this Bill that is before use today and believe that it has achieved something that is going to be great and worth while because that is by far overvaluing what this very limited piece of legislation does achieve. Give it its small credit but recognise the extent of the problems that exist and positively approach and tackle those problems.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Hill's comments, I think, betray very clearly the Opposition's position on this piece of legislation. It wants to say that it likes it, but there is such division in its ranks that it has had to qualify that support. Senator Peter Baume spoke for the Opposition late in the last session. He made a most entertaining speech. I thank him for recording yet again the history of the achievements of women in South Australia. Perhaps that is because some of his colleagues in South Australia have done a lot of homework there. Even he, in giving his support for this legislation, still wanted to introduce a swag of amendments that the Opposition proposes. I would suggest that they may not be reflective of Senator Peter Baume's position, but they certainly are reflective of the divisions in the Opposition on this piece of legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the points that Senator Hill raised was that the Opposition, in coming to the last election, campaigned on great things that it would do for women through the tax system. He suggested that child care costs could be addressed by a tax rebate system. He suggested too, when I interjected, that I would get my time. Yes, I have it now, and I would like to point out that the tax system is of no advantage whatsoever to people who pay no tax. Most supporting mothers of the sort for which he was suggesting he was campaigning do not pay tax and would gain no possible benefit from a tax rebate scheme as opposed to the prospects of raising child care provision. Secondly, the tax rebate system creates not one extra place for child care. Both of those provisions were seriously considered by the Government in providing an alternative arrangement. I do not mind Senator Hill having that view, but for the record I think it is important that people know that it is a false view, that it is indefensible and silly.

TALK.START.PARA: —And what?

—Silly. It is wrong. It achieves not one of those things that the honourable senator claims it achieves. Secondly, I would suggest that his arguments against this piece of legislation are based on the same spurious logic. The honourable senator suggests that this Bill will not address all the problems confronting women in this society. Of course not. It specifically addresses what is under the terms of this piece of legislation; nobody could argue otherwise. It is like suggesting that moves for the union movement will not solve the problems for single mothers. Of course not. It is not addressing those problems. It is a ridiculous argument and I find it depressing that Senator Hill would sink to that level. Again, I think he represents in his qualified support for this legislation the problems confronting the Opposition. There is not a united voice in the Opposition ranks about this legislation, and I will come to that later.
—But there is an official voice.

—We hope that the official voice is the one which is heard and recorded and which supports the speedy passage of this legislation. I shall repeat what the Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Bill 1986 sets out to do-rather than the things that Senator Hill says it will not do. This Bill sets out to eliminate discrimination against women and to promote equal opportunity for women in universities, colleges of advanced education and private sector companies employing more than 100 employees. It is very clear about that. It is quite specific about that. I think it is important that that be understood. It is a piece of legislation that very much develops and goes hand in glove with the sex discrimination legislation that has already been passed by this Government. I think that piece of legislation, in its successful passage, indicated again exactly how divided the Opposition is on these issues concerning the status of women, the rights of women and the opportunities for women. Numbers of Opposition members would feel very much in sympathy with the legislation and the intentions of this Government-in fact they have said so-but others in the Opposition are divided on it. That same division is reflected very well in the affirmative action debate that is taking place here. Any reading of the Hansard record of the debate on this Bill in the House of Representatives would indicate that the same was happening there.

SPEECH.PARA: I come again to the differences in the Opposition. They were highlighted very nicely at the recent national Liberal Party conference that was held in Adelaide. At that conference there was the remarkable case of a motion which was put and which actually won major support, albeit 23 to 21-even so it was passed-restricting the sex discrimination legislation to apply to Commonwealth employees only. It enjoyed a fierce attack by many of the Liberal women at that conference, so much so that two days later, at the first national Liberal women's conference, a motion overturning the original one was moved and successfully passed. It certainly highlights the division in the ranks, not only amongst the men and women but also between men and men and between women and women in the Party. I think it is particularly interesting for those of us who know Senator Walters's view on these matters to understand that it was reported in the Advertiser on 8 August that when the motion was put by the national Liberal women:

Tasmanian Senator Shirley Walters, a conservative, big-L Liberal who spoke strongly in favour of the Tasmanian motion in the Federal Council, did not speak or raise her hand against the Sullivan-Worth motion at the women's conference. Neither did anyone else.

I presume they were resorting to the Thomas More situation of silence being assent under the law. But that silence and that assent at this conference were very much in opposition to what Senator Walters had to say at the previous national Liberal conference. She was supporting such attitudes as I might cite from the New South Wales delegate, Dr Michael Fitzpatrick, who supported that motion to restrict the sex discrimination legislation and who said that he was concerned that militant feminists were dictating to the community; they were a minority group and they were very vocal. He said that the Liberal philosophy should be based on the protection of the family and to protect the mother who stayed at home to look after the children. Feminists represented no one but themselves and had tried time and time again to advance policies detrimental to the welfare of the country.

I turn to the report of the national Liberal women's conference, and I find quite a remarkable difference of opinion and a different assessment. I am sure that the national Liberal women would be greatly entertained by the description of them which appeared in the article by Wallace Brown, which I quoted earlier, in the Advertiser of 8 August. Describing the membership there it stated:

From one of the Liberal Party's original members, Dame Beryl Beaurepaire of Melbourne, to a Ms Jan Hindmarsh, investment adviser, of Brisbane, this was a reasonably broad cross-section of concerned, intelligent, articulate and politically aware women.
Feminists in the main, yes. But in the true sense of the word, not so-called affirmative action buffs who want to push men aside.

Reported in that newspaper item is yet again the misrepresentation of what the affirmative action position is and of what this Bill is about. In finishing this part of my contribution, I can say that I was entertained by a further passage from the article. Ms Virginia Chadwick, a Liberal member of the New South Wales Legislative Council, had this to say:
As a party-
that is, as a Liberal Party-
we are not really comfortable with assertive, confident and ambitious women.

Indeed, it is not. I suggest that the Liberal Opposition needs to get itself sorted out regarding the division on the Affirmative Action Bill and even the Sex Discrimination (Consequential Amendments) Bill. I do not mind if Opposition members have their divisions as long as they do not use those divisions to misrepresent-I think very mischievously-the intentions of the affirmative action legislation, or even, in the more gentle-voiced way of Senator Hill, to argue furphies that are quite irrelevant and remote from the thrust and central arguments of this legislation.

This legislation is necessary to ensure that all large employers take seriously their obligations to women employees. The many things that Senator Hill listed as not being part of the affirmative action program may well be part of the affirmative action program. For example, migrant women workers in organisations employing more than 100 people will certainly be considered under the affirmative action program. That is precisely what employers will have to address. Under this legislation they will have to determine the distribution of people working in their firm or organisation. They will have to undertake a statistical analysis of the distribution of their workers and their level of employment and then come up with a program providing ways of addressing the needs of those workers. I would have thought that very high on the list for any serious employer would be the need to ensure that people who did not have English as a first language had that need addressed. I could see that requirement being quite clearly one of the factors decided on under an affirmative action program by a responsible employer.

A number of the other things which Senator Hill suggested would not be part of affirmative action and are not covered under this Bill. They are just wild distractions. If we looked through the pilot program reports we would have some clear idea of whether employers have a good understanding of what is required under this legislation. They have had the opportunity to test it. We would also have a fair understanding of what they have already decided would be good ideas. Many of the things Senator Hill proposed are certainly the sorts of things that could easily come, and in fact do come, under an affirmative action program if they are seen by the firm, the employer, the union and the employees involved to be appropriate and necessary to further the rights of women and the equality of opportunity for women in that organisation. Senator Hill's arguments were very false.

Another very important feature of this legislation goes to a point that has been mentioned in a number of important forums and certainly by Mr Kirk from Esso Australia Ltd. The report from the working group on affirmative action stressed again and again that neither individual employers nor the nation can afford to waste the valuable contributions which women can and do make to the economy. That point needs to be stressed. It is one of the underlying principles of the affirmative action legislation. In fact, Mr Kirk said that very splendidly when he was reporting on what happened in his firm, Esso. He said that there were a number of reasons why Esso decided on affirmative action voluntarily before the legislation was introduced and significant discussion was happening in the community. He said:
First, we were aware of the increasing availability and qualifications of women . . .
Secondly, he argued that they could see that it was going to happen as the Australian Labor Party, which was then in opposition, was talking along those lines. Thirdly, he argued:

. . . to run an efficient operation we should be utilising the best available human resources. To neglect 50 per cent of the available talent and skills just because of gender did not make good business sense.

From a hard, pragmatic position-not because of any bleeding heart notions of the needs of women but from hard, economic and pragmatic deliberations-Esso and its management agreed that it was ridiculous to waste all those talents.

It is important to stress that this legislation is not something that has been dumped on this Government, the Parliament or the Opposition. It has emerged out of a very thoughtful and reflective consultation process over two years. It has been reported in a series of papers, including a working paper. It has had the experience of a pilot program and the working party report. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Finance. I remind him of the severe criticisms he has delivered concerning the failure of a number of Budgets brought down by the previous Government to meet their targets, and I remind him also that the deficit predicted in the Government's Budget last year was out by some $800m. I ask the Minister: Does he stand by the accuracy of the figures in the Budget brought down by the Government last night? Will he resign if they prove to be as rubbery as the Opposition is predicting?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is correct that last year, for the first time-this Government having produced three Budgets-there was an overrun on estimated outlays and a Budget outcome deficit higher than the estimate. The reasons for that were detailed in the statement which I issued on the June Commonwealth financial transactions. I do not recall it all now and I do not have the statement with me but the principal reasons for both the outlays overrun and the increase in the deficit were related to the devaluation of the Australian dollar and the consequential increase in both public debt interest payments for those Commonwealth borrowings which were owed abroad, or interest liabilities which were payable abroad, and Commonwealth purchases of equipment, particularly defence equipment. I suppose it is regrettable that that happened but a devaluation of the size that has taken place was not foreseen at the time the Budget was introduced.

ANSWER.PARA: However, it is when a Treasurer year after year has a Budget outcome in which the outlays exceed the Budget estimates that one is really getting into the area of fraud. That is exactly what happened during the five years Mr Howard was Treasurer. In every one of those five years outlays exceeded the estimates presented with the Budget. Governments can make mistakes; Treasurers can make mistakes; they can fail to foresee circumstances that are developing, as we failed to foresee everything 12 months ago. But when for five years in succession a Treasurer has a Budget outcome in which the outlays are in excess of the estimate one has to start questioning the honesty and integrity of the Treasurer concerned. That is exactly the record Mr Howard has. Moreover, in three of those five years there was also a very substantial increase in the Budget deficit on the outcome as against the forecast which was made. So Mr Howard's score is five shonky figures out of five on the outlays side and three shonky figures out of five on the deficit side. That is the record of a man who was Treasurer and who now has the audacity, or effrontery, to present himself as an alternative Prime Minister and responsible economic manager.

As for the question relating to this year's Budget, of course no estimate can be anything but an estimate. It is unlikely that any particular figure will be precisely accurate and that the outcome will exactly coincide with the figure forecast, whether it relates to pension payments, the unemployment benefit or capital expenditure. Indeed the only payments about which one can be fairly certain are those usually fixed amounts which are written into legislation as transfer payments usually to other governments. One cannot guarantee the absolute accuracy of any individual figure in the Budget or of the figures in aggregate. In the absence of parameter changes which have not been foreseen, normally there is some shortfall on outlays. That is because departments tend to overestimate the speed with which new programs can be introduced. That is what has happened in three of the four years we have been in government and there is no particular reason to believe that it will not happen again. However, that could be more than offset by some parameter change. The Government believes that the figures presented in the Budget are the best estimates available. Whatever a previous Treasurer might have done, this Treasurer and this Government are not in the business of consistently producing shonky Budget figures year after year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister specifically mentioned the unemployment benefit. Is the Minister personally satisfied with the basis for estimating the outlays on unemployment benefit in the next year? Is he prepared-not during Question Time but at a later time-to make available to the Senate the basis of the calculations on unemployment benefit payments in the Budget?

—Senator Grimes has just reminded me that of all the rubbery figures in rubbery Liberal Treasurers' Budgets the unemployment benefit estimates were the most rubbery. The figure in the Budget Papers is the figure supplied by Treasury and in the first instance it is based on the state of the labour market. A deduction is made from that. —I refer the Minister for Veterans' Affairs to a report in today's Melbourne Sun that as a result of the Budget those getting a war widow's pension will no longer be eligible for a social security pension at the same time. Is this report accurate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the report in the Melbourne Sun, which makes statements that are not correct. As a result considerable distress will be caused to a group of persons who should not be placed in that position. It is not an accurate report and therefore it will cause unnecessary distress to war widows. I hope that the Melbourne Sun-and indeed other sections of the media-will appreciate the necessity to be accurate when it makes comments in respect of different aspects of the Budget. I also hope that the Sun in particular will promptly clarify the matter to minimise the distress this article caused.

ANSWER.PARA: War widows are entitled, in addition to the war widow's pension which is paid at the same rate as the single age pension, is tax free and is free of any income or assets test, to a domestic allowance of $12 per week. This measure was introduced by the Chifley Government in 1947. Around three out of four of the 60,000-odd war widows are also able to receive, subject to the income and assets test, a part social security pension. It is certainly not the case that these war widows will lose their entitlement to a part social security pension. However, the Government has decided that this social security pension entitlement will be frozen at the level being paid on 18 December 1986. In the case of a widow with no other income apart from the war widow's pension and domestic allowance, the maximum social security entitlement will be $60.05 a week and it will be frozen at that level. I am advised that the average social security entitlement of war widows is approximately $35 a week.

I also point out that the war widow's pension will continue to be adjusted every six months. So, as the consumer price index adjustments are made, the war widow will naturally receive the same increase in income as any other beneficiary who is eligible for an income support pension, in line with the CPI increase. The only difference is that those war widows to whom I have referred will cease to benefit from the double indexation of both their war widow's and social security pensions. If they were receiving $60.05, that amount will be frozen, but they will receive the normal CPI adjustment to the war widow's pension. As I was advised that this article might create some difficulties, my Secretary prepared a minute for me on the issue. I seek leave to incorporate that in Hansard so that the position is clarified for all those who want to know the precise position.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
DUAL ENTITLEMENT FOR WAR/DEFENCE WIDOWS PENSIONS AND SERVICE AND SOCIAL SECURITY PENSIONS
Minister
This minute is to inform you of the effect of the Government's decision to freeze from 1 November 1986 the amount of service or social security pension paid to war widows.
2. In the Treasurer's Budget speech he stated that:

``From November 1, 1986, where a newly eligible war or defence widow pensioner is also eligible for a social security pension, the maximum level of the social security pension will be frozen at $60.05 a week.''
3. However, the Government's decision also said that those war widows in receipt of service or social security pensions will have them frozen at the rate they were receiving on 1 November 1986.

4. That is, from 1 November 1986, those war widows would continue to receive their existing rate of service or social security pensions, but will not be eligible for any increases above that rate in future. They will not receive the CPI increases to be made to these pensions in December 1986.

5. Also, from 1 November 1986, all war widows whose service or social security pensions are subsequently reduced because of increased income, other than war widows pension, will not be able to be increased above that reduced rate in the event that their income ceases or the level reduces in future.
6. The following examples illustrate the above.
(a) War Widow receiving Age Pension prior to 1 November 1986
If the war widows only source of income is war widow's pension, age pension would be payable at $60.05 a week if unmarried, or $69.15 a week if married.
If the war widow has other income or assets these rates will be less under the income/assets test.
These rates will continue in payment after November 1986 subject to the income/assets test.
(b) War Widow receiving Service Pension prior to 1 November 1986
As war widow's pension is not taken into account in assessing the rate of service pension, the rate of service pension would be payable at $102.10 a week if unmarried, or $85.15 a week if married.
Lesser amounts would be paid if the widow has additional income.
These rates will continue in payment after 1 November 1986, subject to the income/assets test.
(c) War Widows pension granted after 1 November 1986 to a service or social security pensioner
The rate of service or age pension will be reduced to $60.05 a week if already being paid at a higher rate, otherwise pension will continue at the lesser rate in payment.
(d) Service or Social Security pension granted after 1 November 1986 to a War Widow
The Service or Social Security pension will be granted at the rate of $60.05 a week, or such lesser amount assessed under the income/assets test.
(e) Effect on rates of Service or Social Security pensions of variations in assessable income (other than in war widows pension) after 1 November 1986

If, because of an increase in other income a service or social security pension is assessed at a rate lower than that in payment after 1 November 1986, the service or social security pension will be reduced to that lower rate.
The service or social security pension will not be increased in future even if the income affecting the assessment subsequently reduces.
For example:
Rate in payment after 1 November 1986: $60.05 p.w. Rate assessed and payable following increased income: $40.00 p.w.
Rate assessed when income subsequently reduced: $60.05 p.w. Rate actually payable: $40.00 p.w.

Theoretically it would be appropriate for a war widow whose service or social security pension is frozen at a rate lower than the maximum possible ($60.05 a week) to relinquish the pension when her income reduces, and reapply for it to be granted at the higher assessed rate (up to $60.05 a week). It is intended to legislate to prevent this.
20 August 1986...(D. Volker)
Secretary

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. First, is it not a fact that, even though the French claim that Australian uranium will not be used for weapons, the supply of additional Australian uranium will allow the French to divert uranium from other sources, from power production to weapons production? Secondly, does the fact that France is not a signatory to the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons mean that there is no legal or moral obligation for Australia to supply uranium to France, and that any such sale is thus for purely financial reasons? Thirdly, is it not a fact that the sale of uranium to France will endanger the South Pacific Forum and the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty area by establishing a double standard in our relationship with France over nuclear matters? Finally, why did the Government decide on this uranium sale in opposition to its policies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government did not take the decision to resume uranium sales to France lightly, not only because of its party policy implications but also because the embargo policy symbolised in a dramatic way our absolute opposition to French nuclear testing in the South Pacific-opposition that we are, of course, continuing to pursue vigorously in every available forum, bilateral and multilateral. The balance of considerations in favour of this decision at the end of the day overwhelmed those against. Let me describe those relevant considerations. Obviously, there were budgetary ones. To achieve the kinds of deficit target figures the Government was chasing-that task became more stringent as time went on and economic circumstances changed, making it necessary to go for lower and lower levels-some dramatic savings, cuts and revenue alternatives had to be considered. The budgetary implications of the existing embargo policy were considerable. Not only had there been the $41m of outlays over the past two years on earlier contracted sums, but there was a commitment to pay another $25m this year, $26m next year and $13m the year after that.

ANSWER.PARA: The decision was made on the basis that the Budget would benefit to the extent not only of the amounts contracted to be taken this year but also the amount previously stockpiled. So there was a $66m budgetary impact. Honourable senators will undoubtedly appreciate that not many other avenues offered that saving in a way that was not immediately hurtful to sections of the Australian community. Not only was there the budgetary impact as such but there was the larger economic impact of the decision. The $66m will go straight into our current account and, as such, be an important contributor in alleviating the larger balance of payments problem we obviously have. Moreover, there are obvious implications for the future, in terms not only of that sum this year but also of opening up the French market. It is estimated that if, as seems reasonable, in the future we get 25 per cent of the domestic energy market in France, it will mean, in current dollar values through the late 1980s or at least the early 1990s, export returns to Australia of something over $200m a year. In our present economic climate, it is a considerable luxury to forgo an economic advantage for the nation of that magnitude.

Those budgetary and economic considerations would not, of course, be conclusive were there grounds to believe that the policy was, nonetheless, having some impact in forcing France to change its mind about tests in the South Pacific. If it were having such a potential effect, we would be involved in the same sort of calculation as we are in the context of South African sanctions, and it would be a question of the country making a continuing economic and budgetary sacrifice to achieve some larger policy end. I guess that that would be an overwhelming consideration.

But the reality is otherwise. The policy has had a non-existent political impact in France. There has never been any question of any of the other uranium suppliers-Gabon, Niger, Canada or Namibia-participating in this kind of boycott. There has never been any political pressure or economic pressure on France to modify its behaviour as a result of this embargo. There has never been a chance for the policy in that sense to have an effect. In those circumstances, that became a relevant consideration when weighed against the other advantages.

As to the implications of the policy change in our attitude to the nuclear non-proliferation treaty which Senator Sanders properly raises, in short the Government's change of policy does not undermine the credibility of our strong support for the nuclear non-proliferation treaty, notwithstanding, of course, the fact that France is not a party to that treaty. France is not a party to that treaty but is a party to safeguards arrangements, bilaterally and multilaterally, including in particular those with Australia, which are for all practical purposes exactly the same in their effect. Australian uranium as a consequence of those safeguards arrangements has not been, is not now and will not be in the future used in any French nuclear weapons programs-on Mururoa Atoll or anywhere else.

Senator Sanders raised also the larger foreign policy implications for the Pacific of a South Pacific nuclear free zone, adherence by our friends in the Pacific and the implications for the Forum countries. All I can say in that respect is that there has just been a meeting of the South Pacific Forum. It took place in the context of enormous Press speculation here and internationally about a possible reversal of the policy; yet that issue was not raised at the Forum by any country. One must accordingly make judgments about its impact.

The reality is that at the Forum meeting and elsewhere Australian policy has been acknowledged as a symbolic gesture, not one with any substantive effect. The gesture was made in 1983. The gesture was valuable at the time but it has ceased to be of value. There comes a time in the life of every nation when gestures of that kind simply cannot, for the overall good of the nation, be afforded.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. The Minister mentioned that he hoped that Australia would soon have 25 per cent of the French uranium market. I ask: Have we signed any new contracts for uranium supply to France, other than the existing contracts which we all know about?

—There are no new uranium contracts that have been signed but, as a result of this decision, arrangements have been made for the continuation of the existing contract, including the taking of the originally contracted amounts of uranium. I simply make the point, and was making the point, in the context of the market for all practical purposes now being opened, that it is therefore possible for Roxby Downs new supplies coming on to the market to now actively pursue the French market in a way that was not possible during the currency of this policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I make the point that the Minister is clearly debating the question. We have had very few questions today. She should be brought to order and sat down.

Is it a fact that Budget Paper No. 1 indicates that the consumer price index grew by an underlying annual rate of 10.4 per cent in the six months ended 30 June 1986? Does this rate reflect the considerable effects of the depreciation of the Australian dollar, offset by falling oil prices? In view of the continuing fall in the value of the dollar, the recent upward trends in oil prices and the underlying rate of 10.4 per cent in the last six months of the last financial year, how can the Government confidently predict an inflation rate of 8 per cent in the Budget for the forthcoming financial year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did the honourable senator say that that was in Budget Paper No. 1, Statement No. 2?
—Budget Paper No. 1, page 28.

—That would be Statement No. 2, if it is on page 28 of Budget Paper No. 1. I have not read it all the way through; so I am not sure what the honourable senator means by `the underlying rate of inflation of 10.4 per cent'. The CPI increase for those two quarters was 4.3 per cent and of course since then there has been a discounting of that by 2 per cent in the national wage case. I am sorry; that was for the September and December quarters.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable senator asks how the CPI forecast can be justified. I think it is very important that this fact be more widely appreciated: Inflation in Australia is not being driven by wage increases. Inflation in Australia is being driven by import price changes caused by the devaluation of the Australian dollar, which in turn has been caused principally by the disastrous decline in Australia's terms of trade.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why are you discounting by only 2 per cent?

—Go and draw up another Patrick Partners balance sheet or prospectus, or something like that. I know that the honourable senator is an expert on putting out shonky pros- pectuses, but whether he really understands this I do not know.
—Order! Senator Walsh, that is not a proper line of answer.
—Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I ask that the Minister withdraw that last remark.
—I ask the Minister to withdraw. The remark was in response to Senator Baume.
—Did you ask me to withdraw, Mr Deputy President? I did not hear you very well. I withdraw.

ANSWER.PARA: Inflation in Australia is not being driven by wages; indeed it is being controlled by wages. In the three and a half years that this Government has been in power there has been a real wage rate decline of the order of 5 per cent. In the United Kingdom, under the sort of industrial relations policy which the Opposition says it would like to have, for not quite the same period but for the calendar years 1983 to 1985, there were real wage rate increases of 11.5 per cent. The perverse outcome of all these wage and commodity price changes that have taken place is that a country such as Australia, in which real wages have declined, has recently had an increase in its inflation rate, whereas most of the countries of Western Europe and North America have had falling inflation rates in spite of real wage increases. In some cases, such as in the United Kingdom, which I cited, countries have had very substantial real wage increases. There is a common cause for that paradox, and the common cause is the changes in commodity prices which have punished Australia in terms of both national income and, by the devaluation of the dollar, our domestic price level. Most of the countries in north-western Europe and North America have been beneficiaries of precisely that same phenomenon; that is, the fall in commodity prices.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I have a supplementary question. The point that has been made by the Minister ad nauseam was, of course, referred to in my question and I added for his benefit the further point that in fact oil prices are tending to rise. What I am now asking is: If that is so, obviously inflation will be higher this coming year than the stated figure in the Government's own Budget Papers of 8 per cent; so how can he possibly justify the 8 per cent figure? That is the simple question.

—How can we justify it? I have already referred the honourable senator to one wage discount which is in place. There is a specific statement of Government policy in the Budget Papers to seek a further result in the next national wage case. That is the last one which would affect this financial year. As to the honourable senator's reference to oil prices, the policy the Government adopted, I think some six months ago, in response to the very sudden and huge decline in world oil prices, and consequentially in the import parity price for Australian oil, was in general to maintain revenue neutrality; that is, if oil prices fell and the crude oil excise fell with them, the Government would recover approximately the same amount of revenue from increases in the refined petroleum products excise. That is not quite a one to one offset because a portion of our total petroleum consumption is sourced overseas; but, if oil prices rise and crude oil excise rises with them, the Government's general policy is to apply that same principle but in reverse; that is, to achieve broad revenue neutrality by reducing the excise on refined petroleum products.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. The Minister will be aware of a Budget allocation of $3.1m for a scheme of community work for the unemployed, as foreshadowed by the Prime Minister in his address to the nation in June of this year. The Minister will also be familiar with my previous questions in this place suggesting that guidelines be altered so as to allow those unemployed to undertake several hours of community work without prejudicing receipt of benefits. Can the Minister give an assurance that participation in the new scheme will be voluntary and will in no way amount to civil conscription of those who genuinely cannot find paid work?
—Oh, lovely!
—Do you want conscription?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition has always wanted conscription in the past; so I suppose it still wants it. Senator Tate has shown an interest in this subject for some considerable time. Indeed, I have here a couple of extracts from Hansard as far back as 25 March 1985 and 19 April 1985; so I understand his interest in it.

ANSWER.PARA: In response to the last part of Senator Tate's question, yes, I can guarantee that this will not be civil conscription and that participation in the scheme will be voluntary. There is a widespread belief-I think probably well founded-that a large number of young people presently receiving unemployment benefits would like to have an extended opportunity to perform some sort of community work. I say `an extended opportunity' because the volunteer youth program has been operating at a very low level for some time. What the Government now proposes to do is, I suppose, an extension of that. Because of that I can also give an assurance that those who do undertake that sort of community work will not have their entitlement to unemployment benefits prejudiced.

There are, of course, as Senator Tate suggested, some people who would like to make this sort of scheme compulsory. Foremost is the Leader of the Opposition, who asserted last year that it ought to be compulsory for everybody on the unemployment benefit to undertake full time tertiary training for three days a week. The catch is that if all those people undertook tertiary training in the cheapest per capita way, that is, at a technical and further education college, the cost would be a modest $600m. That was one of the savings options proposed last year by the Opposition Leader-I presume before he had time to think the matter through. I trust he is not still pushing that silly idea which he floated last year. I invite confirmation from the Opposition that he is not pushing that silly idea any more. There is no confirmation so I presume that he is still pushing it. I can conclude nothing else. That is an extreme example but if in any scheme of this type such a practice were compulsory there would be huge administrative costs and a requirement for a large number of additional public servants to enforce the scheme.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer and the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. I refer to the Treasurer's banana republic interview of 14 May in which he said that a growth outcome of less than 3 per cent would result in an increase in unemployment. In view of the fact that the Budget predicts total growth of 2 1/4 per cent in 1986-87, I ask: By how much does the Government expect unemployment to rise this year? How can that be reconciled with the fact that unemployment is at 8.3 per cent yet the Budget predicts an average unemployment rate of only 7.9 per cent?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I will give some clarification of the figure. The 2 1/4 per cent Budget forecast which Senator MacGibbon mentioned is for gross domestic product growth. Non-farm GDP is forecast to increase by 2 1/2 per cent. Non-farm GDP tends to be much more sensitive to employment and unemployment levels than the GDP in total. The more restricted non-farm GDP is more directly related to the labour market. The Treasurer's comment that any growth rate below 3 per cent would result in an increase in unemployment is based on the normal sorts of assumptions about the underlying demographic structure-that is, the net additions to the 15- to 65-year age group and therefore to the potential labour force-and on assumptions about productivity growth.

ANSWER.PARA: It is generally accepted, as the Treasurer said, that any growth rate below 3 per cent will cause some increase in unemployment. Indeed, the Budget documents make it quite clear that the Government anticipates some increase in unemployment, although the unemployment rate is a function not only of the number of people in employment but also of the participation rate. That rate can swing to a quite significant extent. I cannot guarantee the figure, but I think it is correct to say it was forecast in the Budget Papers that the number of UB recipients will on average increase by 35,000 this year. That is the most precise estimate which the Government has made on that in the Budget Papers. It is necessary for internal numerical consistency to have a precise figure built into the estimates of UB recipients. However, that sort of change is not necessarily directly related to the unemployment rate which will finally occur.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations inform the Senate of the Government's attitude to claims by the Plumbers and Gasfitters Employees Union of Australia for a $60 per week over-award payment and a 36-hour week-in effect, a breach of the prices and incomes accord?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's attitude to that attempt by the plumbers and gasfitters, led by George Crawford, to break out of the accord is one of strong opposition. One way the Government will apply pressure to ensure that the plumbers and gasfitters campaign fails is through the guidelines which have long been established for the letting of government contracts. ANSWER.PARA: I note however that the Opposition is in coalition with George Crawford, because George Crawford has adopted the Opposition's wages policy-that is, to let collective bargaining and market forces determine wages. So the Opposition supports George Crawford's campaign for a $60 wage increase and a 36-hour week. Let that be very clearly understood. George Crawford and the plumbers and gasfitters are acting in complete conformity with the Opposition's wages policy, in total opposition to and non-conformity with the wages policy of this Government. If the wages policy of this Government does not prevail-that is, if the plumbers and gasfitters and George Crawford have any sort of significant victory-and the wages policy of the Opposition and George Crawford is then adopted by other unions the outcome for the country will be catastrophic. It is essential that the wages policy of the Federal Labor Government and the majority of Australian unions prevail and that the wages policy put forward jointly by the unholy coalition of the plumbers and gasfitters union and the Liberal and National parties be defeated.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Resources and Energy to the decision announced by the Treasurer last night to allow Queensland Mines Ltd to fulfil its contracts to sell uranium to France. Does this decision herald the start of a surge in Australian uranium sales which will see the Federal Government allowing Queensland Mines to develop its other leases, enabling the development of the Koongarra and Jabiluka deposits and facilitating the development of uranium deposits on Aboriginal land, where the Aboriginal owners have reached development agreements with mining companies?
—The Australian Labor Party policy on limiting to three the number of mines from which uranium can be produced and sold remains, I assure the honourable senator and everyone else, quite intact.

—The Minister representing the Minister for Transport will be aware of the unprecedented world-wide surplus of shipping tonnage and widespread low-cost freight competition. How has Australian shipping been affected by these world-wide trends? What are the implications for Australian exporters of the current instability in the shipping market?

—The Senate would be aware that there have been great changes in the trade situations of most countries. That is reflected in the maritime industry. Some instability in attitudes has developed over the last year or so, and that has implications for Australia. Over recent years there has been an unprecedented level of surplus shipping tonnage on a world-wide basis. As a result there has been increasing low-cost competition. This has resulted in the collapse or restructuring of major transport or maritime companies. The Minister has informed me that there is no shortage of new shipping lines seeking to enter Australia's export trade on a commercial basis. Competition has never been as great. As a consequence most export freight rates from Australia have never been so low. In response to Senator Maguire's question, I understand that these developments have encouraged Australian exporters to have an increased regard for reliability and stability factors within the industry, which is a terribly important part of efficient shipping services to overseas markets. In effect, I am advised that there have been some positive factors in the maritime industry as a result of the changes that have taken place.
