DEBATE.TITLE: FRINGE BENEFITS AND CAPITAL GAINS TAXATION

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that the President has received the following letter, dated 20 August, from Senator Chaney:

INTERJECT.PARA: Pursuant to Standing Order 64, I give notice that today I propose to move-
`That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The need for the highest taxing government in Australia's history to abandon its destructive, anti-investment and anti-incentive fringe benefits and capital gains taxes.'
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The need for the highest taxing government in Australia's history to abandon its destructive, anti-investment and anti-incentive fringe benefits and capital gains taxes.

The Opposition brings forward this matter of urgency because it clearly is a matter of serious concern to all Australians that we should resume the path of economic growth and recovery. That was what we might have expected this week to be devoted to, with the Budget being brought down last night, but of course those expectations have been rather settled by what the Government has produced. We have here the highest taxing government in Australia's history. For the third year in a row it has put in its own Budget Papers that it is taking more than a quarter of the gross domestic product. Of everything produced in Australia, a quarter is taken in taxes by this Federal Government and, at a time when we are in an economic crisis which the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has described as something akin to war, we find that the Government's policy seems to be to tax us out of our difficulties.

What is the economic context in which we are operating? If I may refer to the Government's own predictions as put forward in the Budget last night, we are told that we will have diminishing living standards. The Government tells us on page 9 of the Budget that we will have to restrain real household disposable incomes, consistent with the need for our living standards to be trimmed. We find that the Government is saying that there will be reduced private sector investment. We find that that investment will be reduced in terms of business fixed capital investment, with even larger declines in the investment in housing in this financial year. We find the Government telling us we live in a country which will suffer increasing unemployment this year, confirmed by the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) in Question Time today, and we find that we have a Budget in which the Government is predicting a continuation of the dreadful balance of payments situation we have suffered over this last year.

I suppose one of the hopes that might have emerged is that we would move into a lower interest rate environment. If we accept the Government's estimate that our balance of payments situation will be very difficult, that we are likely to have a deficit of something in the order of 6 per cent again in this current financial year-a figure that Senator Walsh, who is at the table, scoffed at earlier this year-then it is unlikely that there will be a softening of interest rates. We bring this matter forward because we believe that the high level of taxation is an important factor in contributing to the difficulties we face. Later this week we will be debating the Budget, a document which I think we all agree is failing to produce the sort of turnaround in Australia's economic fortunes that all Australians want. For today we concentrate our attention on the taxation system and in particular on the Government's brilliant introduction of a capital gains tax and a fringe benefits tax as part of the cause for the economic malaise which is afflicting Australia and which on the Government's own prediction will continue to afflict Australia over the next 12 months.

It is the position of the Opposition that there is no single solution to Australia's economic problems. It is certainly not a set of problems that can be solved just by a Budget. It is not a set of problems that can be solved by simply targeting in on one area of government activity. There are key areas which this Government must tackle, which any government of Australia today would have to tackle if it wanted to put us back on the path of growth and into a situation where Australians could expect rising instead of falling standards of living. Those key areas that must be tackled are the labour market, and this the Government has lamentably failed to do; the cost burdens which make Australia's industry uncompetitive, and this it has lamentably failed to do; the issues of excessive regulation, and that it has lamentably failed to do; and of course the taxation burden which is frightening off investment in this country.

Our fundamental complaint about the Government's approach to taxation is that it has destroyed incentive and, in particular, the incentive to invest. It is far too complex. It has introduced new cost burdens on business, quite apart from the cost of the taxes themselves. We believe that the Government's approach to taxation has been unfair because it has, for example, imposed tax burdens not on those who receive benefit but on those who pay the benefits. We say most clearly that the overall approach to taxation that the Government has introduced is against the new investment which is absolutely vital if Australia is to have a growing economy which can compete with the rest of the world. That is the context of this debate. We are now in a situation in which in the last 24 hours the Government has announced further tax increases amounting to more than $1.4 billion at a time when, indeed, the whole community is crying out for tax relief and tax reduction and not tax increase.

We would have hoped that by now the Government would have taken some notice of the very wide demands which have been made for relief from the particular taxes specified in this motion of urgency. It is not a narrow Opposition view that these taxes are counterproductive; it is the view of a very substantial part of the Australian community and many of the people who normally are not our political allies. We raised these matters-in particular we raised the issue of the fringe benefits tax-with the Minister for Finance in the Senate at Question Time yesterday. Senator Walsh will be speaking later in this debate. It was interesting to see the contemptuous way in which he responded to the question asked by Senator Messner about the fringe benefits tax. Senator Messner asked him about the attitude of Premier Unsworth, Premier Burke and Mr Ron Edwards, MP. Of course, the Minister for Finance made it quite clear that he would simply abuse those people for putting the views they did rather than responding to those views and giving them the sort of consideration that those people might have thought that they were entitled to. It is interesting to see that the barbs of the Minister for Finance have been so blunted by the fact that he directs them just as much towards his Labor colleagues, particularly his State Labor colleagues, as he does towards those who have the misfortune to sit opposite him in this place.

The view that these taxes should be moved out as quickly as possible goes well beyond the Opposition which has pledged to repeal these taxes. Let me remind the Senate of all the people who have made a very public demonstration of their opposition to these government taxes. The very great regret that we have as an opposition is that some of them were not more public at the time when the decisions were being made and at the time when we were opposing these taxes in the Senate. That might have influenced the Australian Democrats, who are, of course, the cause of these taxes being able to be put in place because they voted for them. It might have helped the Democrats to make up their minds in a more sensible way if the Labor Premiers, who are now so vocal in their opposition to this tax, had been as vocal at the time when the legislation was before the Senate. Nevertheless, I welcome the conversion of the many people who have come out against this tax recently.

On this occasion I even welcome the support of Premier Burke of Western Australia, who asked the Government to rethink the perks tax in late July of this year. Indeed, he even had Sir Arvi Parbo as his guest speaker to point out just what an inane tax this was and what an impact this was having on the productive industries in this country. It was under the chairmanship of Mr Burke that Sir Arvi Parbo pointed out in Perth that under the Government's tax proposal single men's rooms in remote housing areas are taxed as though they were houses and that even the cost of transferring employees from one location to another is considered a fringe benefit. Therefore, we have a situation in which if an employer wants to transfer an employee from one place to another that will be seen as a fringe benefit on which the employer would have to pay tax.

We then, of course, had the comments of Mr Unsworth, who was not at all short of criticisms of the fringe benefits tax after he had been brought to face reality by his electoral misfortune in New South Wales. He said that what has come out of the fringe benefits proposal is an administrative nightmare. The Labor Opposition Leader in Queensland, not a man whom one would find reported in the national Press very often, was reported in the national Press on this issue. Again he used the expression that this tax is an administrative nightmare and that the Government should be doing something about it. His comment about the Government's proposal was:
. . . reads as if some bureaucrat down there--
of course, that is here in Canberra--
has gone mad.

We also find that rather more moderate Labor voice, the Labor Premier in South Australia, Mr Bannon, severely criticising this tax and saying that he has doubts about it in regard to its administrative requirements and saying that he believes that it needs change. Most recently, we find that the Government's own back bench, led by a man who does not normally leap to national prominence, Mr Ron Edwards, a Western Australian back bencher, apparently getting great support in the ALP Caucus when he called on the Government to make urgent changes to the application of the tax. The figures involved in opposition to the tax come from well beyond political circles. However, I make the point that very substantial figures in the Labor movement have recognised that the prejudices and, indeed, the elements of cowardice which led the Government to introduce the fringe benefits tax in the form it did ought to be put aside and that the Government should repeal the fringe benefits tax and let business get on with the job of doing business instead of filling in forms.

The Opposition's opposition to this fringe benefits tax has been quite straightforward. We believe that the tax is unfair. We believe that it is an administrative nightmare. Of course, the Minister for Finance, who sits opposite, who often has to field questions on this issue, is fond of talking about the rorts. He is fond of talking about those people with high salary packages who are able to get benefits in the form of fringe benefits and not pay tax on them. I say very simply to the Minister that those people in that position can very easily be assessed for taxation by the Commissioner of Taxation. Simple procedures are available to deal with that. The reality is that the fringe benefits tax is impacting not on just a narrow band of people who are able to get very high incomes at reduced tax but on a wide range of business and on a wide range of the productive enterprises of Australia which should be encouraged by this Government, instead of being discouraged.

The Government sent out a 56-page booklet on how business people would have to account for the fringe benefits tax. I do not have the time in this debate to go through all the ridiculous detail that people are called on to provide. However, let me say that the Government has moved to a point where people who are using cars as part of their business are required to record so many details that of course many will find it impossible to get their employees to comply. We find that each day it is required that the person who is using such a car keep a record of the date of the journey, the odometer reading at the beginning and the end of the journey, the number of kilometres travelled, the purpose of the journey, the name of the person driving the car, the date the entry was made and the name of the person making the entry. We are told that it has to be in English and signed by the person making the entry. I do not know whether that is a discrimination against people who do not speak English but it is certainly a discrimination against all those people trying to carry on business in Australia and whom the Government is exhorting to be competitive and to get out and compete with the rest of the world. It throws administrative nightmares-I use the word which has been used by Labor leaders-in the road of people who are seeking to get out there to compete, to invest and to make Australia a growth country again instead of a country in decline as it has become under this Government.

I would like to touch on some of the recent indications of the impact of this tax on people who are trying to carry on business, often under very great difficulty. For example, we find that the car industry is now confirming the predictions that people in that industry made late last year and earlier this year about the damaging impact that this tax would have on car manufacturers in Australia. We find that the Federal Chamber of Automotive Industries in its latest statement is telling us that, whilst it believes the real impact of the fringe benefits tax will not occur until the last quarter of 1986, already it has caused a 13 per cent drop in fleet sales.

I have made the point in this place before, and I make it again, that that decline is on top of a whole series of other declines which are doing enormous damage to the automotive industry. What this Government is doing is wilfully adding a new tax burden which is exacerbating the difficulties of that industry. It will cost jobs in the union of the acting Government Whip. It will cost jobs in at least three States of the Commonwealth. We find that the National Roads and Motorists Association has done a survey which estimates that the tax has added $100 a week to the cost of a company car. The whole range-hundreds of thousands-of businesses which provide company cars is subjected to new tax burdens which have nothing to do with the profitability of those enterprises.

When the Agnew nickel mine in Western Australia had to suspend operations in the very difficult trading conditions that it has, it made it quite explicit that it was the fringe benefits tax and other taxes, together with escalating direct and indirect labour costs, which have been significant factors in the decision to suspend operations. The long established mining company in Australia, Mount Isa Mines, described the fringe benefits tax as the last straw. A senior executive of that company was reported as saying that 80 per cent of the company's fringe benefits are paid to blue collar unionists but that they would attract an extra $5m in taxes. He said that that was the last straw that broke the camel's back-a fringe benefits tax which is being dishonestly marketed by the Federal Government as a device to stop rorts.

There is a whole range of people who are being affected in this way. We have the mining companies which are operating in a highly competitive world market. We find that other organisations, such as the National Trust of Australia, educational organisations, the Red Cross Society and so on, are being subjected to a new tax which the Minister opposite and the Labor Party proponents of this tax keep describing as a tax to prevent rorts. In reality it is providing a new burden on productive enterprise and even a new burden on non-profit organisations that are providing services to the Australian community. We find that State and local governments are having to pay huge amounts in additional taxes. It is estimated that they will have to shell out an additional $55m, and that highlights the absurdity of this tax because other taxes will have to be raised to pay this additional tax to the Commonwealth.

We are calling for repeal of this tax because we believe that that would be an important element in restoring confidence in the investment community and doing something about the Government's disastrous investment situation. The Government's prediction is that investment is falling, and it is quite clear that many businesses are being affected by both the fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax. Our request to the Government is made with the strong support of the bulk of the Australian people. The majority of the Australian people have stopped regarding this fringe benefits tax as something which is going to stop rorts. They have now come to see that this is a tax which will impose important and heavy new burdens on businesses around Australia, that it is the ordinary men and women of Australia, in particular those who work in the more remote areas of Australia, who are going to suffer the damage from the new tax. In addition, there are the extraordinary costs which are being incurred. The Government proudly announced that it is going to reduce the number of public servants by 2,000. In fact, the number of public servants next year is predicted to be higher than the number last year, but the estimate for extra staff required for the administration of this tax alone is 590. That alone is a good reason for reconsidering this new tax and its absurd complexity. It is imposing heavy administrative costs, not merely on businesses in a direct sense but on the Government and hence on every Australian taxpayer.

We have a situation where, in the national interest, we believe it is centrally important that the Government should recast its taxation policies. We in the Opposition believed that there was some prospect that last night in the Budget we would see that occurring. In fact, instead of that, we have seen new tax burdens and we have seen, therefore, a worsening of the anti-investment elements of the environment in Australia today. In relation to this we have had a very confusing couple of weeks. In the last couple of weeks both the Prime Minister and the Treasurer have hinted at possible change; then they have denied it, and then they have not seemed to know what the other was saying. We had the spectacle of Senator Cook, who generally comes in and takes part in these debates-we are going to miss him today because he usually contributes to the Opposition's cause in a very effective way-calling a Perth news conference to assure the world that there would be no change. Just what he was seeking to achieve by that I am not sure.

We ask the question: What is the Government going to do? It is quite clear that this tax is having a negative effect on an economy which is in decline. It is quite clear that if we are to get economic recovery we have to have a situation where business is encouraged, and where it is encouraged to enter into new investment. We believe that the capital gains tax discourages new investment; we believe that the fringe benefits tax discourages all forms of business activity. We believe that if the Government has the interests of Australia at heart it will get rid of these taxes and not leave the matter until it is defeated in an ignominious way at the end of next year and it is left to the present Opposition to do the job for it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Fairness demands that employees who are paid solely in cash-as most Australians are-should not be asked to pay more tax and thus effectively subsidise those whose income is obtained partly in cash and partly in the form of valuable benefits of other kinds.

SPEECH.PARA: That is a quotation not from Bob Hawke, not from Paul Keating, not from me; it is a quotation from John Howard in a Press statement that was issued on 11 July 1980. It bears repeating. It is from John Howard, the present Leader of the Opposition:

Fairness demands that employees who are paid solely in cash-as most Australians are-should not be asked to pay more tax, and thus effectively subsidise, those whose income is obtained partly in cash and partly in the form of valuable benefits of other kinds . . .

(Quorum formed) I can see that the members of the Liberal Party of Australia do not like having their Leader's words quoted back at them-their Leader putting the case against allowing massive tax evasion and avoidance through the practice of taking income in kind instead of income in cash and evading taxation in the process. He knew that it should have been stopped in 1980, but he failed to stop it, as he failed to do everything else when he was Treasurer. It has been left to this Government to get on and do all the jobs, all the necessary things which John Howard ignominiously failed to do in the five years when he was Treasurer.

We seem to have heard from Senator Chaney this hypothesis that the present parlous condition of the Australian economy is caused by the very recent application of a fringe benefits tax and a capital gains tax. If one had to put a name to that, I suppose one would have to call it the theory of retrospective causation. Indeed, it is the absence of taxes such as these which has made a significant contribution to the Australian economy being in the parlous condition that it is. I refer specifically to Senator Chaney's point about motor vehicles. It was asserted by an industry lobby-an assertion repeated mindlessly by the Opposition-that because of new measures in regard to the provision of motor vehicles to employees, which had been a major area of tax avoidance or evasion in the fringe benefits area, there would be a massive decline in the sales of motor vehicles to employers. If that were true, it proves that because of the existence of a tax haven, a tax avoidance mechanism by way of fringe benefits through a free company car, excessive investment was being poured into the purchase of motor vehicles for which there was no underlying economic justification. That is, the existence of a tax shelter was attracting capital, which ought to have been invested in productive areas, into a non-productive tax haven, a tax avoidance area, when there was no functional need whatsoever for that investment to have taken place.

The Opposition cannot have it both ways. Indeed, far from taxes of this type having caused the structural problems of the Australian economy, the absence of taxes of this type is one of the causes of the structural problems that we presently face. The fact is that for the last six years Australia has been recording a current account deficit of between 4 and 6 per cent of gross domestic product. The highest current deficit ever recorded was in 1981-82, when John Howard was Treasurer. The major cause of that deficit being as large as it was was the so-called resources boom which had been talked up for cynical political reasons in 1980-a boom which never happened. We as a nation, however, are saddled with the interest costs of that free and easy period of foreign borrowing by governments, State governments in particular, for the resources boom which never happened. That situation has continued for some time. When this Government came to office it set about implementing in the Australian economy the structural changes which are essential if our current account problem is in the long term to be overcome-and Australia has had periodic current account crises. The only way it can be overcome is by restructuring the Australian economy, something that could not have been done overnight. This Government had started that process and it was proceeding. Indeed, one of the more thoughtful economic journalists, David Clarke, wrote that the Government had set in place the mechanisms which were required to turn the economy around and then it was hit with the collapse of the terms of trade.

The Opposition, of course, likes to dismiss the horrendous implications of that terms of trade shift. But let me just say that in 1985-86, over the previous year, our terms of trade declined by 10 per cent. It is expected that there will be a further decline of 8 per cent in this financial year. No country can take a terms of trade decline of that magnitude without its having some pretty horrible implications. So that decline has caused particular difficulties. The country does have an economic crisis, and what is the Opposition's answer to it? To bring back the free boozy lunch. That is the best proposition which the Opposition can put up to overcome a potentially hazardous current account situation accumulated over many years and compounded by a huge adverse movement in the terms of trade. The Opposition says that the way to fix up this situation is to bring back the free lunch and to reinstitute a taxation system which encourages the misdirection of capital investment into areas for which there is no functional need and no economic justification-to encourage investment in tax shelters by way of the provision of excessive motor vehicles, among other things.

The fact is that Australian industry, Australian capitalism, Australian business-call it whatever you like-has before it the greatest opportunity it has had probably for 50 years, if not ever. Our real unit labour costs expressed in Australian dollars are at the lowest level they have been since the 1960s. The level of industrial disputes is lower than it has been since the 1960s. We have an effective wages policy which has reduced award earnings, award rates, in real terms by 5 per cent over a 3 1/2-year period at a time when the economy was enjoying a high and sustained rate of economic growth. There is no precedent in Australian economic history for that outcome. Finally, because of the very large devaluation of the dollar-around 40 per cent when measured against the trade weighted index-something caused principally by the terms of trade decline, Australian exporting and import competing industries are massively competitive by international standards. Some of them will take up the challenge. Others will sit around on their arses and whinge about having to pay a fringe benefits tax-something that they should have had to pay long ago. The substance of an editorial which appeared in the Australian Financial Review on 12 August concerned the fact that New Zealand had turned around its traditional trade deficit with Australia and indeed now had a trade surplus. The editorial concluded with this paragraph:
Fringe benefits taxes are now well established in New Zealand. While Australian business people whinge, New Zealanders are getting on with business and taking their markets.

That is an admonition which the responsible section of the Australian business community ought to take to its bosom. Instead of getting on and doing the job they are supposed to do in the most competitive environment that they have ever had, with the most successful wages policy, the most successful industrial relations policy and the lowest real unit labour costs ever, expressed in Australian dollars, and instead of getting on and doing the job as their counterparts in New Zealand have done, the Australian business community sits around and whinges about a fringe benefits tax with the encouragement of the economic saboteurs in the Opposition.

In New Zealand a fringe benefits tax was introduced in April 1985 at a rate of 45c, since increased to 48c. It is a model for the Australian legislation. The same sorts of complaints came from some sections of the New Zealand Establishment about it-that it would not work and so on-all of which have been disproved. Let us look back and remember the provisional payment system introduced on 1 September 1983. It was said then by the same sorts of people and, in many cases, precisely the same individuals-many of whom are members of the Opposition-that that tax was administratively impossible, that it could not be introduced and that it had to be postponed. Last, it was said that it would cause catastrophic economic damage. The tax came in and none of those things happened. Why were those people mounting that campaign? It was because they were habitual tax evaders. They were into the black economy. They were not worried about the administration of the tax. They were not worried about economic damage. They were habitual tax evaders who wanted to continue to be habitual tax evaders, and this Government stopped them.

When the Fraser Government very belatedly did something about the decay of the income tax base and introduced its bottom of the harbour tax legislation exactly the same complaints were made. It was said that business could not pay this liability, that thousands of businesses would become bankrupt and that hundreds of thousands of workers would lose their jobs as businesses became bankrupt. From April 1983 the money began to come in, ironically at the very point that economic growth turned sharply upwards. Those false campaigns have been waged in the past by people who had a vested interest in deceiving the public and continuing to cheat it. The same sorts of people are doing it today.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you think Premier Burke is saying those things?

—I said yesterday that I will be telling Premier Burke, when we are both in Western Australia together, what I think about his comments on the subject. There is a common thread behind what the Opposition is doing; it is not doing it just in this area. The Opposition is trying to sabotage the Australian economy. We saw an overt example of it when a Western Australian Liberal member of the Legislative Assembly, Mr Lightfoot, wrote to George Shultz and said: `Please keep subsidising the sales of wheat and sugar so that the prices received by Australian farmers will be lower than they would otherwise be. Please keep paying for the Afghan war. Subsidise sales of wheat and sugar in order that Australian farmers and the Australian nation will receive lower prices'. He wrote to George Shultz and begged him to do it. Mr Lightfoot is crasser than most Liberals. He allowed the letter to get out because it was probably a popular thing to say in Leonora. The others are not so crass, but essentially they are doing the same thing. They are sabotaging the economy. Instead of telling business that it has the greatest opportunity it has ever had, they collaborate with a section of the business community in an orgy of self-indulgent self-pity because they are no longer going to be able to avoid and evade paying the taxes which they always should have paid, as Mr Howard said many years ago.

SPEECH.PARA: They collaborate with George Crawford in a wages policy. They have a wages policy in common with George Crawford and are collaborating with him in an attempt to wreck the prices and income accord, which has-and it is worth repeating-given Australia the lowest real unit labour costs expressed in Australian dollars that it has had since the 1960s, the lowest level of industrial disputes since the 1960s, the highest sustained rate of economic growth since the 1950s, a wages policy which has delivered declines in real award wages through that period of high growth and finally, because of the devaluation of the dollar, the most internationally competitive industry Australia has ever seen. What does the Opposition say? Instead of saying to business `Go and make the most of your opportunities; show some of the entrepreneurial flair that you are always talking about, that you admire in the abstract but rarely put into practice, show that entrepreneurial flair which you believe you have and go and get on with your job', the Opposition encourages business to indulge itself in an orgy of self-pity because it will no longer be able to avoid paying taxes.

Almost a year ago this taxation package-I stress the word `package'-was considered by the Opposition's front bench. A document that Senator Messner prepared was thoughtfully leaked that very night and appeared on television. That document said that if they picked up the goodies such as the ending of the double taxation of dividends and the lowering of marginal tax rates and rejected what it called the nasties in the package-such as getting rid of the free boozy business lunch, and imposing a fringe benefits tax and a capital gains tax-they would be seen as humbugs and hypocrites. That is exactly what the Opposition is doing and humbugs and hypocrites are exactly what its members are.

Finally I turn to the matter of administration. I said this yesterday and I repeat it: If anybody can propose a more efficient system of administration than the one which the Government has proposed, of course the Government is prepared to listen. Any sensible government or sensible group of people would be. However, a pack of lies is being told about the administration of this tax, even by implication. Senator Chaney talked about a log book. Nobody has to keep a log book. People have a choice between applying a statutory formula or keeping a log book. But the Opposition is conducting a deliberate campaign of misinformation. It wants the public to believe that this tax is administratively impossible just as it said the provisional payments system was administratively impossible.

I do not have time to go through all the details but I have a transcript of the Carleton-Walsh Report of 12 August. It is an interview with Max Walsh and Peter Cleeland, the member for McEwen, and I believe it is the most lucid account of the administration of the fringe benefits tax I have seen. In particular it deals with the furphy, the lie, that it is impossible for employers to administer such a tax. In New Zealand employers are paying the tax quarterly, just as employers in Australia will be obliged to do. Employers in New Zealand have stopped whingeing about it and have got on with doing the job. In Australia employers, encouraged by the Opposition, have declined to do that. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a section of the transcript of the interview between Max Walsh and Peter Cleeland.
Leave granted.
The transcript read as follows-

Max Walsh: Peter Cleeland, if I could come first to the last point that Robert Oser made there, because it's the point which so many of the critics of the FBT make, is that they don't object to the actual tax perhaps, but they do object to the principal that it is paid by employers, not the employees, the recipients of the particular privileges. How does the Labor Party handle that sort of criticism?

Peter Cleeland: Well don't forget, Max, that since about 1942, Section 26 (e) of the Income Tax Assessment Act has provided that all fringe benefits are taxable. Now of course the reality is that employers have never complied with that Section, so the cost of taxing that particular fringe benefits has always been there but it's just never been taxed. So things haven't changed.
Max Walsh: It was never, am I right, it was never the responsibility of the employer, it was the responsibility of the employee to pay the tax on those fringe benefits?

Peter Cleeland: But then the employer was obliged under tax law, to value the benefit and make provision on the Group Certificate, of the benefit paid to the employee, so in fact the Taxation Department could tax it. That was never done.
Max Walsh: Why wasn't it done?

Peter Cleeland: Well it became a tax rort in the eighties, of the seventies into the eighties, and it became a standardised package that why bother paying tax when the High Court of Australia under Sir Garfield Barwick seemed to let anything go through at all. I mean it became an entrenched system in the employment package area.
Max Walsh: Do you think it might have been worthwhile Labor challenging that with its new High Court, rather than going into what is this 400 page Act?

Peter Cleeland: Well it would have been even more costly for the employer because under the Section 26 (e) provision, someone has to value each benefit paid to each employee and then on each individual Group Certificate, make a valuation. Now that would have been twice as costly as a single rate of tax across all benefits. It's a much simpler administrative process.

Max Walsh: Well if I could pick up the points that I hope Mr Oser made point by point. First of all he spoke about the paper burden. He's described it as a nightmare of paper and calculations. Well, as a tax lawyer, do you agree with that or not?

Peter Cleeland: Well I'm a bit surprised at Mr Oser's statements that companies don't keep detailed records of the cost of their employment. I find that a very strange statement for an accountant to make. How in the dickens can a company properly claim tax deductibility for those expenses of company employment if they're not keeping accurate records. I can't see any additional costs for those record keeping as already exists.
Max Walsh: You mean even the filling out of log books, it's a fairly complex sort of thing, particularly with the most, perhaps the most sensitive area, that of motor vehicle usage?
Peter Cleeland: Well that's the employee's responsibility, not the employer's. So the employer can't complain in terms of administration costs, what the employee has to do to get the tax deduction.
Max Walsh: So your contention is there is little or no additional administrative costs for most businesses?
Peter Cleeland: That's right.
Max Walsh: There would be for a lot of businesses such as those nominated by Mr Oser, say charities which up to now have had no tax responsibility whatsoever.

Peter Cleeland: Well don't forget that benevolent institutions have been exempted from the fringe benefit tax. Now the government doesn't believe any purely charitable organisation can be subject to FBT.
Max Walsh: The particular case he quoted, if a charity takes somebody out to a dinner, entertainment, that they have to pay tax on that part of the food consumed by their own employees.
Peter Cleeland: Well why should a charitable institution who's providing a benefit like any other company structure, be exempt specifically when the private sector isn't?

Max Walsh: The other areas of course which Mr Oser didn't cover, which hitherto haven't paid tax, are of course State Government authorities and their own, the public sector of the Australian Public Service and the statutory authorities. I mean today we saw Qantas making a provision I think of $16 million. They are really taking on new administrative costs, aren't they?

Peter Cleeland: Well if they don't know already which of their employees are taking a subsidised flight on a Qantas aeroplane, then I suggest their records are inefficient already. They should know which employee already is taking a subsidised flight so I can't see again where there is any additional record keeping required.

Max Walsh: If I could turn to the other area which Mr Oser nominated as one of the anomalies, that is the difficult and specific area of housing and he referred particularly to the mining industry and the accommodation industry, where people live on their place of work. He felt that this should be given special treatment. Do you feel there is any case for this?

Peter Cleeland: Well let's keep in mind first that the former failed Treasurer, now Leader of the Opposition, tried very hard to do exactly what the government is now doing, but failed. Now this government is not like the former Treasurer. We are not going to fail on this issue and in fact it will continue. Now the second point about that is that there is very concessional tax. There is a specific remote area provision for those areas and the rate of tax applicable would be very minimal indeed.

Max Walsh: And Mr Cleeland, he also spoke of the area of Australian consultants working abroad, people earning export income from Australia who will now find themselves subject to quite large amounts of fringe benefits tax, competing with people from other countries, other consultants, who aren't subject to this. Are you at all concerned about this?

Peter Cleeland: Well, I'm not quite sure what he's talking about there frankly, Max, because don't forget the way the fringe benefit tax works is that if it is not a deductible benefit in the hands of the employee, then it is a taxable fringe benefit tax. Now in many of those cases an employee who's receiving some specific payment because of the employment aspect, it is deductible, hence it wouldn't be caught by the fringe benefit tax. I think it needs a bit further clarification, exactly what Mr Oser is talking about there.

Max Walsh: Well, having some knowledge of the complaints from this particular area, I could nominate the idea of a consultant working abroad, where he has to pay large amounts for accommodation and in particular areas, run the sort of household which he wouldn't run in Australia, with servants and other things. And the suggestion is that the Australian consultants, if they have to pay tax on this, will not be anywhere near as competitive as they are with consultants from say Canada or the United States.

Peter Cleeland: Well I'm not sure why an Australian citizen living overseas requires servants when he hasn't got servants in Australia to perform his function. If in fact you receive those lovely benefits, I see no reason why you shouldn't be taxed. It's part of his overall remuneration.

Max Walsh: Well the consultants would say that if you are going to do this, is you simply won't have them operating from Australia, consultants, they'll operate, and earning export income for Australia, they'll operate the Canadian or United States consultants.
Peter Cleeland: I'm not quite sure if the only way Australian industry can work is by having an incentive by way of benefit to make people work, then this country is in a terrible terrible state.
Max Walsh: Well if I could now personalise this. Your seat is the seat of McEwen. What's the sort of swing that would unseat Peter Cleeland?
Peter Cleeland: Well the official margin at the moment is 2.1 percent.
Max Walsh: And are you happy to see this fringe benefits tax come in? Do you think that it places your particular seat at risk?

Peter Cleeland: No I don't. You've got to remember that there's less than 10 percent of Australians are in fact receiving income in the form of benefits. And 90 percent have been paying additional rates of tax because of this particular situation. Now I'll be happy next year when a man on $30,000 a year is going to get $25 net in his pocket. He'll be that much better off and I think they're the people who understand what the fringe benefit tax is all about.
Max Walsh: Peter Cleeland, thanks very much for coming in.

TALK.START.PARA: —Finally I want to expand on a point I made earlier. A taxation reform package has been introduced by this Government. If what Senator Messner once chose to call the nasties are knocked off it becomes impossible to deliver the goodies-that is, the cuts in marginal tax rates and the end of the double taxation of company dividends-in an economically responsible Budget. It is also impossible to deliver those goodies if the things which the Opposition is selectively opposing are successfully opposed. Of course the Government will ensure that that opposition is not successful.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the Opposition, Senator Chaney, who led this debate for the Opposition started his speech with some very pertinent comments about the current Budget. He said that the Budget gave no encouragement to growth and recovery. The Australian Democrats would agree with that. He said that there is no encouragement to private sector investment in this Budget. The Democrats agree with that. He said that unemployment will rise. It certainly will; there is no argument about that. He said that this Budget does nothing to solve the balance of payments problems and that undoubtedly interest rates will rise. All of these points made by Senator Chaney are absolutely relevant; they are points with which the Democrats agree absolutely. It is the solutions that the Opposition has for these problems and the alternatives that it is offering to the Australian people-alternatives to the measures in the current Budget-with which we disagree.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Chaney listed four points. He said that the labour market has to be deregulated. The Opposition has not shown how it would go about deregulating the labour market without enormous industrial confrontation. It has not come up with any solution that seems at all viable to the Democrats. The Opposition has said that it will attack costs, but it has not told us where it will cut costs. The Opposition has said that there is excessive regulation in the community at the moment, and we agree with that. Finally, Senator Chaney got to the point of the debate today-that taxation is too high. It certainly is. However, where will the revenue come from if not from the taxation measures set out in the current Budget? There have to be alternative methods of raising revenue and those alternatives have not been spelt out by the Opposition.

Senator Chaney turned to the Democrats and made a cheap political point. He said: `If only the Democrats had joined with the Opposition to block the whole tax package we would not have this problem of high taxation'. I am getting sick and tired of simple political point scoring by the Opposition. Let us look at the facts. Last year we were confronted with a tax package at a time when the Government's stocks were the highest of those of any government ever in this country. We had two alternatives. First, we could do what the Opposition did and implored us to do-that is, stand flat footed, say that we would oppose the whole tax package and that there was nothing good in it at all and just block it. If we had done that there is no doubt that the Government would have gone to the people on that tax issue. The Government promised $4 billion worth of tax cuts to the Australian people and it is sticking by that promise.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are not paying for it out of this.

—This was the position last year and if the Democrats had joined with the Opposition we would undoubtedly have faced a double dissolution probably early this year and the Government would have had every prospect of gaining control of both houses of Parliament. Flat-footed opposition to the tax package was not the responsible political course to follow last year. We confronted the Government, debated the whole tax package with it and listened to the literally thousands of representations we had from individuals and groups in the community to see whether we could get the worst aspects of the tax package changed so that it would not impact too heavily on any groups of people.
—You didn't do much of a job.

—Senator Messner says that we did not do a very good job. Let me turn to what the Democrats did. I will not say what we did; I will quote what other people have said we did. The fringe benefits tax has been referred to today, and I quote a letter I received from the Federal Chamber of Automotive Industries. In case not all honourable senators are aware, this body represents the manufacturers of Ford, Holden, Toyota and Mitsubishi cars. It is a very important body. On 4 July 1986, the Federal Chamber of Automotive Industries, in a letter to me signed by the President, W. L. Dix, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Senator,

The purpose of this letter is to document the Automotive Industry's appreciation of the support it received from the Democrats in negotiations concerning the fringe benefits tax legislation. We appreciate recognition by the Democrats of the significance of the fringe benefits tax on the vehicle industry and your cooperation in establishing a basis which generated a revised vehicle fringe benefits tax scale, which we estimate will result in a full year tax reduction in the order of $200 million or about 25%, compared with collections which would have been derived by utilisation of the original Government formula.

I repeat that: $200m. Senator Messner says that that is a small concession we wrung from the Government. It is not small as far as the manufacturers of motor cars in this country are concerned. The letter went on to state that at least 20,000 jobs would have been saved in the automotive industry as a result of the initiative on the fringe benefits tax.

One of the most important concessions we gained did not concern the fringe benefits tax or the capital gains tax; it concerned the quarantining of farm losses. When we started to negotiate with the Government it was strongly of the view that the quarantining of farm losses should continue. It made a concession and, finally, as a result of continued pressure by the Democrats, it abandoned the whole notion of quarantining of farm losses. Was that an insignificant concession? The Democrats think it certainly was not. The only contribution by the Opposition was to say: `We will oppose the tax. Let us not try to precipitate a double dissolution at a time when the Government would have no trouble in gaining control of both Houses of the Parliament'.

I now refer to the capital gains tax. The Opposition is prepared to say: `We want no capital gains tax'. It wants Australia to be the only country in the Western world that has no capital gains tax. It wants the tax rorts to continue whereby profits are converted into capital gains, no tax is paid, and there is an uneven distribution between income earned through capital gains and income earned through personal exertion. There is, of course, an absolute necessity for any Western country to have a capital gains tax. The United States is in the process of modifying its capital gains tax. It is doing precisely what the Democrats succeeded in getting the Government to agree to in our negotiations. The United States will impose a capital gains tax at the marginal rate of tax and it will be indexed for inflation. So there will be absolutely no difference between income gained by personal exertion and income gained as a result of capital gain. It matters not where the income is derived from. That is the modern approach to capital gains. That is a much milder form of capital gains tax than the flat capital gains tax which was originally imposed in the United States. At least we are now in the forefront, with a gains tax which is even-handed in regard to both forms of income.

We succeeded in gaining other considerable concessions. There is to be no retrospectivity element in the capital gains tax. The tax is to be indexed for inflation, as I have said. Capital losses are to be offset against capital gains. The family home is to be exempt from the capital gains tax. There is to be no death duty element in the capital gains tax. In particular, the goodwill element in small businesses is recognised, and there is to be a 20 per cent reduction in the tax to take account of goodwill. Employee share ownership schemes were being unfairly treated, and that was modified. The capital gains tax is to be averaged over five years, and that was an important concession. We succeeded in gaining the Government's agreement to no fewer than eight out of the 10 or 12 concessions for which we asked. We now have a capital gains tax which is mild and fair and which does not impact unfairly on various sectors of the community.

I now turn to the fundamental matter in this debate. We agree that taxes are too high. We agree that the fringe benefits tax is very complex. Had the Opposition joined with us and negotiated with the Government, I am sure that we could have achieved a fringe benefits tax which was much less complicated. Instead, the Opposition would not even consider discussing the matter with the Government. It opposed the tax outright. At least we have succeeded in getting considerable concessions in both those areas. The Democrats' fundamental criticism of the Opposition is this: It is pretty good on rhetoric, but it is very small on constructive ideas as to where and how there should be a change of direction in the way in which this economy is managed. The fact is that both the Labor Party and the Liberal Party are dominated by radical free marketeers. They want to sit back and let market forces rule this economy. Neither the Labor Party nor the Liberal Party is prepared to manage the economy in the interests of all Australians, and that is what must be done.

To illustrate what could be done if a government of this country were prepared to manage the economy, I refer to our alternative Budget. We set out concrete proposals as to where revenue could be gathered if only there were some attempt to manage the economy. For instance, we pointed out that if the takeover loopholes were addressed, at least $1.5 billion in additional revenue could be gained from that area alone. To illustrate how that could be done, one need only look at the fact that between 1981 and 1984 company tax as a percentage of net profit fell from 25 per cent to 17.6 per cent. Most responsible commentators agree that at least half of this fall in revenue from company tax was due to the excessive takeover rorts which have occurred in this country. Half of that amount represents $1.5 billion in a full year; in 10 months-the life of the current Budget-it represents $1.2 billion.

Everybody agrees that we have a very critical balance of payments problem. What are we doing about it? We are being asked to accept an austerity Budget as the only solution to solving our balance of payments problem. I have heard no suggestion from the Opposition or anyone else in the Parliament that there are ways of attacking this problem directly. I have not heard one politician in this country say that there is an alternative to an austerity Budget in attacking our balance of payments problem. Of course there is an alternative. We can attack that problem directly, and that is precisely what we advocated in our alternative Budget. We said: `Why not impose a tax of 6.5 per cent on luxury imports as a temporary measure?' The fact is that over a full year imports are worth $35,000m. If a tax of 6.5 per cent were imposed on one-fifth of those imports-I refer to luxury items such as orange juice from California, when our own oranges in the Murray Valley are left to rot, and luxury motor cars-another $450m would be raised and, at the same time, the number of imports would be slowed down. We could have done something about transfer pricing, which is one of the greatest tax rorts.

All of these initiatives would result in pressure being applied to big business. It would not affect small business one iota. It is in the area of big business that the tax rorts are going on. There has been no criticism by the Opposition, and certainly no attention by the Government, in regard to that area. A lot can be done, but a fundamental change of direction must take place. Somebody in this country must stand up and say: `We are prepared to manage the Australian economy'. We cannot sit back and let market forces run it. We cannot sit back and let international money speculators make fortunes from speculation on the Australian dollar. We cannot sit back and let international representatives of foreign banks tell us daily on the airwaves how we should run our country and say that, if we do not do as they want, they will sell the Australian dollar into the dust. It is about time that we had a government with the guts to run this country in the interests of all Australians.
