There is no question about that and certainly (there have been problems) involved with complying with the tax, the completion of the administration and technical arrangements, and the impact of the tax.
Fifthly:
He termed some aspects of it as `ridiculous' and said it read `as if some bureaucrat down there had gone mad'.

Who made those comments? They were made not by Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen, the Right Honourable Ian Sinclair or the Honourable John Howard but by Labor Premiers of this country and the Leader of the Opposition in Queensland. There is almost no need for us to make an effort because we can just rely on what Labor Party members have said about the ridiculous disincentive which has been thrust on this land. Why has the fringe benefits tax been imposed? Senator Walsh when he took part in this debate quoted John Howard's statement that there was a need for fairness in the tax situation. I do not disagree with that. I do not think anyone does. Why, therefore, do we have such a tax? There has always been a fringe benefits tax. It might come as something new to Labor Party members that old section 26 (e) of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 states that the assessable income of a taxpayer shall include:

the value to the taxpayer of all allowances, gratuities, compensations, benefits, bonuses and premiums allowed, given or granted to him in respect of, or for or in relation directly or indirectly to, any employment of or services rendered by him, whether so allowed, given or granted in money, goods, land, meals, sustenance, the use of premises or quarters or otherwise;

That just about covers anything. Yet Senator Walsh talked about the rorts that have been going on. If there have been rorts, the old section 26 (e) was able to handle them all, if the Commissioner of Taxation had done his job. But no, apparently the Government wanted extra money and so we have the new fringe benefits tax. The old one would have been quite adequate if applied. Suitable arrangements had been made under it. Farmers, policemen, clergymen, teachers and all transferees came under its auspices. Arrangements were made with the Commissioner of Taxation for a person's rent to be considered in relation to where he lived. It was agreed that a nominal rent would be paid which took into account the fact that certain people would not be able to obtain their own accommodation. It would allow for the fact that those people were continually moving from place to place and living in isolation and for the other factors that had to be considered to make the measure fair. That system worked in most cases and everyone was reasonably happy about it. If the Commissioner of Taxation was not happy, there was all the power in the world under section 26 (e) to bring people back into line.

Let us consider a little of the history of the matter. When the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions he told his followers that we were living in a utopia and that we could have our bit without exerting too much effort. When he became Prime Minister, he continued to say that we lived in a utopia and we could have our bit without exerting too much effort. We got to the stage where quickly we became a high-cost, low-productivity, unreliable supplier on the world market. That started to bring about our demise and the economic downfall which we have all experienced and with which we are fully conversant.

It is really all about that great socialist manifesto, the redistribution of wealth. It is not about the creation of wealth, just the redistribution. Unfortunately, the Government seems to overlook the fact that we cannot keep redistributing what we are not creating. It is essential to the total argument that all Australian people understand that. Because of the many disincentives applied, the private sector is no longer able to create the wealth needed for this country not only to survive but also to prosper.

Government is still growing and, if it is to grow further, it will need more tax. We have the now quite well-known nefarious capital gains tax, the fringe benefits tax which this debate is about and a few others which have come and gone along the road. It was fascinating to hear the Australian Democrats take part in this argument, trying to tell us how through their efforts the excesses of these taxes had been reduced. Everyone should understand that, if the Australian Democrats had gone along with the Opposition, we would not have had these taxes. They went to water and tried to get out from under. They did a backyard deal about which we know nothing. They are trying to get out from under by saying that the taxes would have been far worse if they had not negotiated. Everybody knows that these taxes would not exist if the Australian Democrats had not gone along with the Government.

Senator Siddons quoted from a letter by Mr Bill Dix who said how thankful his members were for the efforts of the Australian Democrats because the fringe benefits tax was not as bad as it could have been. I am sure that Mr Dix now knows very well that there would not have been a fringe benefits tax if the Australian Democrats had stood up and been counted on this issue. I guarantee that they did not receive many letters from the farming section of the community complimenting them on their attitude and actions.

As Senator Chaney said, the fringe benefits tax is complex. A complex booklet was circulated to the business community and accountants. It was so complex that the Commissioner of Taxation had to send people around Australia to explain it. There are still many areas of doubt. I understand that the National Farmers Federation and other sections of the community have listed for the Commissioner of Taxation about 120 anomalies which they want explained.

This is a complex initiative. It is hard to understand and has already cost many jobs. Nobody has denied that. One of the basic issues is that it breaks one of the fundamental tenets of tax law: It is the recipient of an income or benefit who pays the tax. Under this ridiculous legislation it is the provider. A farmer who has tried to keep his help on his farm and has no income for himself has to borrow the money to pay the fringe benefits tax incurred because he has employees. There cannot be a much more ridiculous situation. In many instances, farmers have had to let labour go. Some have had to let one or two workers go; some have had to sack all their permanent staff and employ them on a temporary basis. Some State Labor Party members in Queensland have been saying that there have been no retrenchments in the rural industry because of the fringe benefits tax. If we look at the situations in which a lot of these people live out in the more remote areas, whether they be in the smaller townships working for local government or whether they be on farms, and in respect of which the fringe benefits tax is incurred, it is essential that these `fringe benefits' be provided. Where is a ringer on a station property going to get accommodation if it is not provided? Where is he going to get fresh meat? Where will he get his power? Indeed, why would he go out there if there was not some added attraction to the job so that he would be prepared to go out there and find accommodation and suitable facilities for himself and his wife?

Since this iniquitous taxation was introduced, people have been put off. People who have been out in remote areas with their wives and small families have had to come back to the smaller country towns and go into the provincial towns to try to find accommodation and work for themselves, while all the time they were quite gainfully and happily employed in the more remote areas, with suitable arrangements between them and their employers. These so-called fringe benefits are essential, particularly in the remoter areas, in providing the many much-needed exports for this country.

Just yesterday the Commissioner of Taxation put out a Press release on the valuation that would be applied to some of these houses. There are two methods to go about it. In Press release No. 86/21 the Commissioner said:

Under section 29 of the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Act 1986 an employer may elect to value remote area housing fringe benefits using a statutory formula instead of a market rental value basis. Where an employer elects to use the statutory formula, the annual value for each unit of remote area accommodation is what is described in the law as a statutory annual rent amount.
He went on to say:
The statutory annual rent amount for 1986-87 is $7,170.

If ever I have heard of a bureaucrat sitting down in the splendid isolation of Canberra and working out something, this is it; but that gives us an idea of the concepts that the Commissioner of Taxation and his bureaucrats have as far as this whole section goes.

We are well aware that this nation has massive overseas debts. It was interesting to see a re-play this morning of a British television program which even commented on the fact-if my figures are correct-that Australia's overseas debt is 32 billion pounds sterling. Argentina's overseas debt is 33 billion pounds sterling. There is no doubt that the `banana republic' statements of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) are probably truer than we would ever wish. What is probably more important about that is the way the rest of the world is taking notice of this economy. We have seen that reflected in the value of the dollar. We saw it last night when the rest of the world took notice of the good proposed Budget deficit, one that everyone will try to achieve, but then when the rest of the world saw the fine print in the Budget and saw that the inflation rate was still going to be many times that of our trading partners, it once again started to put a real value on our Australian dollar.

We have the economy in a mess. Extra taxes are not the answer. With the forms and documents necessary it is estimated that over 500 extra public servants will be required to look after this tax. There are at least over 120 anomalies on which we have had no reply from the Government. The economy is in a mess. First of all we have been through the debt led recovery. We are now apparently going through the tax led recovery. There is not really much growth in this economy when we strip the public sector from the growth and just look at the private sector; yet it is the private sector which is the only sector which can get this country out of the mess in which we find it. Yet this Government is penalising the very sector that can get this country out of this mess, the very sector that can increase manufacturing and the very sector that can increase our exports.

There have been many promises of a review of this tax. At the big farm rally at Canowindra the Prime Minister said he would review the tax; but as soon as he got away from the farmers, that prospect of review was very short lived. So I get back to the whole point of this matter of urgency. It is very anti-investment and it is very anti any incentive to the very section of the community that can get this nation going again. We are a trading nation; unless we trade, we are in all sorts of trouble. Currently we are in that trouble. We are buying more than we are selling and we are consuming more than we are producing. Until we right that wrong and until we get our productivity up to acceptable levels-we are certainly not going to do it the way the Government is treating us-we will bear the consequences of this Government's actions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon we are debating a motion by Senator Chaney on taxation. We in the Government oppose this motion because it confirms what most of us have suspected about the Opposition on taxation-that it wants to return to the past. It wants to return to the golden age of tax avoidance and tax evasion, that age when taxation was voluntary for the wealthy in our country. In moving this motion, it is signalling that it wants to remove our anti-tax avoidance armoury. The motion demonstrates also the Opposition's inconsistency in its taxation position. It demonstrates the Liberals' breathtaking hypocrisy, because they are trying to have it both ways on taxation.

SPEECH.PARA: In the last sitting week of last session, on 10 June, Senator Chaney moved a motion in respect of the Government's taxation package calling for our income tax deductions to be introduced in September, and not in December as provided for in the Budget. He wanted tax cuts in September rather than in December, and, of course, on every possible occasion and on every piece of legislation up to that particular time the Opposition tried to block the legislation that the Government proposed to raise revenue to finance the very tax cuts that Senator Chaney wanted. That illustrates the Opposition's hypocrisy and inconsistency on taxation reform. The legislation that we proposed on a number of occasions in the last session relating to fringe benefits taxation, entertainment allowances being disallowed and capital gains tax are the keys to financing the substantial income tax cuts that are going to be made available to the Australian people from 1 December.

It is important to note, as I have said before in this place and will say again, that those taxation measures are part of a package. The tax package is a redistributive measure. It does not increase the taxation burden overall; it redistributes the burden from various groups in the community to other groups. The tax reductions in that package are financed by the range of tax measures I have already referred to this afternoon, including, very importantly, the fringe benefits taxation. On each occasion the Liberals opposed the legislation that we needed to obtain the revenue to provide those vitally important taxation reductions to the community.

Senator Chaney has come into the Senate this afternoon and proposed that we abandon fringe benefits taxation and the capital gains tax. What the motion really tells the Australian people is that the Opposition wants the Government to abandon its personal income tax reductions. That is what it really boils down to. It wants to deny us the revenue. The Opposition is really saying that it wants to deny the Australian people those vitally important reductions in personal income tax which will be in place on 1 December. What it is doing is proposing to take away the source of government revenue which will finance those cuts.

As I have indicated already, the Government's reforms are part of a package. On the one hand we are obtaining revenue and, on the other hand, we are paying it out. They are very important points to be borne in mind. The fringe benefits tax is a tax on the increasing practice of non-cash remuneration for employees. There are cases documented where some top executives in this country have received up to 40 per cent of their remuneration in the form of non-cash payments. That is what we are cracking down on. That is what the fringe benefits tax is all about. I will instance the revenue estimates from the fringe benefits tax. For the current financial year the original estimate of revenue from the taxation of fringe benefits was $320m, rising to over $500m next financial year. They are very substantial sums of money, running into hundreds of millions of dollars. Of course, this motion today indicates very clearly that the Opposition wishes to deny the Government that revenue, that particular means of financing personal income tax cuts for the Australian community.

We have introduced the capital gains tax. The motion refers to that. We introduced that tax to put fairness and equity back into the Australian taxation system. We introduced that tax to reduce the avoidance of personal income tax. The conversion of income which is taxable to capital gains, which had not been taxable, had to be stopped. That revenue from the capital gains tax will also help finance the very substantial reductions in personal income tax which will be provided later this year. The capital gains tax alone raises only a modest amount of revenue; in fact the estimate is $25m a year. But the important thing about it is not so much the revenue that it raises directly but rather the extra income tax revenue collected because the capital gains tax cements the tax base of the income tax. It removes some of the key loopholes in the personal income tax base. So in that way very substantial amounts of revenue will be garnered in the form of extra income tax collections. I have already indicated the substantial extra revenue to come from the taxation of fringe benefits, of non-cash remuneration. Those two substantial sums of money are very important elements of the financing package for the personal income tax cuts.

It is very interesting to note that this motion does not refer to the disallowance of entertainment expenses. We in the Government were assailed in this place week after week, month after month, by Opposition spokespersons about the damage to the Australian economy which they claimed would come from the disallowance of entertainment expenses. They seem to have dropped that allegation very quickly and have consigned it to the dustbin of history.

In Senator Chaney's motion today he claims that this Government is a high tax government. That is what he set out to prove in his argument in the Senate this afternoon. Let us get some of the facts on the record. Look at part of the record of this Government in the taxation arena. For example, in November 1984 the Hawke Government reduced personal income tax by an average of $7.60 a week. That was a very substantial reduction in personal income tax and it was the average reduction for wage and salary earners. The Government's taxation package, to be introduced by December, will in fact provide a very substantial lift in the tax free threshold-that is, the tax exempt income of taxpayers. That threshold currently is $4,595. The Government will be increasing it to $5,100-a very substantial increase. That is going to be of major benefit to the low income earners of this country. Of course, the threshold benefits all taxpayers as well as low income earners. The Opposition, in government, never delivered a tax free threshold in excess of $5,000.

This afternoon Senator Chaney claimed that the Government was a high tax government, but let us check the facts relating to marginal tax rates. Senator Chaney was a Minister in the Fraser Government. The Treasurer at that time, Mr Howard, brought down five Budgets, from 1978 to 1982 inclusive. The lowest marginal tax rate that Mr Howard, as Treasurer, could deliver to the Australian people was 30c in the dollar. The tax package to be implemented by the Hawke Government is going to provide, by 1 July next year, a bottom marginal tax rate of 24c in the dollar. Legislation was introduced into the House of Representatives last night to provide for that reduction. So there will be a very substantial lowering of the tax rate to apply to the bottom income bracket in the Australian tax scale-6c lower than Mr Howard could deliver in five years as Australian Treasurer. Yet, despite offering those substantial reductions in personal income tax the Opposition would want to deny this Government revenue.

The Opposition spokespersons today have claimed that this Government is a high tax government, but let us look at the top marginal tax rates. The lowest top marginal tax rate Mr Howard could deliver in five Budgets was 60c in the dollar. That was the best Mr Howard could offer the Australian people. This Government is going to reduce the top marginal tax rate not to 59c in the dollar but to 49c in the dollar, with effect from 1 July next year. Under the legislation introduced in the House of Representatives last night the rate will fall to an interim level of 55c in the dollar from December. So the top marginal tax rate under this Government is substantially lower than the top marginal tax rate that the Liberal Party could offer in government, and it gives the lie to Senator Chaney's comment that we are a high tax party.

The middle tax rate will also be reduced enormously as a result of the tax package. The vital thing to bear in mind is that as a result of this taxation package-I have indicated that the Opposition wants to pull the rug from under it by denying us the revenue to give effect to it-no longer will any Australian wage and salary earner pay more than half of his or her extra income in tax because the top rate will be 49c in the dollar. The Liberals could never achieve that sort of outcome.

As I have indicated, we thought it vitally important to introduce the fringe benefits tax in Australia. There had been a rapid escalation of non-cash remuneration in the community and a proliferation of arrangements of various kinds by which high income people were rewarded outside the taxation net. It even got to the stage in Australia where companies known as remuneration consultants were established in Melbourne and Sydney. Their business was to devise packages of remuneration for top executives and other employees in such a way as to avoid the income tax net. I find that sort of activity socially indefensible. It gives no economic return to the nation. Those firms existed simply to use the Liberals' taxation arrangements and find loop- holes in order to provide non-cash remuneration for the top wage and salary earners and executives of this country.

This motion today suggests that the Opposition wants to perpetuate the unfair tax system which we have had in Australia. It suggests that it really wants to perpetuate the distortion of Australia's economy into tax avoiding areas and speculation away from productive areas. We have heard spokespersons for the Opposition making dire claims about the impact of the fringe benefits tax on the motor vehicle industry. Senator Chaney was one of those this afternoon. I wish to quote an article from the Adelaide News-a newspaper which has been heavily involved in criticising the car fringe benefits tax-of 9 July, by Mr Brian Francis, headed: `Car tax effect may be falling'. The article states in part:
Business leaders are believed to be deciding to continue to renew company cars for executives.
The trend has been shown in seminars on the fringe benefits tax held in Adelaide over recent weeks.
SA Motor Trade Association president Mr Richard Flashman, said the association believes businessmen had `done their sums' and decided it was still more economical to provide a car.

That gives the lie to the claims that have been made about the impact of the fringe benefits tax on the motor vehicle industry in South Australia. The Government has introduced a capital gains tax to avoid the erosion of the income tax base through the loophole of converting income into capital gains. I will be very interested this afternoon to see how Senator Robert Hill votes on this measure because in his maiden speech in 1981-he is a substantial figure in the Liberal Party and the President of the South Australian branch-he came out very strongly and said that the time for the introduction of a capital gains tax in Australia was long overdue. I will look very closely at his position on this motion. As I have indicated, the Government's tax reform is a package. The revenue gains to be obtained through measures such as the fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax, which are part of the subject of this motion today, will be paid back in the form of personal income tax cuts from December. The Liberals in effect are saying to the Australian community by way of this motion that they do not want them to have personal income tax reductions. The Liberals are really hankering for the golden age of tax avoidance and evasion, where taxation was voluntary for the wealthy and where paying one's proper share was seen as aberrant. It is no wonder that under the Liberal Party ordinary Australians lost faith in the tax system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I strongly support the motion of urgency proposed by my leader, Senator Chaney, which reads, in part, as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for the highest taxing government in Australia's history to abandon its destructive, anti-investment and anti-incentive fringe benefits and capital gains taxes.

The motion is all-embracing and certainly touches a great number of areas of concern to the community. The first point to establish is that this is the highest taxing government in Australia's history. That goes without challenge. This Hawke Labor Government has imposed more taxes on the people of Australia than has any other government since Federation. The proportion of the gross domestic product that as a result of last night's Budget will go to taxes is unassailably the highest amount that has ever passed into the hands of any Federal government, Liberal or Labor, since Federation.

This proves the point absolutely that this Government stands for high taxation and more taxation. That is destroying confidence in the country's ability to drag itself out of the economic recession. Consequently we are proposing this matter of urgency today. The point that the Liberal and National parties intend to make is that the taxes imposed by this Government destroy incentive. Incentive is a vital element in encouraging people to take risks, build up their businesses, employ more people and lift this country out of recession. That is the choice open to any Australian government when assessing and putting in place new systems of taxation. But this Government does not show any sign of boosting incentive. On every occasion the Government introduces new taxation measures it ensures that those people who are striving to lift this country by working harder, by working overtime and by seeking to take risks in the business community, face more and greater taxation penalities. That is what this Government stands for. That is why the capital gains tax has been introduced-to reduce the capacity of individuals to build up their own equity. That is absolutely clear from the Government's approach to the capital gains tax. A tax is being imposed on the future growth of wealth in the community. It inhibits people from working harder to build up their assets. In introducing the tax the Government says: `If you are already wealthy we will not tax you but if you want to get wealthy we will tax you'. This destroys the incentive of people wanting to take a risk to build up their businesses and provide employment opportunities for Australians. The tax does precisely the reverse of what the Government claims it ought to be doing. Consequently, it will continue to inhibit people from building up the community and providing more jobs for Australians.

Let us go over some of the furphies and anomalies mentioned by the Government during this debate. First and foremost, let us deal with the statement that is wheeled out by Senator Walsh all the time about the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard. Senator Walsh says that Mr Howard presided over a great period of taxation avoidance. It was the Fraser-Howard Government which introduced the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act in 1980, which effectively destroyed the tax avoidance industry. The Government knows that. All one needs to do is speak to those lawyers and accountants who were involved in that business to understand what an impact that Act had. That specific action was taken by the former Fraser Government to deal with those problems that were evident at the time.

Senator Walsh also referred to the fact that this Government is dealing with a very difficult economic position. We know that but we point out that the economic situation in Australia today stems directly from this Government's lack of determined action in dealing with the problems of work conditions and the cost of labour. This Government continually points to the falling real cost of labour and says that that protects our competitiveness on world markets. But what it neglects to tell us at the same time is that that cost has been adjusted for variations in the exchange rate, which we all know has been collapsing recently. So the logic of that argument is that while we continue to put on more and more costs of labour, making industry less and less competitive, all we have to do is keep the dollar falling and we will offset the disadvantage and build up competitiveness. That is the Government's answer to the problem but that kind of short-sighted attitude does not deal with the fundamental difficulties that Australia faces. We need a new approach to maintain competitiveness on world markets so that we can build up job opportunities, provide jobs in export-oriented industries, and thus create jobs for our children and for those in the dole queues.

In the introduction of the new taxes-such as the fringe benefits tax-which are destroying jobs, we have noted the role of the Australian Democrats. They supported the legislation and are directly responsible, as is the Government, for the continuing destruction of industries. The motor car industry has been affected by a fall in market sales of some 175,000 cars on an annual basis, since the beginning of this year. This has destroyed job opportunities in the car industry, particularly in my State of South Australia. One would have hoped that the Democrats might have seen the light at the right moment, when they had the opportunity to oppose the legislation and so safeguard the jobs of South Australians. But no, they chose to go with the Government, so ensuring that the car industry was put under increasing pressure.

Let us examine what the loss of 175,000 car sales means to the market. Senator Maguire made a great deal out of the fact that the fringe benefits tax, for instance, will bring in some $300m to the coffers. How much will we lose by way of sales tax not coming to the Government as a result of the fall in the car market? It is more than $400m. By the collapse of the car market we have already lost more than we will gain. Some $400m has been lost to get back $300m from the fringe benefits tax. Those opposite must be incredibly stupid, as they obviously are, to believe that somehow the community will win from that kind of nonsense. Senator Maguire seeks all the time to misrepresent the position on tax cuts. He said that the Government is introducing tax cuts in December and in July of next year, and this will cost the Government $4,500m. Senator Maguire then says that all this will be provided for by the fringe benefits tax, the capital gains tax and so on. The truth is that it is the community that will be paying for its own tax cuts by virtue of the fact that inflation will force up tax receipts. Of course, there might be some element of growth in that which will boost the amount received by some $3 billion. The combined value of the tax package will bring in only something like one-third of the total amount of money needed. The Government is merely giving back to the people the money it will be taking in taxes because of inflation. That is the truth of the matter. It has nothing to do with taxing people through the fringe benefits tax or any other kind of tax in order to give them tax cuts. It is an absolute lie to represent the Government's policy in that way. The Opposition stands for lower taxation. Our policy, when it is released in due time, will show how clearly committed the Liberal and National parties are to lower taxation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't we see it?

—The honourable senator will get it in due course so he will properly understand how determined we are about that matter. The condition of the economy is of very great concern to all Australians. The Government, by its own admission in the Budget Papers last night, said that investment will fall by at least one per cent. That might not mean much to the people outside listening to this broadcast. The point is that investment means jobs, and the only way to create jobs is to back all those who want to join the work force with money and with goods so as to ensure that they are able to produce more goods for the community. That is what investment is all about, but this Government is seeking to destroy investment by virtue of allowing the work practices in the community to continue in the way that they do, by not taking the axe to the Government's expenditure program, by imposing, as it did last night, even more taxes than one could have dreamt possible, after the assault we have had in the last six or eight months with the introduction of the fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax. This Government is totally without reason and has totally lost its direction in terms of what it is seeking to do in the community.

SPEECH.PARA: Dealing with the problems of competitiveness, we did hear the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) say something about a Liberal Party member in Western Australia, Mr Lightfoot, who apparently has been writing to the United States Government seeking continuance of the United States Government's wheat dumping operations. I repudiate everything Mr Lightfoot says about that matter, and I say that on behalf of members of the Opposition. I want to make it quite clear that we certainly do not have any support at all for that kind of principle. I hope that the Government will stop talking about it in terms of somehow being a connection with every member of the Liberal and National parties because it comes from the mouth of one State member in Western Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where are the Democrats on this issue?

—The Democrats are a high taxing party. They have sold us down the river and have no clear alternative policy. Senator Siddons today in this place gave us the solution to the economic problems. He wants not to cut expenditure but to boost it and to boost the deficit to about $6 billion. Effectively, he is saying: `Let us have higher interest rates so we can drive investment down even further than it is at present'. That is what Senator Siddons is arguing. What a load of nonsense that is. Clearly, that would sell this country even further down the tube than we are at present. At least the Government recognises that a lower deficit is important, notwithstanding that it goes about it in the wrong way. It has not reduced expenditure but has introduced more taxation, which is precisely in line with its policies. The highest taxing party in the history of the Australian Federation is now occupying the Treasury bench in this Parliament. More than a quarter of the value of every good and service sold in this country goes to the Hawke Labor Government for its own expenditure. It is the highest taxing government in the history of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: My colleagues who spoke before me mentioned many aspects of the fringe benefits tax that are absolutely farcical in their operation. I fully support their remarks, as does every member on this side of the Senate. We can say the same things about many aspects of that matter which is so close to the heart of the Labor Party, the capital gains tax. In the end that will prove to be a greater disaster than even the fringe benefits tax.

SPEECH.PARA: Most of the artificial schemes have been wiped out. We will always have tax evasion to a limited or greater extent, but with the prescribed payments scheme we introduced and with the proposed Australia Card, this Labor Government will do much to restrict tax evasion. We may never eradicate it entirely, but we will go a long way down the path. The major tax problem of today is that high marginal rates of tax have forced and encouraged the development of tax shelters and have encouraged the more privileged members of society to seek benefits that are not taxable. We all know what they are. We know about the cheap loans. We know about the free use of cars. We know about using and misusing entertainment allowances, the payment of school fees, and on and on it goes. The whole tax system was haemorrhaging.

The one point that is clear is that the tax system had absolutely no equity whatsoever. Equity is an interesting word. It is never mentioned by the Liberals opposite. To give Malcolm Fraser his due, at least he used to talk about equity tax, even though implementing it was something abhorrent to him. No one on the opposite side talks any more about equity in the tax system. As the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has pointed out on many occasions, the fringe benefits tax applies only to a minority in the community, and it applies mainly to those on higher incomes who have sought to reduce their taxable income by other benefits. Often the example is used of next door neighbours. One travels to work by train, eats his lunch out of a brown paper bag, and goes back home to sign the cheque to pay off the monthly payments on the house at no subsidised rate. Meanwhile, the neighbour drives a company car to work, has a filet mignon for lunch for which he does not have to pay and then goes back to a home that is being paid for with a subsidised housing loan. How is that equitable? How can we in this society allow that to continue?

In order to deal with those matters the Government commissioned an extensive White Paper. We held a taxation summit and came up with an equitable package. I would have to admit that new taxes are never popular. We can run as many surveys as we like about tax equity and everyone will say: `We don't want to pay any more tax; we want a fairer tax system'. It does not matter what new tax we introduce, people will always criticise it. Of course, Liberal senators here today and over the past few months have tried cheaply to exploit those sentiments in the electorate. Their criticisms-they have made some criticisms relating to administrative difficulties in regard to these taxes-have to be looked at. The same criticisms were made of the prescribed payments tax. What did we do? We fixed the problems up. Now we do not hear those immense criticisms of the prescribed payments tax in regard to administrative difficulties. If administrative difficulties evolve with the fringe benefits tax they will be tackled and dealt with. It must be remembered that of course the fringe benefits tax will raise $600m. This is nowhere near as much as what we will be giving back to taxpayers in the tax cuts to be brought in in December 1986 and July 1987.

I want to move very briefly to the subject of the capital gains taxes because no honourable senators opposite have really mentioned much about those taxes in their criticisms. No honourable senators opposite have mentioned the fact that nearly all Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries-the bastions of capitalism-have a capital gains tax. The United States has capital gains taxes. One could hardly call it a socialist society.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not at those rates.
—The intellectual wit of the National Party has asserted: `Not at those rates'. The tax will raise $25m a year in this country. How can that stultify the farm sector? How can that stultify business?
—That's the first year.

—I am sorry to inform Senator Boswell that that is over an average of five years. It is a pity he never read the White Paper. The capital gains tax is to prevent people transferring their normal income earning capacity into a capital gain, thereby avoiding tax. What we really should do-what I think Senator Boswell should do-is look at the three-card trick that the Liberal Party is trying to apply. What the Liberal Party is saying is: `We will abolish the fringe benefits tax'-that is $600m gone- `we will abolish capital gains tax; we will not have a tax on lump sum superannuation; we will do away with the means test; and we will not have any taxation on wine'. To top it off the Liberal Party is saying: `We will go back to parity pricing for oil'. This would mean another massive haemorrhaging of government receipts. It says it will do those six things. It says that it will keep expenditure on government outlays at real negative growth for three years. As well as that the Liberal Party also is promising increased expenditures all over the place. That is the three-card trick. It cannot be done with mirrors.

SPEECH.PARA: What honourable senators opposite have come up with is a rural package of $400m extra expenditure. Senator Kilgariff wants a railway line built from Alice Springs to Darwin-another $500m. Therefore, what the Liberal Party is doing is cutting taxation. It will cut new tax measures. It will slash government expenditure. However, it will increase government expenditure in other areas while keeping the deficit down. How is it going to do that? Where is the money coming from? The economic approach of honourable senators opposite is an absolute joke. It is negative; it is inconsistent and it is inconceivable. I will now quote from the Australian Financial Review of 12 August. I very quickly add that it is not a paper that normally supports the Labor Party. That newspaper stated:
Like it or not, the fringe benefits tax issue directly concerns only a relatively small number of Australians.

Those who are expending so much energy fighting it should look at the graph on page 1 in today's issue of The Australian Financial Review. It shows that our trade with New Zealand has now gone into deficit; that New Zealand's imports to Australia have kept rising strongly since the introduction of Closer Economic Relations, while Australia's exports across the Tasman have fallen.
Fringe benefit taxes are now well established in New Zealand. While Australian business people whinge, New Zealanders are getting on with business and taking their markets.

Nothing could be truer than that statement in the Australian Financial Review. When one is considering any tax system the first question has to be in regard to its equity, or it all breaks down. What honourable senators opposite are trying to justify is that some people should get benefits that are not taxable while the rest of the community has to pay its full marginal rate of taxation. That is what honourable senators opposite are saying to us. They are not putting up any other alternatives. Honourable senators opposite are saying that certain people in society must have a protected and privileged position not to pay taxation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on; be honest.

—That is what Senator Watson is saying. He is saying that people in a privileged position able to negotiate a package that might involve free meals, subsidised housing, free school fees or other such things should not have those privileges touched. I remind Senator Watson that when his party presided over this economy from 1975 to 1983 we had a proliferation of tax avoidance and tax evasion. Nothing of any effective nature-bar one thing-was done to prevent those schemes. Honourable senators opposite-not all of them but some, including Senator Watson-came into this chamber and voted for retrospectivity. However, the next time the principle was brought up those honourable senators suddenly reverted to their old principles. They said `no retrospectivity whatsoever'. The definition of someone who does something one day and does directly the opposite the next day in this chamber is well known but is something that maybe should not be mentioned unless with the indulgence of the Deputy President.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe the fringe benefit tax and the capital gains tax are fully justified. As revenue raisers they will nowhere near equate with the amount those taxpayers affected will get back through tax cuts. It is always said that no new tax is popular. New taxes are never popular. However, what we have to look at is the overall mix of taxation and getting that taxation mix correct. When honourable senators opposite were in government they had a windfall gain from the oil price levy. I think that even the most reluctant honourable senators opposite would agree that that tax covered up a lot of the problems in the taxation system. When one finds a new source of revenue amounting almost to $4 billion a year it is easy to ignore all the other tax problems existing in the system.

The Government has made it quite clear that it is going to proceed with the fringe benefits tax and the capital gains taxes. We would have to rectify those administrative problems. I just ask when the Liberal Party is going to produce its alternative Budget. I am very much looking forward to knowing how it will be able to dispense with six major tax areas; how it can hold outlays with no real increase in real terms. I will be interested to know how it will be able to do that while keeping all the promises that its shadow Ministers have made around the country. Will it involve funny money or mirrors? When honourable senators opposite such as Senator Messner tell us how to do it I will do a very unprincipled thing; I will pinch their policy.

As soon as honourable senators opposite discover how to reduce and abolish a whole range of taxes, how to keep the Budget deficit down and increase expenditure outlays on a whole range of things I ask them not to keep it a secret but to come into this chamber and tell us all about it. We would turn the balance of payments round in one day. I tell the nation that Senator Messner either tomorrow or the next day will fix our balance of payments problem by marketing the Messner plan that says that it can do all those things. I am looking forward to that. This particular debate has not been particularly edifying. I do not think that any honourable senator has been particularly fired up. I do not know why. TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill is to repeal the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry Act 1986 and thereby to terminate the inquiry which the Commission was established to carry out. The Commission was set up to inquire and advise the Parliament whether any conduct of Mr Justice Lionel Murphy had been such as to amount, in its opinion, to proved misbehaviour within the meaning of section 72 of the Constitution. The Act requires the report to be made on or before 30 September 1986 unless that date is extended by resolution of each House of the Parliament.

Honourable senators will be aware of the distressing news of Mr Justice Murphy's illness. In a statement issued on 1 August 1986, he said that his medical advice is that he has an advanced state of cancer in its secondary stages, and that there is no cure and no treatment. The advice is that in the absence of a remission he will not live very long. This advice was confirmed in a special report of the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry to the Presiding Officers dated 5 August 1986, which was circulated to the leaders of the various parties in the Parliament and tabled yesterday. I inform the Senate that the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) was advised by Mr Justice Murphy on 5 August that his health was deteriorating to the extent that he would not be able to continue to sit on the High Court after that week, that he was going on sick leave and that he was proposing to devote himself to writing up judgments upon which he has yet to make delivery.

It was with profound sadness that I learnt of Mr Justice Murphy's illness. No doubt all honourable senators will have felt the same. As I have already stated on behalf of the Government, Lionel Murphy and his family have already had to bear more stress in the last two and a half years than most people experience in a lifetime. They will have the sympathy of every compassionate and fair minded Australian as they face this severest ordeal of all.

The matter this Parliament must now address is the inquiry. The special report of the Commission tabled yesterday states that the illness of the judge, in combination with the fact that its inquiry will take at least four more months, raises the question whether the statutory task set for the Commission can be discharged at all. The Commission has made plain its own views, which are that to continue hearings if the judge were too ill to take part in them would be contrary to established practice and to natural justice. The Commission's inquiry should be terminated forthwith, and that is what the Bill before the Senate does. I seek leave to incor- porate in Hansard the remainder of the second reading speech.
Leave granted.
The remainder of the speech read as follows-

The Bill also includes special consequential provisions. These are made necessary by the fact that the Commission has not made, and will not be able to make, any findings in relation to matters before it.
In particular it is necessary to protect from access and publication any allegations against Mr Justice Murphy.

For these purposes, clause 7 has the effect of transferring the documents in the possession of the Commission immediately before the commencement of the repealing Act to the care of the Presiding Officers. Clause 8 makes it an offence to publish allegations derived from materials before the Commission.

I turn then to clauses 7 and 8. Clause 7 (1) and (2) make provision for the transfer into the care of the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives of the documents in the physical possession of the Commission immediately before the commencement of the repealing Act.

As regards documents which contain any material relating to the conduct of Mr Justice Murphy, provision is made in clause 7 (3) to exclude access under any other Federal, State or Territory law, including the Freedom of Information Act 1982, the Archives Act 1983 and any law which provides for the production of documents. Evidence concerning these documents by the persons referred to in clause 7 (3) is also excluded.

As regards documents which do not contain material relating to the conduct of Mr Justice Murphy, access may be obtained but only under the exclusive code provided in clause 7 (4). Specific reference is made to any material relating to the meaning of section 72 of the Constitution. Such material could be of general public interest, and it would be able to be released if it does not contain material relating to the conduct of Mr Justice Murphy. Access will be a matter to be decided by the Presiding Officers. As indicated clause 7 (4) is an exclusive code; in particular, access under the Freedom of Information Act or the Archives Act will be excluded, as will any law which provides for the production of documents.

At the winding up of the Commission, there will be some documents with agencies covered by the Freedom of Information Act. Clause 7 (5) has the effect that the agencies are exempt from the operation of the Freedom of Information Act in relation to documents which have been created for the purposes of the Commission.

Clause 8 is an overriding provision that makes it a criminal offence to disclose any allegations derived from materials before the Commission relating to Mr Justice Murphy or any information relating to consideration in the Commission of any particular allegation. Now that the inquiry is being wound up it would be oppressive and unconscionable to allow the circulation of allegations derived from materials before the Commission but on which no report by the Commission will ever be available. The provision is limited to allegations `derived'-and I emphasise the word `derived'-from materials before the Commission, and any information relating to the Commission's own consideration of any particular allegation. The provision says nothing about materials that exist independently of the Commission.

Finally, I want to emphasise to the Senate in the plainest way that the Commissioners themselves see enormous difficulties in their ever being able to complete their inquiry into any of the allegations in any satisfactory way. My own conclusion, based on what they have said, is that to continue the inquiry would be a futile and oppressive exercise.

I express my thanks and appreciation to each Commissioner for undertaking the inquiry that Parliament set up. Each is a distinguished retired Senior Judge. The presiding member of the Commission is Sir George Lush, a former Judge of the Supreme Court of Victoria. Sir George retired from the Supreme Court in October 1983 after 17 years on the bench. He was Chairman of the Victorian Bar Council and President of the Australian Bar Association from 1964 to 1966. Sir Richard Blackburn, a former Chief Justice of the ACT Supreme Court, was appointed as the ACT's Chief Judge in 1977. Sir Richard was also a member of the Federal Court of Australia, and a Judge of the Northern Territory Supreme Court from 1966 to 1971. The Honourable Andrew Wells, QC is a former Judge of the Supreme Court of South Australia. Mr Wells retired in 1984 after 14 years on the Bench. The two former State Judges were chosen after consultation by the Prime Minister with the Premiers of Victoria and South Australia. Sir Richard Blackburn accepted the Attorney-General's invitation to serve on the Commission. The appointments were finally made after consultation with the Opposition and the Australian Democrats.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

The reduction in Commonwealth effort in TAFE for 1986-affecting both recurrent and capital programs-has been damaging in its effects on the level of effort which can be undertaken in TAFE and has prejudiced the confidence and morale which has been built up in TAFE. We have also dealt with a paper on the harmonisation of the Customs tariff. I really want to make the point that to some extent the industry protection measures which are the subject of IAC reports-the granting of assistance through tariffs and bounties-are matters of very great complexity and require a lifetime of study to cover the whole of their complexities, and I think that this needs to be put into a more reasonable context.

Over the last year we have seen a dramatic deterioration in the value of the Australian dollar which has enormously affected the competitive position of Australian manufacturing industries. Again that is not a straightforward matter because industries which gain from the devaluation sometimes lose when they have to import components, machinery or various other things. I suppose the last 12 months has demonstrated to us the fact that the sort of industry assistance which is the subject of many of these reports is for many industries of much less consideration. What I think is very healthy about the industry assistance area is the concentration throughout industry bodies on attending to elements in the Australian economy which make it difficult for Australian industry to be competitive.

It is interesting to hear the present Government, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) lecturing manufacturing industry on what is required. Today we had a lecture from the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, in the matter of urgency debate about the need for Australian management and Australian entrepreneurs to get off their tails, to be more effective and to do the job that they are there to do. I think Australian entrepreneurs and Australian managers would be very much encouraged if the Government showed itself as being ready to do something about the concerns of industry in the many areas where it finds it very difficult to compete internationally.

This afternoon I express the view on behalf of the Opposition that the calls the Government is making to Australian manufacturing that it must be outward looking and internationally competitive-calls which the Opposition supports-make sense only if at the same time the Government addresses the many unsatisfactory elements of the Australian economy. There has been a lot of publicity this week about work practices in Western Australia, at the Robe River works, and there have been other difficulties on the North West Shelf. It is quite clear that Australia can no longer afford the luxury of perverse work practices, absurd demarcation disputes, and things of that sort. I think it is fundamental to the health of Australian industry that the Government should be seen as determined to assist industry and the trade union movement to root out those practices. It is not something which can take ten years. I do not think Australia has ten years in which to reverse the very bad practices of the past. I suggest to the Government that there is a major challenge for it greatly to accelerate the relatively minor steps it has taken so far-for example, in the heavy engineering industry-to discourage work practices which make it very difficult for Australian industry to be competitive.

In the minute or so remaining to me, I make the point that there is no single answer to the problems of Australian manufacturing industry. It is very heartening to the Opposition to find a growing unanimity in industry on the need to concentrate not so much on industry protection but on obtaining the sort of environment in which industry has a chance to be outward looking and internationally competitive. I call on industry to be very tough with this Government and, indeed, with the next government, in making demands for the removal of burdens, be they tax burdens, cost burdens or the burdens of restrictive practices, which prevent Australian businessmen from performing in the way in which I am sure they wish to perform and in the way in which Australia's future requires. I hope that it will not be too long before our having to consider these detailed reports becomes a matter of the past, and we have a more outward looking and competitive economy which relies less upon the intervention of government and more upon the fact that Australian managers are able to do a job which is as good as the job that is being done anywhere else in the world without the burden of excessive trade union interference.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to paper No. 8, the Industries Assistance Commission report on the textile, clothing and footwear industries. If the preferred option of the IAC is adopted, it could result in the loss of between 60,000 and 80,000 jobs. In this environment of high unemployment, I do not think this is good enough or realistic. The IAC report on the textile, clothing and footwear industries, I believe, does not give proper attention to the community's capacity to absorb the rate of change involved in this report and to accommodate both the economic and social consequences of such tariff reductions as are contained in this preferred option.

SPEECH.PARA: The focus in this issue, I believe, should not be simply on protection but on fostering international competitiveness, with due regard to our domestic situation at the moment. I believe that one of the regrettable features of the Budget last night was the cut in bounty payments and the effect that that will obviously have on unemployment. Protection should not be dismissed solely in pursuit of a perfectly competitive market. It has serious implications for domestic employment and output for Australian living standards, and for government revenue. I think it is totally inadvisable to argue for high reductions in protection at a time when unemployment is high and increasing, prospects for world trade are dismal, and world trade barriers are intensifying.

In 1983-84 the textile, clothing and footwear industries played a significant role in Australia's domestic economy. Industry turnover was $5.6 billion and it had a $2.6 billion added value, constituting 7 per cent of total value added by all manufacturing. It employed approximately 10 per cent of the total manufacturing work force and was the largest single employer of women in the manufacturing sector, with 27 per cent of females working in manufacturing industry. The industry has continued to expand its operations in many areas, while at the same time improved efficiency through rationalisation has been achieved. Since 1980 over $420m has been invested in new plant and state of the art equipment, while labour productivity has improved markedly.

Reductions in tariff involve serious complications which are often unrecognised by the anti-protectionists. For example, resource immobility is one issue which I believe always receives inadequate attention, yet is of vital significance. Labour is not a fully mobile resource. Our country is large and it takes time to respond to changes within the employment market. Labour mobility, unfortunately, is low and is limited by geographical and training factors. There has been a lack of training and a lack of incentive to get people to change. For this reason, structural unemployment undoubtedly is likely to worsen in the short term if protection is reduced in accordance with the preferred option. There is a way around it. Perhaps one of the options does leave some hope. We hope that the Government will follow this lesser option, provided other factors are built in, such as appropriate training for displaced people and a proper monitoring authority.

A further consideration, of course, that we must take into account is the timing of the gains and the losses. Unfortunately, losses and gains are not made simultaneously. Gains by way of cheaper prices are immediate, of course, while the losses are also forthcoming. However, the benefits by way of increased exports are long term propositions. The gains from reduced protection are postponed too far into the future. DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on Computer Acquisition by the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 13 June, on motion by Senator Vigor:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The inquiry into computer acquisition by the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations arose because of complaints by certain computer vendors about the conduct of a tender and because of criticisms by the Auditor-General about shortcomings in project planning for Job Seeker-computer acquisition by the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations. Public tendering is governed by strict guidelines but each department or authority handles its own tenders, within the constraints of Department of Administrative Services procedures. The committee of inquiry has come up with some disturbing findings in this case which underline some of the hazards encountered by Public Service departments and, indeed, most Australian organisations when lay people happen to try to purchase very advanced technology.

SPEECH.PARA: Computer technology has advanced quickly. Data bases in particular offer considerable advantages in information access over conventional filing and sorting systems. Linkage of many remote sites into a single data base allows quick access to well-organised information. However, because those advances continue apace, there has been insufficient investment in the industry on standardisation. It is exactly like the VHS-Beta argument with video tapes. In fact, manufacturers prefer to keep their equipment non-standard, so that customers will find it too costly, when upgrading, to buy from another manufacturer. That practice should be stamped on. It results in non-standardisation and has become one of the most insidious and dishonest marketing practices. There is the practice also of underquoting, underestimating and undersupplying to get the customer committed beyond the point of no return.

Another dishonest marketing practice is to forward-sell new technology. In this practice, the company advertises in carefully phrased innuendoes that its current product incorporates a particular technological capacity, whereas in fact this is only scheduled for release at a later date, by which time the industry calls it an `update'. In the meantime, the company is protected by conditions of sale that indemnify it against failure of its product to meet specifications. This is a particularly pernicious process. All these types of practices appear to have been used in this case.

In supplying computing equipment, salesmen have added advantages that are not available in other areas. They deal with clients who are generally ignorant simply because the technology is not properly understood. One may try to buy the most advanced technology but the purchasing guidelines and performance indices are generally out of date before the bureaucracy has had time even to get the ink dry on the contract documents. Added advantages for the salesmen are the wide advertisements given to the latest technology in computing, so that customers take it for granted that these new advanced facilities are fully tested products. It is almost unknown for any single computer manufacturer to be able to supply an integrated, working, tested system incorporating all the latest features available on the market. Only fellow professionals in the computing industry are fully aware of these traps for new players and they cannot always predict where a particular new piece of computing equipment will have a set of hidden `gotchas'.

I commend the committee of inquiry on its tenacity in wading through the reams of technical specifications to extract the essence of failure in this project. Indeed, this high expectation of both technical and financial success on the part of enthusiastic public servants is sufficient to make them impatient with the normal bureaucratic delays and constraints. The exploitation of this enthusiasm by commercial computer salesmen has become quite a normal practice in the industry. These dishonest practices I mentioned earlier are pretty common, and it may be that something needs to be done about them.

The other shortcomings we have in current government purchasing practices have also been highlighted in this report, and we should learn from it and legislate to try to stop this process. We have a need in funding for rolling triennial budgets. We need to examine properly the desire for equipment and to be able to plan for the full introduction of a system so that all the equipment does not have to be purchased within one financial year and so that people are not trapped into making decisions at the wrong time.

Another problem that occurs in the Public Service is that funds can be cut in the middle of a project, which means that people rush in and purchase equipment which they may not have otherwise purchased. There is a need to give clear costings of all possible alternatives when seeking approval for capital expenditure. There is also a need, when cutting back projects, to be assured that there is not an overall loss and that one does not end up without both the system and the money that was going to pay for the system. It may be that dependent projects are going to get into a problem and cost even more money.

Two closely related computer proposals were put to Cabinet in this case. The first one was an extension of the job bank system, which was requested to allow country centres access to job information. This required some extra mainframe computers and would have provided sufficient extra capacity to support the job seeker system. The second system was a job seeker system providing local registers of people seeking jobs which could be matched with available jobs on the job bank central computer. This required local terminals with access to a central job bank computer. Cabinet, in its cost cutting exercise last year, approved the job seeker program but not the extension to the job bank system. It did not appreciate, apparently, the need for extra central computing capacity to support the proposal. In order to proceed, an urgent revision of the technical specifications of the job seeker system resulted in the dumb terminals out at the various centres being replaced with stand-alone micro-computers. However, the current state of the art was such that commercially available micros at that stage had only limited and very unreliable software.

As a computer expert, I suppose I could have told the Government that, but because of the Westminster system and various other problems with government, the skills which we have in this Parliament are not actually accessed by the Government when it looks at these types of things. Although the revised specification was technically feasible and was ahead of the current commercially tested software, this led to enormous problems for the computer company, which could not supply. The next stage that happened was robbing Peter to pay Paul. There was a diversion of allocated funds. This was done by changing the technical specifications while the project was still there. The two original projects together required $5.02m initially for the job seekers, and $3.3m in 1984-85; and for the job bank program $6.8m, and $4.7m in 1984-85. The revised job seeker program still required an extra $2m of capital funds in 1984-85, so the Government did not gain anything. This is a long, sad story and I hope that other people will be able to continue it.
