DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON INDUSTRY AND TRADE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Senate Standing Committee on Industry and Trade I present the fourth report on the Development of Closer Economic Relations between Australia and New Zealand.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

It is an honour to present to the Senate the fourth report of the Senate Standing Committee on Industry and Trade's inquiry into the Development of Closer Economic Relations between Australia and New Zealand. The Committee commenced its inquiry into the Australia-New Zealand Closer Economic Relations Trade Agreement, which is known as CER, on 24 August 1984. A number of honourable senators have participated on the Industry and Trade Committee during the period of inquiry. Since that date, the Committee has presented four reports which have examined various aspects of the CER agreement. I think it would be useful to recap on some of the major findings and conclusions from earlier reports before I discuss the Committee's fourth report on CER.

One of the first observations the Committee made when it commenced its inquiry into CER was the lack of awareness of CER in Australia. This awareness has improved since 1984 but it still does not approach the depth of awareness and interest that exists in New Zealand. The Committee cannot stress enough the fact that Australians will become significant losers under CER if this apathy and lack of involvement persist. The operation and success of the exclusive Australian licensing scheme-EALs, as they are known-have been the subject of debate from day one of the agreement. Although access has increased annually since 1983 and a large number of item codes have become licence exempt or licence on demand, the licensing scheme still continues to frustrate and thwart Australian export market development efforts.

In its second report, the Committee stated that the agreement lacked a plan or strategy for future development of industries and regions in both countries. The Committee still believes that this is the case and maintains that no one can predict significant benefits without some clearer understanding of industry and regional outcomes. The Committee is also of the opinion that the agreement, in its present form, does not guarantee fair competition in a number of areas, and as such will not be able to promote the most efficient use of resources.

Exchange rate fluctuations still continue to add an additional element of uncertainty into the trans-Tasman trade equation. Since the freezing of both exchange rates, the Australian and New Zealand dollars have moved quite sharply and suddenly against other and most major currencies. This has been further compounded by the fact that our respective currencies have, at times, moved in opposite directions. This is not conducive to export market development.

One of the glaring omissions from the CER trade agreement is the lack of a definite timetable for the removal of all forms of export assistance between the two countries. The Committee believes that it is contrary to the whole philosophy of a free trade agreement. The continued existence of export subsidies provides an unfair advantage to the exporter at the expense of the local producer.

CER does not exist in isolation from the rest of the world. Our earlier reports have dealt with the problem of trading practices of third countries and their impact on CER; in particular the damaging effects of the European Community's common agricultural policy and more recently the United States export enhancement program. These practices not only undermine our traditional export markets but have the potential to disrupt each other's domestic markets if they are used to offload unwanted stocks of agricultural produce.

I now come to the major findings of the Committee's fourth report on CER. One of the major uncertainties surrounding CER, particularly from the point of view of manufacturing, is the ability of each member country to continue to pursue independent industry policies. The maintenance of different industry policies, particularly in cases involving different levels of tariff assistance, can result in what is commonly called ``the intermediate goods problem''. The existence of this problem results in one member country obtaining an unfair advantage over the other. In addition, differences in other forms of barrier protection will result in similar unfair trading advantages. Bounties, subsidies, concessional loans and many other non-tariff barriers to trade are used by both sides as instruments of industry policy. If CER is to succeed, then much more consideration must be given to the impact of industry policies on CER. Unfortunately the wait and see approach adopted by both sides tends to play down the importance of the relationship between industry policy and CER.

It was drawn to the Committee's attention time and time again that limited access into New Zealand is still one of the major obstacles for Australian manufacturers. The very poor utilisation of EALs makes the Committee question why licensing was given a 12-year phase-out period compared with only five years for tariffs-a major issue. To date, New Zealand has benefited from CER. Trade figures for the 11 months ended May 1986, show that the balance of trade between Australia and New Zealand has moved to a $150.7m deficit compared with a surplus of $209.8m in 1984-85. Even this sharp turnaround in the balance of trade does not seem to be causing our trade officials undue concern. In fact they are still prepared to make unsubstantiated statements to the effect that `over the longer term the result should be more even'. The Committee simply cannot share their optimism! On the contrary, Australia will continue to lose more ground if attitudes towards CER do not change. This change of attitude must come from both the private and public sectors.

The Committee undertook a number of manufacturing case studies in order to assess, at first hand, the progress and problems arising from CER. The studies revealed a number of interesting matters. In particular the studies reinforced the Committee's view that both countries will need to consult more closely on the question of specific industry problems. Some studies also highlighted the existence of non-tariff barriers to trade which were preventing manufacturers from freely trading under CER. There were also indications arising out of the case studies that third country trade prospects could be enhanced by greater industry to industry co-operation.

The Committee believes that CER has been seen as a far more important trade and economic agreement for New Zealand. Therefore it is particularly important, in view of Australia's overall lacklustre trade performance, to take a more active interest in the future course of trans-Tasman trade. It is hoped that the 1988 review will provide an appropriate launching pad for this renewed interest. The Committee believes that Australia has not benefited from trade under CER to this point in time. Further, the Committee believes that the benefits will not come automatically, as suggested by some trade officials, but rather Australia will have to take a far greater interest in the future development and direction of CER.

As a first step the Committee has concluded in its fourth report that the relevant Australian Government departments and industry groups need to ensure that adequate preparation is undertaken for the 1988 review. The Committee believes that its four reports on CER should provide the Australian participants with useful background material and a basis on which to develop a comprehensive document spelling out Australia's objectives for the CER trade agreement over the next 10 years.

Finally, in many respects, Australia's lack of success under CER reflects a far wider problem associated with export market development. CER must not be considered in the context of bilateralism versus multilateralism but rather as bilateral free trade in association with the development of a more outward orientation towards trade. Further, if it can be clearly demonstrated that changes arising from developments under CER will result in increased prosperity for both countries, then it is imperative that the CER trade agreement should be given every possible assistance to ensure the fulfilment of its objectives. I commend the report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to commend the Senate Standing Committee on Industry and Trade on a quite outstanding report in relation to closer economic relations between Australia and New Zealand, but I have a number of reservations in relation to the CER agreement. In fact, it has been acknowledged in New Zealand that the implementation of CER since January 1983 has caused fewer problems than New Zealand expected. In 1985 the New Zealand Minister for Trade and Industry stated:

SPEECH.PARA: We have done rather better out of CER than we thought we might. We have expanded our share of trade with Australia slightly faster than Australia has its share with us.

If we look at the latest figures we find a complete reversal of the trade position. Now, for the first time, New Zealand has overtaken Australia in its share of the trans-Tasman trade. While undoubtedly there have been winners-and most of the winners have been in New Zealand, although there have also been winners in Australia, the manufacturers-there have also been losers. Most of those losers have tended to come from my State because that share of trade that has increased most significantly from New Zealand's point of view is certainly in the agricultural trade. While New Zealand has successfully exploited the closer economic relations, I think Australia has failed to capitalise on what has really happened. Undoubtedly we must say good luck to New Zealand.

One area of interest is third markets. Both Australia and New Zealand have decided to co-operate in these third markets, provided it is mutually advantageous. The other area of interest is research. Unfortunately far too little seems to have been directed to this particular activity. In fact, research has played a vital part in the development and maintenance of an efficient farm sector. I think an increasing number of problems require solution through research. If Australian agriculture is to remain fully competitive and to develop its undoubted potential much more must be done in this area. I am somewhat critical of the resource funds that are devoted by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation to do research into horticulture. While millions are being spent in the wheat and cereals areas, the horticultural area is relatively neglected. Considering that the north-west coast of Tasmania accounts for something like 75 per cent of Australia's frozen pea production, I think this is an area in which more money should be spent. There is certainly a need to develop plant variety rights schemes. We are lagging behind in this area simply because our growers have not got access to the latest varieties that are available overseas.

I still complain that in relation to the CER agreement there needs to be a monitoring authority, and the Committee report acknowledges this. A monitoring authority is essential particularly when we have such volatile movements in the exchange rates between the two countries. If we graphed the situation we would see that the importation of peas in particular has a very strong linkage with the exchange rate prevailing between Australia and New Zealand. Because of the strong policy followed by the New Zealand Government until very recently the New Zealand dollar had been appreciating quite strongly. For this reason over the last couple of years we have not had the sorts of cutbacks that we had earlier. Following the sudden collapse of the New Zealand dollar recently I can see a flood of imports from New Zealand, which will be to the detriment of Tasmanian agriculture.

The market-place a few years ago was controlled by the vegetable processors. Unfortunately, it now remains the domain of the big seven, or the big five, supermarket chains. There may be a need to investigate the purchasing power of supermarket chains. That is important from the point of view of housewives associations and vegetable growers. Unfortunately, from time to time, we hear allegations of veiled threats to import produce. The growers' view is that some of the Australian processors are unwilling to challenge supermarket chains which are importing produce from New Zealand, Canada, the United States of America and so on. Tasmanian agriculture must be protected from violent movements in exchange rates. It is completely unfair to expect farmers growing crops to suddenly find, through no fault of their own, that because of a lack of proper understanding, monitoring arrangements and adjustment processes, the crops are not needed.

Also, the so-called fast-track anti-dumping provisions are an absolute farce. They operate only in situations where people making the complaint are virtually bankrupt. Much more work must be done in relation to movements in exchange rates and the flow of agriculture across the Tasman. This is far too important an industry to be subject to such fluctuations considering the high cost nowadays of putting in crops. I commend the report to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: AFFIRMATIVE ACTION (EQUAL OPPORTUNITY FOR WOMEN) BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In my contribution earlier today I was describing the details of the Affirmative Action (Equal Opportunity for Women) Bill largely because very clearly there has been some misunderstanding about what the legislation proposes and what it addresses and covers. I had accounted for the title of the Bill, its principal aims and how it was derived from a serious and significant consultation process over two years, a process that had produced a pilot program, a working paper and a working party report.

SPEECH.PARA: I had remarked that there was a consensus on the recommendations in that working party report, and in large part that consensus is reflected in the sensible contributions to the debate to this point. The disarray and the difficulties within the Opposition are also reflected in some of the contributions of its members. I certainly remarked on Senator Peter Baume's contribution and again I acknowledge it. But Senator Baume in particular would have the view he does as he was on the working party and contributed to the consensus report. I would have been very surprised if he had changed his view. The fact that he did not is entirely consistent. I had described how the Bill will apply to 19 universities, 46 colleges of advanced education and to all private sector organisations with 100 or more employees.

The line on my paper said that I was interrupted at this point so I will move to my next point. The Bill describes in detail the way that the affirmative action programs to be implemented by those universities, colleges and private organisations will be introduced as a phased-in process. The Bill specifies the dates and times at which the affirmative action programs in the various institutions and organisations will start and the times at which the programs shall be reported on-that is, a year after the programs start. I will not hold up the Senate by detailing that but for anybody with an interest it is spelled out very precisely in the Bill. I suppose it can be said that the universities are required to report by 1 July 1987. Their affirmative action programs started as at 1 July 1986. I will be very interested to look at the reports emerging from the universities in 12 months' time.

Each organisation or college is required to produce two reports-a public report going to the statistics describing jobs, classifications and the distribution of men and women in their organisation, a report on the progress of the affirmative action program and some outline of that program in their organisation. They will also submit a private or confidential report which will outline in more detail the eight steps of the affirmative action program. Those steps are listed in the Bill in great detail, and I mentioned them earlier. That private report will not be available to the public except under very special circumstances. The decision to have the two reports emerged from consultation during the early discussion stages. It met the needs of people who had a concern about the confidentiality of information about employees. At the same time the public report also met the needs and requirements of government in relation to accountability in this area of legislation. The expenses incurred by any organisation or firm in establishing affirmative action will be tax deductible.

The most significant dispute and misunderstanding-and I submit that on many occasions it is deliberate misunderstanding-in this legislation has been about what affirmative action means. It is described very precisely in the legislation. The Government and I are a little surprised at the misunderstanding that continues to be raised about this matter because the Government has said since the beginning of this debate that the affirmative action program is based on the principle of merit. I simply say it again: It is based on the principle of merit; it is not based on quotas. Firms are not required to employ a certain number of women or to appoint women to positions if they are not qualified, but merely because they are of the female gender. This legislation is absolutely clear on that. Affirmative action or equal opportunity for women legislation is based on the principle of merit.

The other specific point of importance is that the Bill also spells out quite clearly that any forward estimate under the requirements of affirmative action will include measures or aims that can reasonably be implemented by a relevant employer within a specified time. There is no requirement for employer organisations to do what is unreasonable or to do unreasonable things in an unreasonable time. The legislation is thoughtful and reflects, I think, the real world in which it is being introduced. It has to be said again that those positions were agreed to by all, including the Opposition, in the working party's recommendations. I take the opportunity here to thank those people who were involved in the working party, those people involved in the pilot program, and those people in the Office of the Status of Women and in the office of the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women (Senator Ryan). They had a large hand in all the work and prior efforts that have gone into this legislation. There has been considerable consultation between trade unions, employers, and women's organisations. As I said earlier, the working party was representative of those groups and the Opposition. I mention in particular that in the pilot program three of my State's organisations were represented-the Mitsubishi firm, the South Australian College of Advanced Education, and the Simpson company. I know personally that their contributions were very constructive, as were all the contributions, I understand.

Some people have argued that this legislation is not tough enough, that the only real penalty for firms, organisations or institutions failing to produce their reports is that they will be named publicly. I would have thought that it was a considerable penalty for an organisation to be named as not being prepared to co-operate. I might say that the naming of a firm or an organisation will happen only after that firm or organisation has had the opportunity to advance good reasons for its inability to produce a report on time or actually to implement a program. The other penalty that ought to be noted is that there is a fine and/or jail term if any of the confidential information in the private report is released improperly.

It is interesting to ask again why the Government has been so concerned to introduce this legislation. It is very important to spell out once again this Government's commitment to furthering the conditions, the rights, and the opportunities for women. It is part of the Government's commitment to justice and equality for all citizens. This is a very significant reform, enshrining in legislation not only the requirement of practice but also the principle of equality of opportunity for all citizens. It needs to be said at any opportunity, and I will certainly do it now, that affirmative action is not about advantaging women over men. It is about addressing a current insufficiency and even discrimination in a society that handicaps women in their employment at all levels. We have to ask then: Ought we to do nothing, as some members of the Opposition have suggested, or ought we to address the current discriminatory practices, the current insufficient practices? This legislation is not about discriminating against men, it is about addressing the current discrimination against women. It must be understood that that is the intention and the effect of this legislation. Otherwise, we are saying that we accept the current discrimination and inequality in society against women.

I urge honourable members, honourable senators, and anybody else who has the interest to read the thoughtful speeches in this debate because a number of people have spelled out any number of examples of discrimination against women. I will mention only one. Dealing with average weekly earnings according to Australian Bureau of Statistics figures for February 1986, addressing all paid work, the male average was $422.70; for females it was $276.40. If we look at full time work only, for males the average was $460.10; for females it was $360.60. In my own State of South Australia the figure for all paid work for males was $393.90 compared with a figure for females of $256. For full time work only, the male average was $435.70; for females it was $350.30. Those figures speak very clearly of the current inequalities for women in the work force in this country-more than sufficient reason, I think, to introduce legislation to address that insufficiency.

Senator Hill also made the point that this legislation is only for middle class and educated women. I presume that he does not mean that they should be freed from discrimination and that others should not, nor do I understand him to mean that they should continue to be discriminated against while we redress discrimination for impoverished women. I would hope that middle class and educated women in this country can enjoy a society free of discrimination, just as any other women or man in our society can.

The legislation affirms that it is for all of our society, for every man and woman, to have the opportunity to develop the talents and skills they have and to extend the range of those talents and skills. It is not that this legislation restricts that development to women only. In fact, it is legislation that proposes to enhance the development of talents and skills of women so that they can contribute to the productivity of this country for the benefit of all. It needs to be understood, and I will say it again, that this legislation is not against men; it is advantaging women in their currently discriminated position.

The final point I want to make, and I believe Senator Ryan in her comments will address this more comprehensively, is that some people have asked what will happen to Commonwealth statutory authorities. Commonwealth statutory authorities are not covered by this legislation because separate legislation is being introduced to require equal employment opportunity programs in those authorities for women as well as for Aboriginals, migrants and the physically disabled. That is because this Government is committed to having the same employment conditions in all parts of government employment, and there are already EEO programs in Commonwealth Government departments. The Bill does not cover State government employment, nor does the Sex Discrimination Act. Both of those are State matters and are covered by State legislation.

I say again that this is a very significant piece of legislation. It addresses the current discrimination against women in employment and proposes ways in which opportunities for women and their talents can be extended. It celebrates the principle of choice by extending the opportunities for women. It will enable them to make a wider series of choices. It also celebrates choice in that the affirmative action program is something the employer will introduce in consultation with his or her employees. That choice is there in the legislation. The affirmative action director will not design or establish these programs. The definition of the programs will be available and will be described by each employer. Therefore, it will meet the needs of each employer according to the requirements and specific needs of the employees in any particular organisation or institution. It is a most important piece of legislation. It is based on the principle of merit. It redresses discrimination. It extends equality of opportunity. It is part of this Government's commitment to social justice and equity. I commend the legislation to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are debating the Affirmative Action (Equal Opportunity for Women) Bill 1986. I would like to state clearly at the start of my contribution that the National Party of Australia is opposed to this legislation, although the National Party is not opposed to the concept of equal opportunity for both sexes. The National Party believes that this legislation is demeaning to women. The legislation clearly tells me-I think it clearly tells a lot of women-that women really are not good enough to compete against men unless they have some form of legislative protection. That is a concept that the National Party can never accept. We believe in equal opportunity. We believe that men and women are equal in every way.

SPEECH.PARA: We believe in equal opportunity and demonstrate that clearly in a lot of practical ways. The Federal President of our Party is a woman, Mrs Shirley McKerrow. The two women who run the National Party in Brisbane do an excellent job. The Secretary of the New South Wales National Party is a woman. We have endorsed ten women for winnable seats in the coming State election. Some of these seats are green ribbon National Party seats with a 64 per cent National Party vote. I refer, for example, to the seat of Callide. That demonstrates to all the people of Queensland and the people of Australia that the National Party is the party of equal opportunity. It demonstrates that the National Party is unlike the Australian Labor Party in Queensland, which has endorsed only seven women. Most of those endorsements are for seats that will be impossible to win. I must say that although the Australian Labor Party did re-endorse a sitting member for one of those Queensland seats it did not re-endorse in the meantime the very popular Greek, Jim Fouras, the sitting member for a South Brisbane seat. The Greek people in South Brisbane will never forgive the Australian Labor Party for treating Jim Fouras in such a shabby way. Unlike the Australian Labor Party, the National Party has no hang-ups in regard to race. We have endorsed three Greek candidates. We also have a Torres Strait Islander and a Chinese person running for us. We just do not believe that equal opportunity should be based on sex. The National Party believes that equal opportunity means that the best man or the best woman for the job gets the job.

I believe that the National Party has shown that it is a party that believes in equal opportunity. However, the National Party cannot agree that this type of legislation does anything except add costs on to business and disrupt business. At this time when we are facing a financial crisis the National Party believes that it is absolute stupidity and madness to bring in this type of legislation.

Apart from the philosophical reasons which I have outlined there are many practical reasons as to why this legislation should be rejected out of hand. For instance, we are told that this legislation proposes to create an affirmative action commission and that the office of the proposed affirmative action commissioner initially will cost the Australian taxpayer $1.25m. That cost will be to administer an affirmative action program for 510 firms with over 1,000 employees. In two years time the firms that have over 100 employees also will be caught in the equal opportunity trap. The office of the proposed affirmative action commissioner will then have to investigate those firms.

There are approximately 5,000 firms that employ over 100 people. There are 510 firms that employ over 1,000 people. Therefore, on the basis of a straight proportional increase, one would think that the $1.25m initially outlaid to administer the 510 firms will escalate to around $12.5m. We are told that there will be an office in Sydney. I ask the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) whether there will be offices in Victoria, Queensland and all those other States? We are creating a monster. It is not going to do one thing for the economy and it will not create one productive job in Australia. The Minister should be honest with the people and honest with the Senate, and should tell the Senate what will be the cost of the equal opportunity office two or three years down the track. At a time when Australia is facing a financial crisis, when we have to slash $500 million from welfare expenditure and increase tax by $1.5 billion, we should not be bringing in an expensive, big sister, snooping organisation that is going to frustrate, hinder, intrude on and add costs to business.

If this equal opportunity program is going to be expensive to the taxpayer, we should spare a thought for the already harassed employer who is trying to unravel himself from the draconian fringe benefits tax that is costing business millions and millions of dollars. The employer will have to put in a public report and a private report to the office of the commissioner. I suppose he will have to investigate all the equal opportunity programs involving every woman whom he employs. It will cost Australian business many millions of dollars-when Senator Button and all the other Ministers are telling us that we have to be competitive, that we have to get our business plans right, that we have to be able to compete with other nations. It shows the hypocrisy of the Australian Labor Party when it brings down legislation like this, which will only add costs to business. Senator Button looks ashamed over there--

TALK.START.PARA: —I would be ashamed about the rail charges of your Queensland Government.

—If you want to debate the rail charges, Senator, I would be happy to accommodate you at any time, but at the moment we are debating affirmative action. We are told that under this legislation consultation is required between trade unions and employers. That is also a concept that the National Party rejects. We believe that a businessman owns his business, puts up capital and takes his financial risks. We believe he should be able to make the decisions that are going to make or break his company without any consultation with the unions. If he wants to consult the union representative, that is his prerogative; he should be able to do that. But in no way should it be compulsory. In no way should an owner of a business be forced to go with his cap in his hand to talk to the union representative and ask who he is to employ or who he is to promote or demote. That has to be the decision of the person who owns the business. That is another reason that we will not accept this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: It will also require firms to set up equal opportunity programs. These are going to be costly to enforce and even to organise. I say to Senator Button, who is one of the senior Ministers in the Government, that business is hanging on by its fingernails out there. Business is facing low profits, because of low demand, and massive interest rates. The last thing that it needs at the moment is more interference. Most businesses are facing reductions in profits and are just hanging there, hoping that in another 18 months this Government will go away, that the coalition will be returned and that then they can get back into a profit-making mode. All they are doing now is counting the days to the next Federal election.

TALK.START.PARA: —They might have you. That is a great possibility.

—They can go only one way, Senator, and that is up, because you have reached the bottom of the barrel. Another reason for the National Party being opposed to this legislation is a fundamental one. Clause 5 (9) invokes an international treaty that can be used to override State rights. I was elected to the Senate to protect the rights of my State, to stand up for the federal system of government-not to erode those rights, not to sell them out.
—You do it.

—I am going to do it, Senator. In my contribution I have endeavoured to outline my Party's opposition to this legislation. I believe it is demeaning to women. It is an invasion of the privacy between employee and employer. It gives a union the right to intrude into decisions that are rightfully the prerogative of the employer, the owner of the business. It is costly to the taxpayer and it is costly to business. The women who support my Party reject the legislation. They do not want it. The Country Women's Association rejects the legislation. It believes it is not in the best interests of women. Only 10 minutes ago I was speaking to Vivienne Quinn, the Queensland Chairman of the Australian Small Business Association, who is sitting in the public gallery. She is a very prominent woman in Queensland business. I went up to her and I said that I would be speaking on this equal opportunity legislation and I asked what her personal view on it was. She said: `We reject that legislation out of hand. It is not required. We believe women are equal to men and they should compete equally. We do not need and do not want any special legislation. We do not want to be treated as a disadvantaged minority group. We want equality'. That is what the women of Australia want. They do not want this special, demeaning type of legislation. The women who support the National Party find it hard to accept this type of legislation. When a woman is in a camp in the Gulf of Carpentaria mustering cattle, working side by side with her husband, it is hard for her to understand that she is not equal. A woman would find it hard to understand that she is not equal if she were driving a tractor for eight or 10 hours a day, trying to support her husband, trying to sustain their farm when they have had to let go their last worker as a result of the imposition of the fringe benefits tax. It would be hard to understand that she is not equal.
—Come on.

—That is true, Senator. Every rural worker in Australia is costing a farmer so much money-I think it comes down to $1,700 a year. Many of these farmers are on negative incomes. The average farmer is earning $7,600 a year. The fringe benefits tax is the straw that has finally broken their backs. That is the fact of life. Small business women are standing beside their husbands being their storemen and packers and their clerk-typists. They cannot understand why they need equal opportunity legislation. They believe they are equal. They cannot understand the Government bringing this sort of legislation before the Parliament. The legislation becomes completely irrelevant to them. The National Party treats all people as equals and sees no reason to support this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I state, firstly, that as a woman and as a Liberal I am totally committed to equal employment opportunity. However, this is a piece of legislation that may be framed with the best of intentions but about which, as a Liberal, I have grave reservations. I am most concerned in principle at any further regulation applied by government to the private sector or to our tertiary institutions. I am particularly concerned that this legislation purports to offer equality of opportunity but will fuel an increasing emphasis on equality of outcomes and will therefore erode the merit principle.

SPEECH.PARA: At the outset I must state that equality of opportunity of employment again is a deeply held Liberal belief that is as essential as our belief that merit and individual suitability should be the criteria for filling any position. For that reason I support measures that corporations and public institutions may take in reviewing personnel policies to enhance equality of opportunity and remove any discrimination. I favour such action when its effect is to increase the pool of qualified applicants, making it more likely that the best person will be chosen for any vacancy. Major firms owe it to themselves to ensure that they are not violating the merit principle in any way-with regard to men or women.

The pursuit of excellence at all levels is the best guarantee against discrimination in employment and that, too, is important. On previous occasions the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) has said that the pursuit of excellence in education was not necessary. I am firmly of the belief that the pursuit of excellence in any employment or educational institution is vital. I therefore wholeheartedly support voluntary programs for equal opportunity by individual firms and institutions that involve the training of women for bigger and better positions with no consideration whatsoever given to preferential hiring.

With any legislation of this kind we must seek to ensure the ever-threatened freedom of choice. This means that employers must be free to choose the person who is best qualified and best suited for the position, just as we should uphold a woman's right to seek employment in any career she chooses. All too often in the past freedom of choice has been limited to the actions of authorities claiming to act in the interests of society. We have experienced in the past unspoken affirmative action in favour of men against women and of single women against married women. It was felt then that married women belonged in the home, just as today we in the Liberal Party firmly believe that the decision as to whether a married woman will work, and at what level, is purely and simply up to her and her family. That should be their choice and not the choice of any government. If we are concerned to preserve freedom of choice we need to be wary of any government legislation and regulation that dictates employment policy for private enterprise and tertiary institutions, no matter how benevolent the intentions might be.

Before we vote on this legislation we should ask ourselves, I suppose, whether we may be setting a precedent whereby future governments may create new forms of discrimination in employment by giving legislative weight to the orthodoxies of the time. Freedom of choice over the long term can only be diminished by regulation and interference.

This brings me to my first major reservation about this Bill-its compulsory nature. It was noted in the report of the working party on affirmative action that both the Business Council of Australia and the Confederation of Australian Industry advocated that the field of affirmative action be left to voluntary programs.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government does not listen to them.

—Exactly, the Government does not listen to them. A strong, firm and unequivocal commitment and recommendation has been completely ignored. As a Liberal I believe that the principle of mandatory programs under the supervision of yet another bureaucratic agency is inherently undesirable. Employment practices that are beneficial to employer and employee alike may, at the most, need government advice, but certainly not government enforcement. Whenever we in this Parliament decide that private enterprise should conform to some new measure that we might consider as socially desirable, we should be under absolutely no illusion that the process will be simple or cheap. We are imposing additional costs on the private sector, costs which it simply cannot afford. The cost to the 28 companies taking part in the pilot program was between $5m and $10m. One company spent $750,000. Overseas, the 500 largest firms in the United States during 1981 spent $1.5 billion on affirmative action programs. If the tertiary education sector can take as correct what the Vice-Chancellor of Sydney University has said, he has estimated the cost of affirmative action at $450,000 per annum. Where does that money come from? It comes purely and simply straight from the taxpayer.

SPEECH.PARA: The requirement of clause 18 relating to the compilation of statistics will be a particularly heavy imposition on those businesses that do not have computerised staff records. These costs will have their greatest impact, not on large corporations, but on the 3,430 firms employing between 100 and 500 people which never have excess manpower. Whilst these firms are being given a longer lead time to implement affirmative action, the ultimate reality of the cost burden has to be met some time. I urge the Senate to consider that such smaller firms may not be enjoying the increased profits now benefiting some major corporations. Again, it is disturbing that smaller, private firms will, under clause 13 (3) (a), have to submit public reports as to the types of jobs performed by employees of either sex. Once again, consider the manpower needed for that exercise. The smaller firms, in particular, have the right to confidentiality as to their internal operations. At this stage I am pleased to move on behalf of the Opposition an amendment to the Opposition's amendment to the motion for the second reading. This amendment seeks to highlight the additional financial burden that the Bill will place on the business sector. I move:
At the end of the words proposed to be added, add: `, and
(vi) will further erode business confidence at a time of national economic crisis which was not properly addressed by the 1986-87 Budget'.

I do not doubt that the sanctions against non-compliance, for example, will be effective in compelling employers to submit to affirmative action and I deplore the suggestions that stronger penalties should be introduced. Why should there be penalities at all? That is the question. The effect of incurring the official displeasure of the Government through being named in Parliament has deeper ramifications in today's society and is yet another example of big brother creeping into our daily lives. When so many private firms have so many dealings with government and its agencies, it is quite a brave employer who dares to defy the government, and in such a public forum. There is an implied threat that non-complying firms will be excluded from subsidies and any government purchasing. In other words, once big brother or big sister names you, watch out! Many firms will avoid that risk and implement a program which will impose severe costs and administrative burdens that will not be solved by a provision for tax deductibility.

I would also sound a warning that the Office of the new Director of Affirmative Action has the potential to expand and create an empire, like so many institutions supported by the Australian taxpayer. When the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) informs Parliament that the two major employer institutions have established a council for equal opportunity with a register of participating companies we should ask the question why we need a new section of the Public Service to do the same job.

The Bill's explanatory memorandum mentions an initial staff of 25 with a budget of $1.25m, a mere drop in the ocean of bureaucratic spending, but nonetheless a cost that should not be thoughtlessly imposed on the taxpayers we represent. It was only last night that we saw the Budget brought down in this place with cuts everywhere. It is important that there should not be further cuts.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 29 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What has been the cost throughout Australia of bridge repairs on major highways financed by the Federal Government caused by overloaded trucks attempting, but failing to pass under them, in the years 1984 and 1985.

(2) Who pays the costs for such incidents? Is it the Federal Government, the various State and Territory Governments, local authorities, the employers of the trucks that cause this damage, owners or employer drivers.
(3) What measures are available to the Federal Government to monitor the overloading of interstate trucks.
(4) What penalties are imposed in the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory for blatant overloading.
(5) Who are the recipients of such charges, the employer or the employee.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Each State and Territory has its own systems for accounting roadworks and has provided the following details. Separate statistics are not available in New South Wales or Western Australia, however in each State, the incidence and cost are thought to be very small. In Victoria there was a single case in which a tip-truck hoist malfunctioned. Final costs are not yet available but liability has been accepted by the truck-owner. In Queensland there was one case involving a tramway overpass, costing $950, and in South Australia in 1985 one case costing $1,000. There were no cases in Tasmania or the Northern Territory.

(2) In all States and the Northern Territory liability is determined by the Courts, in the absence of voluntary admissions. So that repairs may be put in hand without delay, the cost is initially met by the Road Authority and charged to the program from which the road is funded. When an amount is recovered in respect of an incident it is credited to that road program.

(3) to (5) State and Territory Governments have primary responsibility for administering vehicle mass and dimension limits. The Federal Government's role is to encourage appropriately uniform limits in the best interests of the whole Australian community. It does so by working through the co-operative framework of the Australian Transport Advisory Council (ATAC), which brings together Federal, State and Territory Ministers responsible for Transport. The questions you raise should therefore be addressed to the relevant State and Territory Ministers. In the case of the Australian Capital Territory, responsibility rests with the Hon. Gordon Scholes, MP, the Minister for Territories.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 2 June 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: What actual progress has been made towards the speedy implementation of the recommendations of the Hamilton Report into living conditions for Service families.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Work has already commenced on the implementation of some of the recommendations contained in Mrs Hamilton's excellent report `Supporting Service Families'.

The Department's Deputy Secretary A and the Assistant Chief of the Defence Force (Policy) have accepted joint responsibility for co-ordinating the implementation of Mrs Hamilton's recommendations. Financial cover has been programmed for the next five years to cover the estimates which relate to the Australia-wide Defence Families Information and Liaison Service.
The Hamilton Report Implementation Team, headed by Brigadier Phil Davies, has been established to assist the relevant senior officers in pursuing the issues raised in `Supporting Service Families'.

The team's task is to co-ordinate within six months the implementation of those recommendations that can be given immediate effect, and to prepare within the same period a detailed strategy for implementation for those with longer term implications.
Its principal objectives are:
(a) To determine and implement those recommendations of the report which can be given immediate effect.
(b) To prepare a detailed strategy of implementation for those recommendations of the report with longer term implications.
(c) To establish the Australian Defence Families Information and Liaison Service.
(d) To prepare for the Minister for Defence, by 5 December 1986, a progress report on the strategy for implementation of the report's recommendations.
(e) To establish a National Consultative Group of Service Spouses to advise on the implementation of the report's recommendations.

The Hamilton Report Implementation Team has no authority to implement those Hamilton Report recommendations relating to conditions of service. This is the responsibility of the Department's Director-General of Service Conditions. However, the team will monitor progress in this area and provide advice as to the impact that perceived conditions of service shortfalls have on families of defence force members.

In conclusion, the team has been able to commence operations on a positive note because of the general acceptance of Mrs Hamilton's report. Their efforts will, however, be directed primarily at establishing the Family Information and Liaison Service organisation as it offers practical support in the field to our families. Conditions of service matters on the other hand must be referred and processed through the departmental and Government machinery, and this involves delay.
